DOC.HEAD: NATO Begins Maneuvers in Mediterranean
DOC.TEXT: Frigates and destroyers from seven NATO countries have begun exercises in the Mediterranean. Ships from Italy, Germany, Portugal, Spain, Turkey, Britain and the United States are taking part in the 51-day naval and air exercises dubbed ``Deterrent Force 2/90,'' which began Friday. The maneuvers by the Western military alliance are held twice a year in the central and western Mediterranean. Adm. Jonathan Howe, commander of NATO's southern forces, said the exercises have a special relevance in the wake of the Persian Gulf crisis. ``Although this period of historic transformation in Europe offers great hope for our future security, the Iraq invasion of Kuwait has reminded us again that dangers remain along our borders,'' he was quoted as saying in a NATO press release. ``It is most appropriate that we demonstrate. ... NATO's continuing vigilance, readiness and unity,'' Howe said.

DOC.HEAD: Random Mail Big Boost to Troops
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The mail pours in from thousands of Americans, addressed simply to ``Any service member, Operation Desert Shield.'' The Marines tend to change the address to ``Any Marine'' as they read the notes, many of them in care packages of toll house cookies and other treats. ``We are very thankful for your fighting for our country. ... The least we could do was make you some homemade cookies,'' wrote two children, 8-year-old Chris Horrigan and his 4-year-old sister Allysa, from Arvada, Colo. The Marines tended to avoid popcorn shipments, which arrived stale. Cookies were a hit, but nothing brought whoops of joy like racy books or perfumed envelopes. One Marine from the 1st Tank Battalion of the First Marine Expeditionary Force opened a letter from a woman describing herself as Single, 26, no kids and female. ``I could sell this one,'' he commented. Master Gunnery Sgt. Junior Talauega flashes a Bowie knife and sticks it into a large cardboard box, saying, ``Think of this as a large Iraqi soldier.'' He draws no blood, but a large batch of chocolate chip cookies and popcorn. The Marines scramble for letters from their home state. Many of the letters mentioned prayers, reflecting church letter-writing campaigns for the troops sent to the Saudi desert since Iraq invaded neighboring Kuwait on Aug. 2. ``Every evening after work, I see the news and I pray for your safety, wrote Vicky Arnold from Middleburg, Fla. ``Please take care and enjoy the cookies. Lt. Thomas Zohlen, 25, of Edgewater, Md., grabbed a bodice ripper novel and said, ``Let's see if we can find a good page.'' ``This is pornography, put it away,'' said Sgt. Paul Young, 29, of Orlando, Fla. U.S. troops in the region will be able to mail their letters, postcards and cassettes free of charge after all. The Pentagon said Friday that it agreed with the U.S. Postal Service to go ahead with the free mail service despite the lack of action on pending congressional legislation permitting such a move. The decision clears up a problem that arose earlier this week when the postal service said it was ready to go ahead with the privilege, but the Pentagon said it lacked congressional authorization. The free mail authorization will be funded by the postal service as an interim measure until legislation allows the appropriated funds for postage, the Pentagon said in a statement.

DOC.HEAD: Taxes, Spending Cuts Not All Up for Grabs In Budget Talks
DOC.TEXT: More than tax increases and spending cuts are at stake in the nearly `round-the-clock deficit-reduction negotiations between congressional and Bush administration officials. As they struggle to avert wholesale cuts in federal programs next month, the president's aides and top members of Congress also must decide how to divide targeted tax cuts that would cost more than $20 billion over the next five years. The intended beneficiaries include rich investors, giant corporations, first-time homebuyers and workers pursuing employer-financed educations. Most of a dozen tax benefits that expire this year enjoy wide support in Congress and are backed by the administration. Thus, their renewal is likely to be attached to any deficit package approved by the negotiators. That package likely will be the only tax bill passed this year. The fate of another big proposed tax cut - one that has been the subject of a running battle between Congress and President Bush since he took office - is far less certain. The administration insists on including in the package a cut in the tax on capital gains. But Democratic leaders are saying that can't be done unless overall income tax rates on upper-income Americans are raised to pay for it. Senate Republican negotiators on Friday reacted angrily to implications that their party is trying to favor the rich. ``That is the old Democrat lie that has been out here for 20, 30, 40 years,'' said GOP Leader Bob Dole of Kansas. His anger was prompted by disclosure of an analysis showing that a package of tax increases offered by Republicans would lopsidedly favor higher-income Americans - chiefly because nearly 80 percent of the benefit of a capital gains reduction would go to those with incomes over $100,000 a year. Negotiators apparently had little success in another day of closed-door meetings Friday at nearby Andrews Air Force Base in Maryland. They will try again Sunday, hoping for quick agreement but promising nothing. As far as progress is concerned, griped Sen. Pete Domenici, R-N.M., ``We're nowhere.'' The goal of the talks is a plan to slash $50 billion from the budget deficit during the 12 months that begin Oct. 1 plus another $450 billion in the following four years. Without an agreement, the Gramm-Rudman deficit-reduction law will be triggered, forcing $100 billion in cuts in most federal programs. But while most of the government is focused on the need to rein in spending, the budget negotiators have their eyes on renewing several tax breaks that otherwise would die this year. The biggest special benefit likely to be added to the anti-deficit package is supported by Bush and most members of Congress. It would cut business taxes by more than $9.2 billion over the next five years by renewing a credit and deduction rules aimed at increasing investment in research and experimentation. Another $3.7 billion would go to investors who build or rehabilitate rental housing available for low-income people. Among other expiring tax breaks that are likely to be renewed: A $1.4 billion credit for part of the wages employers pay newly hired low-income workers; a $1.7 billion exclusion for a limited amount ot tuition that employers pay for workers; a $546 million exclusion for employer-financed legal aid for workers; a $770 million subsidy for lower-income people buying a first home, and a $1.8 billion credit to help self-employed people pay for health insurance.

DOC.HEAD: Average Japanese Household Savings $86,000
DOC.TEXT: The average Japanese household has more than $86,000 in savings, up 16.6 percent from a year earlier, according to a study published today. It was the biggest increase in savings since 1973, when the average rose 28 percent from the year before, according to the national survey of more than 4,000 families. The annual survey was conducted in June and July by the Central Council for Savings Information, a non-profit group of Japanese financial institutions and scholars. The survey said the average rose to $86,700 because of an increase in earned income from a strong domestic economy. In September, Japan entered its 46th straight month of economic expansion.

DOC.HEAD: Goodbye, Goodbye
DOC.NOTE: EDITORS NOTE
DOC.TEXT: The 265th Quartermaster Detachment of the South Carolina National Guard is one of the reserve units called up for duty in Saudi Arabia. National Writer Fred Bayles is with the 14 Guardsmen as they deploy overseas.

After two weeks of hard training comes the hardest day. ``It's all right, hon. It's going to be fine,'' Sgt. Earnest Deloach said over and over as his wife, Lillie, sobbed into his big chest. ``It's okay.'' The 265th Quartermaster Detachment was leaving for the Mideast. Ima Jean Rooker went to hug her son, Spc. Mark Rooker, a big, strapping boy of 20 whose desert camouflage uniform was hung with canteens, chemical warfare gear and his M-16. Her smile dissolved into tears as she reached out for her youngest. ``Ooh,'' was all she managed to say. Rooker's father, Jerry, stood to the side, reaching in around his sunglasses to rub his eyes. Nineteen days ago, Rooker was a college student, Deloach was a prison supervisor and the rest of the 14-man unit of the South Carolina National Guard worked jobs from truck driving to construction. But military planners determined they needed water purification specialists in Saudi Arabia and the Allendale, S.C., unit showed up on someone's list. The unit was mobilized and rushed through a busy training schedule of physical conditioning, marksmanship, chemical warfare and radio communications. Now, it was time for goodbyes. ``It reminds me of your GI Joe days,'' Mrs. Rooker said to her son, her voice choking. ``I'll be home before you know it,'' Rooker said. There was an uncomfortable silence. Suddenly, Spc. Ulysses Calhoun began to sing. ``Sometimes I feel like a nut, sometimes I don't ... '' Everyone laughed and the tension was broken. Calhoun, a 23-year-old construction worker, was usually the one to complain about the duty or the weather or the food. Today he was light and breezy, joking with everyone and playing with his daughter, Whitney, a fearless 3-year-old who marched around with a U.S. flag in her hand, her father's desert-issue sunglasses propped on her face. ``Daddy, why you always wearing the same clothes,'' she asked, pointing to his uniform. Whitney had seen her father on local television a number of times, but Calhoun was unimpressed with his celebrity. ``I'd rather I was on a game show,'' he said. The goodbyes lingered through most of the day. The unit traveled to Hunter Army Air Field in a tight little convoy of four pickup trucks and one van. The families followed in their cars, headlights on like a funeral procession. No one talked in the crowded van. ``Why y'all so quiet,'' Sgt. John Williams asked. ``How about some music?'' No one noticed the rap music booming out of the radio. Mostly they napped or stared out the window at signs and yellow ribbons wishing godspeed to troops already departed for Saudi Arabia. The 265th's immediate destination was a large, open airplane hangar half-filled with cots, a color television, bleachers, video arcade games, portable latrines and magazines in Eastern Airline folders. Creedence Clearwater Revival and Pink Floyd echoed from a loudspeaker in the rafter. This was ``lockup,'' a holding area for men and material shipping out to the Mideast. Once in, the men couldn't leave. Their families weren't allowed near the area. So the families gathered in bleachers set 1,000 yards away to watch their husbands and sons load duffel bags and flak jackets onto one of their trucks. A while later the families sent over packages of fried chicken and had their own picnic as the men ate in the sweltering heat of the runway. But finally, it was time for the families to go. They shouted and waved as the men rushed out to wave back. ``Goodbye, goodbye,'' they called, their voices high and thin in the distance.

DOC.HEAD: Bush: France Has Full U.S. Backing After Assault on Embassy in Kuwait
LaserPhoto WX6
DOC.TEXT: President Bush, declaring that Iraq's entry into the French and other embassies in Kuwait has heightened Persian Gulf tensions, is promising French President Francois Mitterrand full U.S. support for whatever action he may take. A French response to the Friday incident was to be discussed today at an emergency meeting of the French cabinet. The Iraqis detained four Frenchmen and released one of them, a military attache, after several hours. The other three had been in hiding at the embassy to avoid being taken hostage. It was a day of heightened tensions in the gulf, brought on not only by the Iraqi penetration of the French embassy but by similar actions at the Canadian and Belgian diplomatic missions. In addition, a U.S. Navy vessel halted and boarded an Iraqi tanker in the Gulf of Oman as part of the American effort to enforce United Nations-ordered sanctions against Iraq. The ship was released later in the day. The State Department expressed concern that the Iraqis might use their intelligence apparatus to undertake terrorist activities against American interests in the gulf area. Bush denied that all the tough words and the Navy's deeds constituted saber rattling. Meeting with reporters before heading off for a weekend at Camp David, Md., Bush said, ``When I rattle a saber, the man will know it,'' he promised. ``When an escalation is required from me, (Iraqi President) Saddam Hussein will know it.'' He called the incident at the French Embassy a ``matter of grave concern to the United States.'' Bush said the embassy incidents ``add up to clear violations of international law. They do raise tensions, they clearly do.'' The American consul and four other consuls were detained by Iraqi troops at the Canadian Embassy but all were released after two hours. Iraq's official news agency denied Iraqi soldiers stormed the compounds, which it referred to as ``former diplomatic missions in the province of Kuwait.'' Since invading and annexing Kuwait in August, Iraq has referred to the emirate as an Iraqi province. Its demand for nations to vacate their embassies in Kuwait has been widely ignored. There were these other developments Friday: -Bush thanked Japanese Prime Minister Toshiki Kaifu for his pledge of an additional $3 billion in financial support for the U.S. military effort in the Persian Gulf and for compensating poorer countries affected by the situation there. Bush also praised Britain for increasing its military contribution to the defense of Saudi Arabia. -Sam Nunn, chairman of the Senate Armed Services Committee, said the billions of dollars the United States expects to receive from its allies for the operation against Iraq must come under congressional regulations. ``We've got to make sure that we don't lose the power of the purse,'' Nunn said. But the Democratic National Committee's executive committee endorsed Bush's policies in the gulf. -Bush asked Congress for an extra $1.9 billion to pay for the military buildup the Persian Gulf. He also sought congressional approval to forgive $7 billion in military debts that Egypt owes the United States as a show of thanks for Egypt's support for U.S. policy in the gulf. -An additional 300 American women and children and non-American family members who left Kuwait Friday morning were due to arrive in Baltimore this afternoon. Another flight was scheduled to arrive at the same location on Sunday.

DOC.HEAD: Desert Deployment Spawns Two Newspapers; Radios for the Troops
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. military is handing out radios and more newspapers to GIs hungry for news, but it's not printing or broadcasting anything the strictly Moslem government could deem religious or racy. In the early weeks of the deployment, troops often asked visitors to send copies of local newspapers, saying they knew little about their mission or the situation back home. Operation Desert Shield since has spawned two new newspapers, the Desert Defender and the Desert Dragon, as well as several more informal newsletters. The military this week distributed portable radios by the dozens at base camps, so the troops can hear Armed Forces radio and local English-language broadcasts. The radios were distributed after the military refined programming to make sure none of the broadcasts include religious programming or gospel music. ``We are being very sensitive to the culture of the host country,'' Army Col. Rick Kiernan said. ``We want to get the troops music, information and sports programming but we also want to be good guests.'' A transmitter was recently installed in Saudi Arabia to relay the radio, and Armed Force television also is available in some areas where U.S. troops are housed in military housing or hotels. Television programming includes sports, news and other shows transmitted under agreements with the U.S. Cable News Network, ESPN and the major television networks. The Air Force published the first issue of the weekly Desert Defender last week and issued No. 2 a few days ago. Most of the editorial material is written by Air Force public affairs personnel. Included on the front page of the second issue was the text of President Bush's Aug. 30 address to the troops. Also on the front page is a photograph of the F-117A stealth fighter, which reporters have been asking to see for several weeks. The paper also contains comics and a crossword puzzle. The Desert Dragon, a four-page newspaper printed on glossy paper by a local public relations and advertising firm, will publish its first issue within days. Articles include details of the arrival of several Army units and the availability of legal advice to the troops. Capt. Michael Edrington of the 49th Public Affairs Office detachment, which publishes the Dragon, said it has a $40,000 budget to print 10,000 issues a week for 12 weeks. He said there will be no pictures of women unless they are in uniform and performing military duties. ``Cheesecake isn't done any more,'' said Edrington, who has a staff of five enlisted men helping him with the paper. One of the men, Specialist Michael Hixson of Fort Lauderdale, Fla., said the first issue almost was delayed because the Arab printers, reading from right to left as is their custom, typeset the columns too wide. ``It was pretty hokey for awhile but we got it done,'' Hixson said. ``You got a deadline, you got to meet it.''

DOC.HEAD: Kuwait: Ravaged by Tanks, Looters, is Left a Ghost Town
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Kuwait, once a showcase of stability and wealth, has been ravaged beyond recognition by Saddam Hussein's marauding soldiers and by civilian Iraqi looters, recent escapees say. Some report indiscriminate shootings of Kuwaitis and random terrorizing of Western residents. Kuwait City has become ``a city of ghosts'' following Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion, said Hussein Mohammad, 23, a Palestinian graduate student, who was interviewed on arrival in Amman, Jordan. ``People are afraid to walk the streets at night in order not to get caught in the middle of clashes between Iraqi troops and Kuwaiti resistance,'' said Mohammad, who was born in Kuwait. ``All that you hear at night is gunfire or explosions during heavy clashes,'' he said. Elizabeth Walters, an evacuee from Kuwait who arrived in Britain on Wednesday, told of a British man in Kuwait who ``was taken off into the desert, blindfolded and told to get out of the car.'' Then Iraqi soldiers threatened to kill him, she said. ``He was then pushed back into the car and they drove him round again and did the same, threatening to kill him again,'' she said. ``They were terrorizing him just for the sheer hell of it.'' Part of the terror for remaining Westerners is trying to avoid detection. The U.S. State Department said Wednesday that Iraq was intensifying its efforts to find American men in Kuwait, most likely to use them as human shields at military targets in Iraq. ``In Kuwait, there has been increased harassment of U.S. citizens, and more systematic house-to-house searches for American men are now being conducted,'' department spokesman Richard Boucher said. Kuwaitis also live in fear. ``The Iraqis are shooting (Kuwaiti) people and burning their houses down for writing slanderous graffiti against them,'' said Deborah Ahmed, a Briton who was evacuated to London this week. Other Western refugees have told of such slayings. The plundering was not limited to the military, said Mohammad, the business student. ``I saw Iraqi women looting the Muthana Shopping center on Fhad al Salem street a few days after the invasion. I saw scores of Iraqi women carrying away bags full of clothing and shoes, running out of shops,'' he said. ``After Saddam issued an order to hang all looters, the Iraqi civilians left for home,'' Mohammad said. ``But what is the use of the order? People had already stolen everything in the city and there was nothing much left to worry about.'' But Mohammad said Iraqi authorities have hanged numerous Iraqi civilians and officials, including an army colonel, for looting. ``I saw the hanging of Col. Kathem Khazal, who was accused of stealing money from the people,'' he said. ``He was hanged on Aug. 25 in front of the town hall in front of hundreds of people. His body was left hanging for at least four hours so everybody could see it.'' Gasoline stations are open and water and electricity are still available throughout Kuwait City, except at most of the holdout foreign embassies that refuse to shut down. Egyptian diplomats left Kuwait this week because conditions had become unbearable, an Egyptian official in Cairo said. ``They couldn't take it any more.'' A businessman working for a Bahrain-based firm who would only be identified as B.S., said families put their garbage on the streets and burn it. By many acounts, the most critical problem people face is obtaining enough food to eat. People ``drive round the streets to buy food from anyone selling,'' B.S. said. Mohammad said food prices have risen four times in some cases; a carton of 30 eggs sells for $8. ``Some people even go to Basra or Baghdad just to shop for food,'' he said. The trip to Iraq includes a stretch across the desert of more than 310 miles.

DOC.HEAD: Souter Won't Reveal Abortion Stand
LaserPhoto WX7
DOC.TEXT: Senate Judiciary Committee members on both sides of the abortion issue have failed to extract from Supreme Court nominee David Souter his view of how he would approach the subject on the nation's highest court. But the responses from the New Hampshire judge could make either side nervous. In his second day of testimony Friday, Souter denied he would join the Supreme Court with any decision already made on overturning the 1973 abortion rights ruling in Roe vs. Wade. ``I have not got any agenda on what should be done with Roe vs. Wade. I would listen to both sides of that case. I have not made up my mind,'' he said. He later strenuously declined an invitation from Sen. Edward Kennedy, D-Mass., to express his view, legalisms aside, on the morality of abortion. Feminist groups, convinced by his remarks that Souter would join other conservatives on the court in voting to overturn Roe v. Wade, held a protest Friday calling for his rejection. But during the hearing, Souter also gave some pause to the anti-abortion side. Explaining his vote in favor of allowing abortions at a hospital on whose board he served, Souter spoke of the health risks women would face if they had no such facility and sought abortions anyway. The discussion sounded much like the rationale of people who object personally to abortion but still oppose making it illegal. But Souter said the vote did not necessarily reflect his moral outlook. Souter also lavished praise upon Justice William Brennan, the liberal pro-choice justice whose retirement created the vacancy Souter would fill if confirmed. Whatever his personal feelings, Souter insisted they ``will play absolutely no role'' in his decision-making once on the court. Just before the hearings broke for the weekend, the questioning got testy for the first time in the two days as Kennedy pressed Souter on the nominee's defense of a New Hampshire literacy test for voters. Kennedy read a quote attributed to Souter that the votes of illiterates ``dilute the votes of those people who can read.'' When Souter responded, ``That is kind of a statement of math,'' Kennedy suggested that reasoning was callous. ``That's something that I find is troublesome,'' Kennedy said. When Kennedy also hammered at Souter's apparent lack of compassion in the case of two elderly, ailing brothers who failed in seeking unemployment benefits after being laid off from part-time work, the nominee pointed to the legislature for passing the law that created the situation. But Souter was far from entirely opposed to the judiciary stepping in when the legislature didn't act. Asked by Sen. Charles Grassley, R-Iowa, about activist judges and ``rights created by the courts,'' Souter said he believed ``the Supreme Court is left to act alone when the political branches do not act beforehand.'' Souter said in Brown vs. Board of Education, the 1954 decision that outlawed racial segregation in public schools, the court acted ``because we had no decision from any other branch of the government, at any other level of the government, facing the undoubted constitutional problem that had to be solved.'' Souter's testimony before the committee resumes Monday. The committee also will hear from legal experts. After the hearings are completed, the Judiciary Committee will meet to recommend full Senate action. If confirmed, Souter would become the 105th person to serve on the nation's highest court.

DOC.HEAD: Skinner: Fuel Economy Plan Would Increase Traffic Deaths
DOC.TEXT: Transportation Secretary Samuel Skinner is labeling as unrealistic and irresponsible Senate legislation that would require tougher auto fuel economy standards, saying it would cause hundreds of additional traffic deaths. Skinner denounced the legislation Friday only hours after the Senate voted 68-28 to consider the proposal next week. The measure would require automakers to increase average fuel economy of new cars to 35 miles per gallon by 1995 and to 40 miles per gallon by 2001. Supporters contend the higher fuel economy requirements, once fully implemented, would save 2.8 million barrels of oil a day, but key opponents promised to continue fighting the measure. Skinner told a news conference that if the measure clears Congress, he would strongly advise President Bush to veto it. But the measure likely will run into serious opposition in the House, where supporters must maneuver around the Energy and Commerce Committee, whose chairman, Rep. John Dingell, D-Mich., is strongly opposed to the legislation. Skinner said the bill is ``unrealistic, irresponsible and, more important, unattainable.'' He said auto executives have convinced him there is no technology to achieve the bill's goals without making cars smaller. ``It should be called the highway fatality bill,'' Skinner said. He cited a new study by the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration that concluded there is a clear link between reducing the size of cars and increasing numbers of traffic deaths. Joan Claybrook, NHTSA administrator during the Carter administration and now president of the consumer group Public Citizen, disputed claims that cars necessarily will have to be made smaller to burn less fuel. She cited a Transportation Department research vehicle built in the 1970s that achieved 43 mpg while providing occupants improved protection over conventional cars. Sen. Donald Riegle, D-Mich., who has led the opposition to the plan, said he would continue the fight against bringing the measure to a vote next week. ``We've just had the first inning of this nine-inning game,'' said Riegle. ``We hope and intend to win this fight.'' But the Senate vote reflected the growing support in Congress for an effort to reduce U.S. reliance on foreign oil, a subject in the spotlight since Iraq's invasion and annexation of Kuwait early last month. In floor debate, Riegle said the bill's fuel savings wouldn't likely begin phasing in until 1995 and a better response to today's oil crisis might be to return to a national speed limit of 55 mph. Later, a Riegle spokeswoman said the senator didn't necessarily support a change in the speed limit and would vote against such a measure if it were introduced. Sen. Richard Bryan, D-Nev., the bill's sponsor, described the measure as a message to the automakers ``that they're going to have to look at fuel economy and not just muscle cars.''

DOC.HEAD: Names in the News
LaserPhoto NY14
DOC.TEXT: Feminist Gloria Steinem says a Michigan law requiring adult consent for minors seeking abortions will disenchant women. ``If a woman is old enough to get pregnant, she's old enough to get un-pregnant,'' Steinem told a meeting of lawyers Friday. The law takes effect in April. It requires a minor to get permission from a parent or judge before having an abortion. ``I fear women are simply losing faith in the law,'' she said. ``When the women's movement started 20 years ago, we had enormous faith in the system.'' Steinem is an author, lecturer and co-founder of Ms. magazine. --- CHARLESTON, W.Va. (AP) - Former gymnast Mary Lou Retton returned home to West Virginia for dedication of a state theater in her name. The room in the West Virginia Cultural Center is now ``Mary Lou Retton Station.'' In thanks at Friday's ceremony, she gave the center a pair of gym shoes she wore at the 1984 Olympic Games, where she won a gold medal. Retton, 22, lives in Houston and plans to marry in December. ``I would love to coach someday,'' Retton said. ``I go to a club and I still go into the gym and work out once in awhile.'' --- RENO, Nev. (AP) - Actor Fred Dryer will not have to forfeit a $250,000 bond he guaranteed for his former father-in-law, convicted slot cheat John Vaccaro. Government attorneys agreed not to seek forfeiture because of the time and expense involved, Assistant U.S. Attorney Brian Sullivan said Friday. Dryer, former all-pro football player for the Los Angeles Rams and star of television's ``Hunter,'' put up a California apartment house he owns as collateral while Vaccaro appealed a conviction on charges of masterminding a Nevada slot machine cheating ring. Dryer was married to Vaccaro's daughter, Tracy, at the time. The government had sought to seize the bond since 1987 on grounds that Vaccaro was indicted in California on racketeering charges while free for appeal. A U.S. magistrate agreed, but was told by a federal judge to consider the forfeiture again because the government's argumentwas shaky. ---
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also moving on sports circuits.
DOC.TEXT: Arnold Palmer believes private country clubs have the right to restrict membership as long as they don't host public golf tournaments. ``I suppose if you have a private country club it's your right to stay private,'' said Palmer, in Las Vegas on Friday to dedicate two public golf courses he helped design. ``It's like your own home. In your home you can do what you wish.'' ``If you have a golf tournament, you have to let the general public in,'' he said. Palmer said an announcement earlier this week that the Western Open would be moved from Butler National outside Chicago because of its all-male membership strips the PGA Tour of one of its finest courses. ``Butler National is a great club and I'm sorry to see that happen,'' he said. ``But I think there are going to be clubs that reserve their rights to be private.''

DOC.HEAD: Asian Refugees Find More Strife on Road from Iraq
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Asian refugees heading home from Kuwait are finding more strife in the desert, even after being moved from a nightmare camp on the Iraqi border. Relief officials closed the squalid Shaalan I border camp on Thursday and transferred about 5,000 Indians to an organized tent city near Azraq, 50 miles east of the capital Amman. But 14 hours after arriving on a barren, windswept slope, most of them had gone unfed and on Friday, they appeared worried about their future. ``This morning we are eating only dust,'' said Jose Daniel as the constant wind blew clouds of ochre-colored powder across the camp, situated on a field of lava rocks. The Red Cross, which built the Azraq I camp, distributed sandwiches, bread, fruit and vegetables a couple of hours later. But that did little to relieve the uncertainty and bewilderment among the refugees. ``We thought we were going to Amman. They brought us here in the night,'' said P.A. Abraham, who was among the Indians bused from Shaalan I. He and others said they had left cooking utensils and some food behind at the border camp 160 miles away. ``They told us we would have everything. We left all our things behind so as not to carry extra luggage,'' said Achuthan Sreekumar. Compared with Shaalan I, a haphazard collection of makeshift tents that sprang up on the border after Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait, Azraq I is a model camp. Shaalan I's population swelled to as many as 50,000 Indians, Bangladeshis, Pakistanis, Sri Lankans and Filipinos. Many were stranded for up to two weeks with little food and water and no bathroom facilities in a desert where temperatures soared to 120 degrees during the day and dropped to 60 degrees or lower at night. As relief efforts became better-organized and more aid was supplied to Jordan's government, those awaiting transportation home from Jordan were moved to two other border camps and two near Azraq. A high-pressure water line from Amman to Azraq was tapped for the camp, so water was plentiful. Electricity was to be hooked up by Friday night, said Werner Kaspar, the head of the International Committee of the Red Cross delegation in Jordan. Kaspar said there were tents for 18,000 people and the camp could be expanded for up to 30,000. What he couldn't provide was information on how long they would stay. That was up to embassies arranging flights from Amman's airport. Inside the tents, which house up to 20 people each, going home was almost the sole topic of conversation.

DOC.HEAD: Fourth Countdown Begins for Columbia
DOC.TEXT: The fourth countdown for space shuttle Columbia began early today after NASA checked and rechecked for hydrogen leaks that halted two earlier launch attempts. Columbia was scheduled to lift off with seven astronauts and an astronomical observatory at 1:28 a.m. EDT. Tuesday. The space agency replaced a temperature sensor after a helium test found a slight leak Thursday, said Bascom Murrah, in charge of pre-launch operations. The sensor, about the size of a spark plug, is on a fuel line leading to one of three main engines in the rear compartment. A final check produced no further leaks, Murrah said. Earlier in the week, workers replaced a crushed seal on a fuel valve. Engineers believe hydrogen entered Columbia's rear compartment around the seal during fueling for the first launch attempt in May and one last week. Murrah said he was more confident than he has been for months. Until this week ``we were shotgunning it. We were going at the thing even if we didn't know it was leaking,'' Murrah said. ``We have found two definite leaks. To me, that says we've actually found something and fixed it.'' The true test will come when more than a half-million gallons of liquid hydrogen and liquid oxygen are pumped into Columbia on Monday. None of the other countdowns have made it past that point. Time quickly is running out for the astronomy mission. NASA will try for a few days to launch Columbia before turning its attention to Discovery, which must lift off with a sun probe by Oct. 23 or face a 13-month delay. Discovery is the only shuttle in which hydrogen leaks have not been found. It was the last shuttle to fly, carrying the flawed Hubble Space Telescope into orbit in April. Atlantis was grounded in June. Columbia's astronauts return to Kennedy Space Center this weekend for another try at getting off the ground. Four of them are astronomers who will operate the $150 million observatory, called Astro. Astro's three ultraviolet telescopes and one X-ray telescope will observe more than 260 high-energy objects, some of them millions of degrees. Problems with the X-ray telescope forced NASA to halt Columbia's second countdown late last month. The observatory will remain in Columbia's cargo bay throughout the nine-to 10-day mission.

DOC.HEAD: Scientists: Hormone May Lead to New Hypertension Test
DOC.TEXT: Scientists say a hormone they found appears to play a role in development of high blood pressure and could lead to a new test for hypertension. Researchers from the University of Maryland School of Medicine and the Upjohn Co. said it is possible drugs could be developed to block the activity of the hormone, which is still unnamed. The scientists said they do not fully understand how the hormone affects blood pressure or how many cases of hypertension it could be responsible for. The announcement Thursday came on the first day of the American Heart Association's three-day conference on hypertension. High blood pressure affects an estimated 60 million Americans and is a leading cause of heart attack, stroke, kidney failure and congestive heart failure. The scientists said the hormone appears to be similar to ouabaine, which was extracted from tropical trees and shrubs by South American Indians to make poison darts. The hormone apparently circulates in everyone's blood system, the researchers said. Scientists detected the hormone during eight years of studying dogs, cats, rats, sheep, pigs and cows. ``It's kind of surprising that something like a poison can be present normally in the circulation of every mammalian species we looked at,'' said Dr. John M. Hamlyn, associate professor of physiology at the Maryland university. Early in the century, physicians prescribed ouabaine to stimulate sluggish hearts. Later, they switched to digitalis because it was less toxic. The scientists said abnormally high levels of the hormone appear to impede cells lining the blood vessels from expelling sodium. This upsets the cells' chemical balance, causing them to retain abnormally high levels of calcium. Elevated calcium causes the vessels to constrict more than they should, raising blood pressure, said Dr. Mordecai P. Blaustein, chairman of physiology at Maryland. Reasons to measure levels of the ouabaine-like compound in people's blood include children who have normal blood pressure but a family history of hypertension. They could be tested for elevated hormone levels and to see if they risk developing high blood pressure. Such a test also could be used to see whether someone has bona fide hypertension or ``white coat'' hypertension, which is a passing elevation in blood pressure caused by anxiety. A mistaken diagnosis ``can condemn patients to years and years of drug therapy,'' Hamlyn said.

DOC.HEAD: Cruzan Family Vows To Continue Fight To Let Daughter Die
LaserPhoto WX24
DOC.TEXT: Joe and Joyce Cruzan say they aren't ready to give up on their lengthy battle in the courts to allow their daughter to die. The Missouri couple, whose 33-year-old daughter Nancy was the subject of the Supreme Court's first right-to-die ruling, said Friday they hope to succeed in a new legal effort. ``The bottom line is we haven't stopped fighting yet because we believe in what we're doing,'' said Cruzan, a sheet metal worker from Carterville, Mo. He and his wife on Friday spoke at a law and medical symposium on the right-to-die issue. The couple last month asked a Missouri state court for permission to remove the tube that carries food and water to their brain-damaged daughter. They cited new evidence, saying three people had come forward recently with information about her wishes concerning life-sustaining medical treatment. The Supreme Court, in its first right-to-die decision, ruled that the Cruzans lacked ``clear and convincing'' proof that their daughter would want to die. In the 5-4 decision, the justices said states have broad power to keep patients on life-support systems when they have not made their wishes known conclusively. In their Friday appearance, the Cruzans made their first extensive public remarks since the ruling last June. They received a standing ovation from the nearly 500 people in attendance. They expressed frustration with the legal system, but said they were not angered by the Supreme Court's decision. ``We were not surprised and it was kind of strange in a way to hear people say, `Well, it's finally over,' because it wasn't over for us,'' said Mrs. Cruzan. Her husband declined to comment extensively on the pending case, but said, ``I feel like that the new witnesses, coupled with the existing testimony, if that's not clear and convincing then I don't know how you're going to achieve that unless Nancy can raise up from her bed and write out something and then lay back.'' No hearing has been held on their latest request. Nancy Cruzan has been in a coma-like condition, called a persistent vegetative state, since a 1983 automobile accident. There are an estimated 10,000 Americans receiving similar life-sustaining care.

DOC.HEAD: Study Finds No Link Between Cancers, Nuclear Facilities
DOC.TEXT: People living in or near counties with nuclear facilities face no increased risk of death from cancer, results of a government study show. But the survey methods used in the two-year investigation, the results of which were released Friday by the Department of Health and Human Services said Friday, did not permit an assessment of risks in more limited areas around a facility, the head researcher cautions. Groups concerned about the health and environmental effects of nuclear power pointed to that flaw in the study. HHS Secretary Louis Sullivan called the National Cancer Institute survey ``an important step in evaluating the possible hazards of living near nuclear facilities.'' He said other studies at the state and federal level are in progress. NCI's mortality survey involved 107 counties across the nation containing or close to 62 nuclear facilities. Among the facilities were 52 commercial plants, nine Energy Department research and weapons plants and one commercial fuel-reprocessing plant, all of which began operating before 1982. HHS said in a statement that cancer institute researchers examined deaths from 16 types of cancer, including leukemia. Cancer death rates in the 107 counties with or near nuclear facilities were compared to cancer rates in a control group of 292 similar counties with no nuclear facilities nearby. The agency said some of the 107 counties had higher rates of certain cancers than the control counties and some had lower rates, either before or after the facilities came on line. ``There was no convincing evidence of any increased risk of death from any of the cancers we surveyed due to living near nuclear facilities,'' said John Boice, chief of NCI's Radiation Epidemiology Branch. However, Boice said the counties may be too large to detect risks present in limited areas around nuclear installations. ``No study can prove the absence of an effect,'' he said, adding that any risk would be too small for detection with the researchers' methods. Starting in 1987, the NCI scientists surveyed more than 900,000 cancer deaths using county mortality records collected from 1950 to 1984. They evaluated changes in mortality rates for 16 types of cancer from 1950 to the date the facility started operation, and from the start of operation until 1984. More than 1.8 million cancer deaths were studied in the 292 control counties. Michael Mariotte, director of the Nuclear Information and Research Service, said his national network of 1,000 environmental groups considers the NCI research incomplete and misleading. ``Their methodology was not designed to find anything,'' Mariotte said. Mariotte said cancer has a long latency period and victims don't die from it instantly. ``Most of these plants haven't been up long enough for people who have developed cancers to die from them,'' he said. ``You have to look at the incidence of cancer rather than the mortality.'' The other main problem, he said, is that the county-wide data does not specifically address the population most at risk - people living downwind of the plants. ``These are the people where you would expect the maximum exposures,'' he said. ``You really have to look at meteorological data.'' The NCI survey was sparked by public concerns in the United States and a British survey that found elevated rates of childhood leukemia deaths near some British nuclear installations.

DOC.HEAD: D.C. Must Hold Hearing on Hinckley's Right to Vote
DOC.TEXT: City election officials are under a federal judge's order to conduct a special hearing on whether presidential assailant John W. Hinckley Jr. should be allowed to vote this fall. U.S. District Judge June Green issued the order Friday after Hinckley sought court permission to attend an administrative hearing that had been scheduled. Hinckley, found innocent by reason of insanity for the 1981 shooting of President Ronald Reagan, has been confined to a mental hospital since 1982. He must obtain court permission to leave the St. Elizabeths Hospital complex and prosecutors have vehemently opposed his requests over the years. He claims he has been unfairly denied a right to vote in the District of Columbia. He claims he is entitled to do so because he has been a D.C. resident and a taxpayer for the last eight years. Green ordered election officials to hold the hearing on Hinckley's voting rights claim at the hospital. Hinckley is legally entitled to a public hearing, but St. Elizabeths officials said they could not allow reporters or other members of the public to attend. Because of that, Green ordered that a transcript of the hearing be made public.

DOC.HEAD: Survey Finds `Appalling Gap' in Public's View of Free-Speech Rights
DOC.TEXT: Americans believe their views should be protected under the First Amendment, but that constitutional protection should not necessarily be applied to others, says a group that conducted a private survey on free speech. Americans surveyed overwhelmingly believe the Constitution guarantees their individual freedom of expression but more than one-fourth say that protection shouldn't apply to the arts or the media, according to the survey released Friday by the Thomas Jefferson Center for the Protection of Free Expression. The nationwide telephone survey of 1,500 adults in June also showed that while nearly three-fourths defended an artist's right to display works that might be offensive, fewer than 25 percent favored supporting those works with tax funds. Robert O'Neil, founding director of the center, said the survey spotlighted ``an appalling gap'' in public understanding of free speech and equally protected freedom of the press. ``We found alarming evidence of a double standard, a sense that the First Amendment protects what the speaker wants to say, but not so clearly the views of others,'' O'Neil said, releasing the survey results at a news conference on the steps of the Jefferson Memorial. While 90 percent of Americans believe the government has no business telling them what to say, nearly 59 percent said the government should have some power of censorship, according to the center's survey. In addition, more than half said the government has the right to ban the sale of recordings that favor drug use or broadcasting of sexually explicit lyrics; 84 percent favored mandatory labeling of recorded songs containing such lyrics. The survey said between 25 percent and 30 percent of those questioned believed the First Amendment's guarantees of free speech didn't cover art works, films, music, radio, cable and network television, play, newspapers or photographs. On federal support for controversial art, an issue that has plagued the National Endowment for the Arts for months, the survey showed that nearly 74 percent of Americans backed artists' rights to display works that might be offensive. But 72 percent opposed spending tax money for ``objectionable'' art, films or plays, the survey said. O'Neil urged Congress not to impose any new anti-obscenity restrictions on the NEA, the same position taken earlier this week by a bipartisan study commission created by Congress. ``It is one thing for government simply not to be a patron of the arts,'' said O'Neil, a legal scholar and former president of the University of Virginia. ``It is quite another for government to say it will support only individual works or artists it does not deem objectionable.'' The center is a non-profit, non-partisan, privately financed institute associated with the University of Virginia that defends First Amendment rights of free expression. Its trustees include syndicated columnist James J. Kilpatrick Jr., film producer Richard Roth, American Civil Liberties Union president Norman Dorsen, and political consultant Mary Dent Crisp, former co-chairwoman of the Republican National Committee.

DOC.HEAD: Governor's Return Ends Mutiny
DOC.TEXT: The ``Massachusetts mutiny'' ended quietly when Gov. Michael S. Dukakis returned from Europe and his lieutenant governor returned to second in command. Lt. Gov. Evelyn Murphy dropped out of the Democratic primary for governor after attempting last week to take control of the state's sagging finances by ordering cuts in spending. Critics contended Murphy's mutinous behavior while Dukakis was on a European trade mission was aimed at boosting her founderng campaign. Dukakis ended her brief reign as acting governor Friday when he returned. Dukakis, who is not seeking re-election, planned to meet today with aides to discuss the state budget, which is running a deficit just two months into the fiscal year. Some elements of Murphy's plans to cut spending might be adopted, said S. Stephen Rosenfeld, Dukakis' chief of staff. ``I will take advice from anybody and everybody who can constructively participate in this - that includes the lieutenant governor,'' Dukakis told reporters. Murphy said her plans would save the state about $150 million annually. She called for slashing about 1,000 state jobs.

DOC.HEAD: Administration Considering $18 Billion Arms Sale To Saudis
DOC.TEXT: The administration is preparing to submit to Congress a request to sell Saudi Arabia $18 billion worth of weapons, including F-15 fighter planes, tanks and other sophisticated arms, an official says. Officials at the State and Defense departments were working with Saudi officials to determine that country's needs to withstand the military threat posed by Iraqi President Saddam Hussein. ``It's not all finalized yet, and it won't be until we submit it to Congress,'' said the official, who spoke on the condition of anonymity. If it goes through, it is believed the sale would be the largest single arms deal in U.S. history. The administration has already proposed selling Saudi Arabia $3 billion in new weapons to bolster its defenses, including F-15 fighter planes, M-60 tanks, 15,000 rounds of armor-piercing anti-tank ammunition and 200 Stinger anti-aircraft missiles, according to congressional sources. The larger package includes 24 additional F-15s, as many as 48 Apache helicopters, 385 M-1A2 tanks, 400-500 M-2 Bradley armed personnel carriers and thousands of trucks and jeeps, the New York Times said in today's editions. The Washington Post, in its editions today, said the package would range from $18 billion to $23 billion and also would include Patriot air defense systems, naval command and control systems and thousands of tons of ammunition. Earlier in the day, an administration official noted that additional sales had been promised to Saudi Arabia when the latest package was recently announced. However, the official said, ``No recommendations have come to the White House.'' Once the larger package is submitted to Congress, lawmakers will have two months during which they can debate it and decide whether to approve the sale. The White House had approved the sale in principle and passed the plans along to technical teams to work on the details, the official said. The administration is trying to speed up submitting the package in order to take advantage of the bipartisan support for President Bush's policy on Saudi Arabia and his decision to send more than 100,000 troops to defend the oil-rich kingdom, said another official familiar with the deal.

DOC.HEAD: Mossad Book Selling Fast, Stores Await More Shipments
DOC.TEXT: A book about Israel's secret service that Israel tried to suppress has sold out all over town and orders to the publisher have more than doubled. Bookstores were swamped Friday with requests for copies of ``By Way of Deception: The Making and Unmaking of a Mossad Officer.'' Thursday, a state appeals court approved distribution of the book, reversing a judge's decision to ban sale of the book at the request of the Israeli government. St. Martin's Press, the publisher, originally received orders for 50,000 copies. This week orders jumped to more than 100,000. ``It is a recurring phenomenon that if someone wants to stop publication of a book, just the opposite occurs. Many people will read it who wouldn't otherwise,'' said Roy Gainsburg, president of St. Martin's Press. Israel claims the book could endanger its intelligence agents by blowing their covers. The author, Victor Ostrovsky, says he was a Mossad agent for four years in the 1980s. He wrote in the book that Israel had detailed information about preparations for the bombing that killed 241 U.S. Marines in Lebanon in 1983 but gave the United States only a vague warning so that U.S.-Arab relations would be damaged. A sampling of city bookstores Friday found most still waiting for their copies of the book, but managers said readers were asking for it already. ``Every other call last night was a request for the book,'' said Jill Tardiff, general manager of a Doubleday bookstore on Fifth Avenue. The store has increased its order to over 500 copies, she added. Four shops in the Waldenbooks chain said they had received shipments of the book and almost immediately sold out. About 30 copies of the book arrived at a Waldenbooks store in the financial district Thursday afternoon after the appeals court lifted the ban, said Roman Schreiner, the store's manager. ``We sold out this morning, shortly after opening,'' he said Friday. St. Martin's had already shipped some 17,000 copies of the book to 1,500 stores and reviewers before Israel obtained the temporary order to ban sales. Gainsburg said 30,000 copies of the book that could not be sent Thursday because of the ban were shipped Friday.

DOC.HEAD: Major Events at the New York Post
With PM-Post Talks, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Here is a chronology of the New York Post, the nation's oldest continuously published daily newspaper.

Nov. 16, 1801 - Post founded by, among others, Alexander Hamilton, the nation's first Treasury secretary, and former New York Gov. John Jay, later chief justice of the Supreme Court, as a polite, liberal publication for the city's upper class. 1829 - William Cullen Bryant begins his 48 years as editor. 1881 - Sold to railroad tycoon Henry Villard. 1903 - Passed on to Villard's son, Osward Garrison Villard. 1914 - Sold to banker Thomas Lamont. 1922 - Sold to a syndicate of 34 owners, including Franklin Delano Roosevelt. 1924 - Sold to Cyrus H. K. Curtis, publisher of the Saturday Evening Post. 1935 - Sold to Philadelphia publisher J. David Stern, who was persuaded by Roosevelt to keep the paper going after Curtis' death. 1939 - Bought by City Councilman George Backer and his wife, banking heiress Dorothy Schiff. They divorced in 1942 and Mrs. Schiff assumed sole control and turned the newspaper into a tabloid. 1966 - The Post becomes the only afternoon newspaper in New York City as the number of dailies shrink in the wake of a strike. 1967 - Moved to 210 South St., former plant of the defunct Journal-American, and circulation rises to 700,000. 1976 - Mrs. Schiff sold the Post for about $31 million to Australian publisher Rupert Murdoch, who was building his media holdings in the United States. 1983 - Circulation reached 962,000. 1986 - Murdoch granted two-year wiver by Federal Communications Commission on rule barring cross-ownership of newspaper and television station in the same city. Sept. 30, 1987 - Post circulation had dropped to 690,915. Oct. 23, 1987 - Cutbacks become effective. Dec. 30, 1987 - Congress approved measure preventing the FCC from repealing or modifying its newspaper-television cross-ownership rule. Jan. 14, 1988 - FCC gave Murdoch until March 6 to sell the Post or his TV station. Feb. 7, 1988 - Developer Peter Kalikow agrees to buy paper, contingent upon $24 million in union concessions Murdoch called essential to continued operation. May 10, 1988 - Kalikow names Jane Amsterdam editor to raise paper's ``journalistic standards and practices.'' March 5, 1989 - A Sunday edition is launched. May 31, 1989 - Jerry Nachman is named editor, signaling a return to all-out, slam-bang tabloid coverage, but circulation continues to slide, falling to just above half a million. Nov. 26, 1989 - Sunday edition scrapped. Sept. 4, 1990 - Kalikow tells unions the Post cannot survive unless it gets $19 million worth of contract concessions. Sept. 14, 1990 - Ten of the Post's 11 unions agree to concessions and the newspaper continues to publish at least until Sept. 17, when the last and largest union, The Newspaper Guild, votes on management's final offer.

DOC.HEAD: Australian, U.S. Warships Fire On, Board Iraqi Tanker
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: American and Australian warships fired warning shots and then boarded an Iraqi oil tanker in the Gulf of Oman, U.S. Navy officials said. Friday's interception was the third reported shooting incident since the U.N.-backed sea blockade of Iraq began five weeks ago, and the first involving any other than a U.S. member of the multinational force enforcing the sanctions. The tanker, identified as the 41,400-ton Al-Fao, at first ignored .50-caliber machine gunshots by the U.S. frigate Brewton, but stopped after a second volley by the Australian missile frigate Darwin, they said. Cmdr. Dave Knox, a U.S. spokesman, said the two frigates, on blockade duty in the waters just outside the Strait of Hormuz, the entrance to the Persian Gulf, intercepted the tanker and were advised that it was an Iraqi ship, sailing empty and bound for the Iraqi port of Basra. He said the Brewton, a 4,200-ton frigate, requested the tanker to stop and allow a boarding party to inspect it. ``After repeated requests, the Brewton fired warning shots with its .50-caliber machine gun,'' he said. When the tanker refused to stop, the Darwin fired more warning shots with a .50-caliber machine gun. ``The master of the Al-Fao then advised that he was stopping the ship and would permit boarding,'' Knox said. He said a combined naval-coast guard team from the Brewton and another team from the Darwin boarded the tanker. ``They discovered no prohibited cargo and the Al-Fao was allowed to proceed.'' he said. Two American missile frigates fired warning shots at two Iraqi tankers in and near the Persian Gulf on Aug. 18 but did not attempt to stop or board the vessels. Since then the U.N. Security Council has approved the use of ``minimal force'' by members of the multinational force in the gulf region to prevent ships from carrying cargo to and from Iraq. The embargo aims to force Iraq's withdrawal from oil-rich Kuwait, which was invaded Aug. 2. U.S. warships have challenged 900 commercial ships and boarded 23 before Friday's incident, according to U.S. military officials here. Al-Fao is one of several Iraqi tankers that have tried to run the U.N.-sponsored blockade but was turned away last month from the Saudi Arabian port of Yanbu, on the Red Sea. The Brewton is a member of the U.S. battle group led by the aircraft carrier Independence in the north Arabian Sea. The Darwin and a sister ship, the Adelaide, arrived in the region Aug. 30 to join the multinational force.

DOC.HEAD: Gulf at a Glance
DOC.TEXT: Here, at a glance, are the latest developments in the Persian Gulf crisis:

Western nations sharply protested Iraq's raids Friday on the French, Belgian and Canadian diplomatic compounds in occupied Kuwait. Since its Aug 2. invasion, Iraq has ordered all embassies in Kuwait to close. French President Francois Mitterrand called an emergency Cabinet meeting for today. France said Iraqi troops removed four people, including a diplomat, from the French ambassador's residence and took them to an unknown destination. Iraq denied its soldiers entered the compounds. --- U.S. and Australian Navy ships fired warning shots and halted an Iraqi tanker in the Gulf of Oman on Friday as part of the effort to enforce trading sanctions against Iraq. After a boarding party identified the cargo, the tanker Al-Fa was allowed to proceed to its destination. --- More than 360 evacuees, mostly American women and children, arrived in London late Friday on a flight from Iraq. The Americans were due to leave for Baltimore this afternoon. An estimated 2,200 Americans remain captive in Iraq and Kuwait. --- Military pressure on Iraq intensified. Britain said it will send an armored brigade of more than 120 tanks and 6,000 combat troops to the Persian Gulf, and Canada committed a dozen fighter jets, 450 fliers and ground crew. Italy, Belgium and South Korea pledged either money or equipment. --- Secretary of State James A. Baker III was scheduled to travel to West Germany today. He's urging NATO allies to send troops to symbolize shared involvement with the military buildup. President Bush asked Congress on Friday for $1.9 billion more toward Operation Desert Shield, which officials say is costing Washington an estimated $1 billion a month. The administration also is preparing to ask Congress to approve the sale to Saudi Arabia of $18 billion worth of F-15 fighter jets, tanks and other sophisticated arms, a U.S. official source said. --- Iraq announced plans to ration bread beginning today. Rationing of sugar, rice, cooking oil, soap and detergent began in some neighborhoods earlier this month.

DOC.HEAD: Lotto Fever Rages in Florida
DOC.TEXT: Lines were long and dreams were big for tonight's $100 million Lotto drawing. It was possible, but not probable, that the jackpot will end up at more than $115 million, the amount of the nation's highest, Lottery Secretary Rebecca Paul said Friday. The chance of a single winner was nearly one in 14 million, which is the number of possible combinations of six numbers. It was likelier the riches will be split among several winners. With 100 million tickets expected to be sold by tonight's drawing, there was only one chance in 200 that no one will pick all the winning numbers, lottery spokesman Ed George said. And they could come from anywhere. ``Everybody who knew I was coming to Florida this week wanted me to buy them Lotto tickets,'' said Frank Greer, a Washington campaign consultant for Democratic gubernatorial candidate Lawton Chiles. ``That's all anyone is talking about.'' The state Lottery Department fielded calls from across the country and Canada, George said. The $1 Lotto tickets were hustled for $3 to $5 at newsstands on Wall Street and midtown Manhattan. A dry cleaning shop in Washington, D.C., was shut down Friday for illegal sales. Authorities said more than $1,000 in cash was seized along with a lottery machine and gaming receipts. In Georgia, a couple who parked their pickup truck at a Macon shopping mall and posted a sign saying ``Florida lottery tickets for sale'' was arrested Wednesday on commercial gambling charges. Michael LaBruno, a self-proclaimed ``Lotto nut'' from Jersey City, N.J., flew to Jacksonville and bought $7,600 in tickets at a convenience store. It took almost five hours to process the tickets and cost him $600 in air fare. Connecticut businesses that deliver tickets for out-of-state lotteries were swamped with customers, most interested in the Florida drawing. Thomas Wilkison, owner of the Manchester Lotto Express office, said his office took orders for 20,000 tickets Wednesday. By mid-afternoon Thursday, 17,000 more had been taken. Florida's previous record Lotto prize was $58 million, split between five winners in April. Each winning ticket was worth almost $11.7 million to be paid over 20 years. The record for a prize to a single winner of a computerized numbers game is held by Sheelah Ryan of Winter Springs, who won a $55.1 million Florida Lotto jackpot in September 1988. The current jackpot was missed four weeks in a row, rolling over each time. Pennsylvania's lottery produced the nation's highest jackpot in April 1989. It paid the holders of 14 winning tickets $8.3 million over 26 years. Throughout the week in Florida, there were several reports of Lotto players spending $10,000 on the weekly computerized game. But not all were big spenders. A mother of three in Apopka bought a Lotto ticket with 100 pennies. ``It was all we had,'' said Melanie Faby, 37. ``If we win, I'll start a foundation to help abused children and women.''

DOC.HEAD: Americans Report Dwindling Kuwaiti Resistance; Hungry Iraqis Eat Zoo Animals
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Plane scheduled to leave at 9 a.m. EDT, with scheduled arrival in Baltimore at 4:30 p.m.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: U.S. evacuees say Iraqi troops are wiping out the Kuwaiti resistance fighters, and an animal rights official accused the Iraqi forces of eating most of the animals in Kuwait's zoo. More than 270 Americans were to leave today for Baltimore after arriving at Gatwick airport outside London along with other nationalities aboard an Iraqi jet the night before, the U.S. Embassy said. Galina Suliman from San Francisco, who arrived on the Iraqi Airways Boeing 747 from Baghdad, said: ``The Kuwaiti resistance has been put down ruthlessly by the Iraqis in the past day or two.'' Her husband, Rani, said he saw the bodies of seven Kuwaitis hanged by the Iraqis for looting. ``One was hanging from a crane. They left him there for four days,'' he said. Andrea Hanson from Portland, Ore., who arrived on the same U.S.-chartered flight into Gatwick, said Kuwaiti groups did not have enough weapons to fight the Iraqis. The Times of London today quoted Victor Watkins, an official of the World Society for the Protection of Animals, as saying Iraqi soldiers in Kuwait have eaten 70 percent of the edible animals in Kuwait's zoo. The zoo's staff fled after the invasion, and the animal protection group fears that all the animals in the zoo may have been wiped out, including rare species such as the soemmerings gazelle and the shoebill stalk. The newspaper article did not specify how Watkins got his information or how many animals were in the zoo. Watkins, the society's director for the Middle East, said the soldiers have eaten many antelope and deer. ``It is a dreadful situation. Things are desperate enought for the people, so anyone might understand how bad it is for the animals.'' On Friday's flight to Gatwick, there were believed to be 275 Americans plus 43 Canadians, 26 Britons, six Japanese, six Australians, two West Germans and a number of Indians, Syrians and Filipinos, the British domestic news agency Press Association. Most were women and children but there was confusion about precise numbers. An official at the U.S. Embassy said today he did not know the exact number of Americans. The plane left Baghdad Friday afternoon and landed at Gatwick 25 miles south of London shortly before midnight. The Americans and others spent the night in hotels. A Gatwick airport official said 30 people due to fly on the plane were detained in Baghdad because they could not clear Iraqi exit formalities in time. She did not give the nationalities of the 30. Sky News television said the women and children on Friday's plane are believed to have been among the last who expressed a wish to leave behind their husbands and fathers in Kuwait. Ms. Hanson, who traveled with her son Zach, 5, said people in Kuwait had to wait in line five hours for some food items. She added: ``I saw with my own eyes a lot of looting and burning but I cannot say it was all by Iraqis.'' Speaking of Kuwaiti resistance fighters, she said: ``Resistance is very haphazard ... They haven't got enough people. They haven't got enough weapons.'' Iraq invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2 and later annexed the oil-rich emirate.

DOC.HEAD: ABC's ``World News Tonight'' to Appear in Spain
DOC.TEXT: ABC, which like CBS and NBC is seeking new overseas markets for news programs, says ``World News Tonight'' will start on Spanish television next week - in the mornings. It's the first sale of the show overseas, an ABC spokesman said Friday. In October, the Polish Television Network will start ``ABC News Presents,'' a one-hour weekly series of highlights from various ABC News programs. Dan Rather's ``CBS Evening News'' appears in France, Germany, Belgium, Italy, Japan and Hong Kong, a CBS spokeswoman said. NBC said Tom Brokaw's ``NBC Nightly News'' appears in the United Kingdom on Rupert Murdoch's Sky Television direct-to-home satellite service. ABC's ``World News Tonight,'' anchored by Peter Jennings, will appear on Spain's new national television network, Canal + TV. It will be sent via satellite each weeknight, taped there for broadcast at 8:30 a.m. and shown with Spanish-language subtitles, ABC said. The Spanish network is one of three new private televison channels that began operating this year, ABC said.

DOC.HEAD: Current Quotations
DOC.TEXT: ``When I rattle a saber, the man will know it. When an escalation is required from me, Saddam Hussein will know it.'' - President Bush, on the Iraqi president. --- ``I have not got any agenda on what should be done with Roe vs. Wade. I would listen to both sides of that case. I have not made up my mind.'' - U.S. Supreme Court nominee David Souter, giving his view in Senate confirmation hearings on the 1973 ruling that legalized abortion. --- ``If the choice is death or three days to live, I'll take three days.'' - New York Post Editor Jerry Nachman, after all but one of 11 unions agreed to concessions designed to prevent the newspaper from folding.

DOC.HEAD: Auto Strike Called in Canada Against Ford
DOC.TEXT: The Canadian Auto Workers union today began a strike against Ford Motor Co. of Canada after negotiators decided they could not meet a midnight deadline for settling the dispute over pay, benefits and job security. Parallel talks in the United States recessed early today, with the United Auto Workers telling its members not to strike against General Motors Corp. The negotiators in Detroit agreed to extend a similar deadline and more talks were set for later today. The Canadian talks were also to continue later today, spokesmen for Ford and the Canadian union said. ``We still have a very significant distance between the two positions,'' Don MacKenzie, Ford's chief negotiator, told reporters as discussions broke off Friday at a downtown Toronto hotel. The union president, Robert White, said the strike - the first against Ford of Canada since 1976 - would begin midnight Friday. Up to 12,800 workers are expected to walk off the job at nine plants and two offices in Ontario. The company has two plants in Oakville, five in Windsor, one in St. Thomas and one in Niagara Falls. However, the strike won't mean anything in terms of production until Monday because Canadian Ford plants do not operate weekends. After announcing the strike late Friday, White said the tough issues were job security, protection from inflation and time off. ``Ford is balking at putting enough economics on the table to get an agreement,'' he said. Both sides have refused to disclose details of their proposals and demands. It was not known how much of a raise the union was demanding over the current hourly base pay of about $15 (US). Earlier Friday, union and company officials had agreed communication was good and that work was progressing toward a new contract. But White had acknowledged it was impossible to get everything done by the midnight deadline. In Detroit, the United Auto Workers union and General Motors Corp. agreed to extend their national labor contract Friday, local union leaders said. ``They're going to negotiate through the weekend,'' said Charlie Gledhill, acting president of UAW 549 at GM's metal stamping plant in Mansfield, Ohio. In both countries, the unions target a single company in their talks in hopes of fashioning a pattern contract for workers at other automakers. White said earlier in the day that Ford had not made a new economic proposal since the first one put on the table a few days ago, which the union found unacceptable. He said the union had presented Ford with a counterproposal early Friday and that Ford officials went off to calculate the numbers. Ford Canada spokesman Jim Hartford confirmed that, but said he did not know how long it would take Ford to work out the cost of the union proposal. Neither side offered details of the proposals.

DOC.HEAD: Time For Healing, Say Descendants of Mormon Massacre
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Also in Saturday AMs report.
DOC.TEXT: Irene Lee Wait simply wanted to replace the ronze plaque that branded her pioneer great-grandfather the mastermind of the most shameful episode in Mormon history. ``I was so unhappy about it. It wasn't true,'' said the 75-year-old descendant of John D. Lee, the only man ever charged in the infamous Mountain Meadows Massacre. From her vexation has come not only a new marker, but a new memorial - a stone arch etched with the names of Arkansas migrants who were slaughtered by Mormon militiamen and Paiute Indians 133 years ago. Kindled too was a spirit of reconciliation among the victims' descendants and those of the Mormon pioneers who, as one historian said, were ``frenzied by mistaken zeal'' to protect their homes, families and church. ``I hope that what it will do is change the focus from what happened in the past to what can happen in the future,'' said Rex Lee, president of Mormon Church-owned Brigham Young University and John D. Lee's great-grandson. On Friday, about 60 of Lee's descendants - he had 19 wives - gathered at the old monument in southwestern Utah to replace the marker on a monument erected in 1932. The new memorial will be dedicated Saturday in Cedar City. ``Those who have gone to the other side - you can feel their presence - they have made their peace and so have we,'' Wait said in a benediction. The massacre on Sept. 11, 1857, occurred after President James Buchanan concluded that the fiercely independent Mormons, who had fled persecution in Ohio, Missouri and Illinois, were in rebellion. When he ordered an army to the Utah Territory, war fever ensued. Into the storm rode a California-bound company of Arkansas settlers led by Alexander Fancher and John T. Baker, along with a band of horsemen from Missouri who baited the unfriendly Mormons as they wended southward from Salt Lake City. In her definitive history, ``The Mountain Meadows Massacre,'' Juanita Brooks said Lee was not present when local Mormon militia leaders decided the Fancher train, camped in the meadows 35 miles southwest of Cedar City, must be ``done away with,'' with the Paiutes' help. They sent a runner to Mormon leader Brigham Young in Salt Lake City, but his orders to leave the settlers alone apparently arrived too late. Lee was present, however, at the massacre, which began with a trick. Lee and another man convinced the emigrants they would help them reach safety from Indian attack. Mormon militiamen then escorted the unarmed settlers single file from the safety of their wagons. On a signal, the militiamen shot the men and the Indians sprang from the brush to kill the women and older children. Of some 120 people, 17 young children survived and eventually were turned over to federal agents. Their cattle and supplies were sold and the Indians blamed for the slaughter. Over the years, whispers about the massacre grew to persistent demands for justice. Lee, his great-granddaughter says, became the scapegoat for his church. Excommunicated in 1870, he later was convicted and condemned to die. Lee was brought to Mountain Meadows in 1877 where, seated on the edge of his coffin, he denounced Young for abandoning him. Then he was executed by a firing squad. ``The fate of the emigrant train was decided by military leaders,'' Wait said. ``He didn't confess to anything. He gave his life to save the church.'' The old plaque named Lee as the confessed militia leader and misrepresented the number of dead. The new marker gives a straightforward account and casts no blame. Wait hopes the marker and memorial will ease the pain of the Fancher train descendants, one of whom she met at the old monument. ``One lady came up to me very angry, and said, `I want to know what happened to the stock and the money from the train,''' Wait recalled. ``I stopped and thought for a moment. I said, `I can understand why you're hostile. I would be, too, if my ancestors were killed.''' ``Her whole attitude changed,'' Wait said. ``And she said, `I'd be angry, too, because your ancestor was killed for something he didn't do.' ``We were friends then.''

DOC.HEAD: Post Headline Screams `AIN'T OVER YET!'
LaserPhoto NY7
With PM-Post-Chronology
DOC.TEXT: The New York Post screamed the good news. ``AIN'T OVER YET'' read the front page in what could have been the final edition of the nation's oldest continuously published daily. The Post got a temporary reprieve Friday night when all but one union agreed to $19 million in concessions after more than 12 hours of negotiations. The ultimate fate of the 189-year-old newspaper depends on a vote Monday by members of The Newspaper Guild. Its negotiating committee voted 7-3 against the settlement agreed to by bargainers for 10 other unions. ``If the choice is death or three days to live, I'll take three days,'' said Jerry Nachman, the newspaper's editor. Publisher Peter Kalikow is demanding massive concessions to make the tabloid break even. The newspaper is losing about $27 million a year. The more than 850 Post workers represented by the 10 unions must ratify the the agreement. The Guild represents 352 reporters and members of the advertising staff. A cheer went up in the newsroom when Kalikow announced in a televised news conference that the newspaper had at least another three days. Eric Breindel, editorial page editor, said Kalikow had written two columns for today's newspaper: one celebrating its survival, one lamenting its demise. On Friday, some Post reporters worked on ``Live Post'' issues while others worked on ``Dead Post'' issues. ``We've been through a wringer all day long for a few days and we're going to have to go through it again,'' said metropolitan editor John Cotter. Cotter said a prepared farewell edition that included reminiscences from past Post columnists was ``terrific ... but hopefully it'll never be read by the public.'' Money troubles are not new to the Post, founded in 1801 by Alexander Hamilton. In 1939, heiress Dorothy Schiff bought the Post and made it one of the nation's most liberal newspapers. But the Post also became known for making do with a small staff and old equipment. In 1976, Schiff sold the newspaper to Australian media baron Rupert Murdoch for $31 million. At the time, the newspaper was losing $500,000 annually. Under Murdoch, the Post went conservative editorially and began running sexy pictures, racy headlines - including the famous ``HEADLESS BODY IN TOPLESS BAR'' - and a steady diet of crime stories. Murdoch said the newspaper lost $150 million before he sold it in 1988 for $37 million to Kalikow, a real estate developer who also acquired the newspaper's valuable waterfront land in Lower Manhattan. The Post said today that Kalikow is demanding that the drivers union give up 100 of 263 jobs; the 70 printers cut their work week to four days and the 17 paper handlers give up five jobs.
