The Guild was asked to give up 43 jobs and to agree to a four-day work week for four days' pay. ``I feel optimistic that when the members see it they will approve it,'' said Kalikow. ``If they turn it down, the paper will stop publishing immediately.'' The Daily News, which also is losing money and is in the midst of a labor conflict, has demanded that any concessions the unions give the Post must be extended to the News under ``me-too'' contract clauses. The New York Times said it would seek union concessions related to the same economic conditions that have affected the Post and News and led to declines in ad revenues.

DOC.HEAD: Troops Advance Towards Jaffna Hospital
DOC.TEXT: Government troops today advanced slowly through booby-trapped buildings and mined streets toward the main hospital in the northern city of Jaffna, military officials said. Capturing the hospital offers the government both strategic and psychological advantages in trying to loosen the Tamil rebels' grip on the town. The abandoned hospital is in the center of Jaffna, about a mile from Jaffna Fort, which the army said it reached Thursday, breaking a three-month siege by Tamil separatist rebels. The government says 25 soldiers have been killed and at least 136 wounded since Thursday. It claims more than 100 Tamil Tigers have died. The Tigers' office in London has denied the siege was broken. The military officials did not say how far their men had advanced today, but a senior officer said they were under constant rebel fire and progress was very slow because of mines buried in the streets and booby traps hidden in buildings along the way. The overwhelmingly Tamil town 185 miles northeast of Colombo, the capital, has been a Tiger stronghold since the rebels embarked on their separatist war against Sri Lanka's Sinhalese majority in 1983. But this summer's new outbreak of civil war, coupled with the Tigers' strong-arm tactics of soliciting funds, is sapping enthusiasm for the guerrilla cause in the city of 60,000, recent visitors to the town reported. The Tigers also claimed their first successful attempt to down a government plane with a SAM-7 missile. The government conceded that a single-engine ground-attack plane crashed in Jaffna Lagoon on Thursday. But it said the pilot ditched the Italian-made Marchetti aircraft when he could not pull out of a dive after attacking a Tiger gun position. The pilot was reported missing. The military officials, who spoke on condition of anonymity, accused the Tigers of killing eight unarmed Moslem civilians in eastern Sri Lanka Thursday night and Friday. Four Tiger guerrillas were killed in clashes with government troops in the region, the officials said. The Tigers have been fighting for political autonomy or independence for the Tamil minority, claiming to have been victimized by Sinhalese discrimination in jobs, education and use of the Sinhala language. The Sinhalese, who comprise 75 percent of Sri Lanka's population of 16 million, control the government and the military. Tamils, who account for 18 percent of the people, live mostly in the north and east of the Indian Ocean island. Moslems make up 7 percent of the total population; most of them live in the east. At least 14,000 people have been killed since the war erupted in 1983 in this once-idyllic nation of palm-fringed beaches, precious gems and tropical plantations.

DOC.HEAD: Body Samples Taken From Second Suspect
DOC.TEXT: Investigators took ``body samples'' from a suspect in the slayings of five college students and considered searching an area frequented by another suspect in the case. Searchers waded through alligator-infested swamps and scoured dense woods Friday looking for body parts and other evidence near three complexes where the bodies were found nearly three weeks ago. Authorities said they conducted the search because Edward Lewis Humphrey, 18, frequented wooded areas. Rusty knives, metal, paper products and clothing were among items found in the search. Police Lt. Sadie Darnell said the objects must be analyzed to determine if they are connected with the slaying of four women and one man. Two of the women were mutilated and another was decapitated. Polk County authorities, meanwhile, announced that the Florida Department of Law Enforcement had taken ``body samples'' from Stephen Bates, 30, a burglary suspect jailed in Bartow since Aug. 29. Investigators already have taken blood and hair samples from Humphrey at the Brevard County Jail, where he has been held in the Aug. 30 beating of his grandmother. Humphrey also faces warrants in an Aug. 25 assault on two male University of Florida students and an October 1988 armed burglary and attempted rape in Indian River County. Bates and Humphrey are the two suspects publicly identified by police. Six other people also are considered suspects. Darnell said authorities may search Sebastian Inlet State Park. The area, searched shortly after Humphrey's arrest. Humphrey, a University of Florida freshman, frequented the area. ``We have a lot of information on Mr. Humphrey, but we have not connected him to these murders,'' Ms. Darnell said.

DOC.HEAD: Fujimori Announces Drug Agreement Deadline Extended by Bush
DOC.TEXT: President Alberto Fujimori says President Bush extended the deadline for signing an agreement on U.S. anti-drug aid, which Fujimori has criticized for lacking funding to help coca farmers switch to other crops. Fujimori on Wednesday appeared to reject the $35.9 million in economic aid, saying that since the package ``is destined only for the fight against drug trafficking, we are not going to sign this agreement.'' Fujimori had said any agreement must include aid to wean farmers away from growing coca leaves, the main ingredient for cocaine, and persuade them to cultivate other cash crops. Better roads into cities have been suggested as one solution. However, the Peruvian president told the state news agency Andina that Bush on Friday extended a recently expired deadline for agreement. Fujimori said he was confident the two nations would negotiate an agreement by the end of the month. Fujimori met Friday with U.S. Ambassador Anthony Quaynton, who delivered the message from Bush. The aid proposal includes $20 million to provide soldiers with arms and equipment and to build a training camp in the coca-rich Upper Huallaga Valley. The northern valley, 250 miles northeast of Lima, is the world's largest supplier of coca leaf, the raw material for cocaine. The army wants the agreement to focus on aid for fighting the Maoist Shining Path rebels, according to the local news magazine Caretas. The magazine said the United States wants the wording of the agreement to state the aid is solely to fight drug trafficking. Opposition politicians have criticized the proposal, fearing it could lead to direct U.S. involvement in a 10-year-old guerrilla war that has claimed nearly 20,000 lives. The police, which direct Peruvian anti-drug efforts, already operate with the U.S. Drug Enforcement Administration an anti-drug helicopter base in the Huallaga Valley. Guerrillas attacked the base in April, battling U.S. pilots.

DOC.HEAD: Playmates Reveal Friend's Death After Extensive Search
DOC.TEXT: Four playmates of a 10-year-old boy went for weeks without revealing their friend had not vanished but had plummeted 120 feet to his death from atop a deserted grain silo, authorities say. The boys told their story Thursday after a nationwide, five-month search failed to turn up Ricky Rodriguez. Ricky fell to his death in April while bouncing with his friends on a conveyor belt stretched across the abandoned silo, the boys told authorities. Ricky's body was discovered later Thursday right where one of the friends said it would be, in the silo that once stored grain for a deserted Falstaff Brewing Corp. plant, police said. ``They were scared. They're just little boys and they thought they were going to get into trouble,'' said police Detective Eileen Guest, a youth officer. Police had scoured Ricky's neighborhood, using helicopters and scba divers to search for any trace. A picture of Ricky recently was sent to millions of homes as part of a campaign to find missing children. ``We searched everywhere we could think of for this boy,'' police Sgt. Rovert Jones said Friday. Police separately interviewed each of Ricky's four playmates, all of them about 10 years old, and were convinced the boy's death was an accident, Detective William Marley said. Ricky, a good student with caring parents, had stopped home briefly the afternoon of April 26 to ask his father what time dinner was. It was the last trace. One of Ricky's friends told police that keeping the secret made the summer terrifying. ``He said he couldn't sleep, that he had been having nightmares,'' Guest said. The mystery unraveled when a sister of one of the playmates overheard a conversation in which some of the youngsters said Ricky had fallen. She told her mother, who notified police. ``Well, everybody can stop looking,'' said Steve Rodriguez, Ricky's father. ``I thought he was dead the night he disappeared. It just didn't fit his pattern. But ... I was hoping.''

DOC.HEAD: First Ferry Service Launched between China, South Korea
DOC.TEXT: South Korea launched regular ferry service with China today for the first time since the Korean peninsula was divided in 1945. A 4,300-ton ferryboat carrying 130 people left the western port city of Inchon for Weihai on China's Shandong peninsula, the South Korean news agency Yonhap reported. The boat will leave Inchon twice a week, Yonhap said. It will fly a Panamanian flag because the two countries have no diplomatic relations. South Korea has strengthened economic and non-political ties with China, a close ally of Communist North Korea. In recent months it has also increased ties with the Soviet Union and most of the formerly Communist nations in Eastern Europe. China intervened on North Korea's side in the 1950-53 war between the Koreas. The two Koreas have never signed a peace treaty, and hundreds of thousands of troops guard their borders.

DOC.HEAD: Dirty Dancing? Saudis Bag Morale-Boosting Show
With PM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The U.S. military says it has canceled a planned morale-boosting variety show for American troops after the Saudi government objected to a burlesque dance routine. ``They objected in general, but it was pretty clear that it was the women that set them off,'' said a military source who spoke on condition of anonymity. The Saudis complained to U.S. military officials after monitoring the show on CBS, which broadcast a brief segment showing four women dancers. Lt. Col. John Olsen, a U.S. military spokesman, said the military decided it would not send audiences to the shows because of the Saudi objections. ``(It) caused some discomfort on the part of the Saudi government and we regret that,'' Olsen said. The episode is the latest in a series of incidents that have caused increasing cultural strains between the Americans and their Saudi hosts. Earlier in the week, the Saudi government complained to U.S. commanders about American soldiers venturing into Saudi towns carrying their weapons. Saudi officials have also been relaying complaints about women in the military driving on Saudi roads. Women are not allowed to drive here. The 90-minute show was being staged by a group of Americans, Britons and other Westerners who wanted to show their appreciation to the thousands of Americans deployed in Operation Desert Shield. At opening night Wednesday, 400 members of the 82nd Airborne were repeatedly brought to their feet by the performers and many said afterward that the show was a break from the heat, boredom and isolation of the desert. A second show was staged Wednesday night and two more on Thursday. But two planned for Friday night were effectively canceled when military officials, responding to the Saudi complaint, said they would not allow troops to attend. The troupe had planned to put on six shows next week and hoped to continue the show for several weeks to allow troops to be rotated in for entertainment while awaiting the arrival of entertainers being brought in by the USO. ``We were just trying to give the guys a break,'' one of the organizers of the show said, insisting on anonymity because of fears she would be penalized for participating. ``We were worried what might happen if the Saudis found out.'' From the outset, Saudi and American officials have predicted some cultural clashes as the 100,000-plus American troops settled in and began to interract with Saudis. After weeks of relatively few incidents the last week has become tense, with several U.S. commanders complaining privately the Saudis appear unwilling to bend their traditions. Saudi offials in turn have complained the Americans were unnecessarily engaging in activities that offended local customs. During a Thursday visit by Gen. Colin Powell, chairman of the Joint Chiefs of Staff, a Saudi official walked up to a senior American officer and argued furiously that servicewomen be sent home or at least prohibited from driving. The officer, Gen. Gus Pagonis, who is in charge of the logistics and supply efforts for the U.S. deployment, could hardly get a word in as the Saudi official, who refused to identify himself afterward, insisted driving by women be halted. ``I'm trying to hold back but I must perform my mission,'' Pagonis told the official. ``They must perform the mission.'' Saudi women appear in public draped in clothing that covers their faces, arms and legs. Western women also are advised cover their calves and arms when in public.

DOC.HEAD: Storms Sweep Arizona, Tennessee
DOC.TEXT: Thunderstorms swept through parts of Arizona and Tennessee today after heavy rain and winds pelted parts of the Midwest. The forecast called for scattered storms in the Southwest, the Pacific Northwest and along the Gulf Coast. Showers were expected over the upper Midwest and along the East Coast. Heavy rain Friday fell in Michigan, Indiana and Ohio. A three-week heat wave in Nebraska ended. Tornadoes touched down near Fort Wayne, Ind., Dayton, Ohio, and in southern Michigan, but there were no reports of injuries. Thunderstorm winds toppled trees, tore at roofs and broke windows in Michigan. At least two homes were destroyed in Ohio and damage also was done in Indiana. Hail hit Tuscola, Mich., and heavy rain from strong storms caused flooding of streets, small streams and low lying areas around Three Rivers, Mich. Record temperatures were recorded in parts of Utah, Florida, Colorado and Idaho, but the sizzling heat that had gripped Nebraska since Aug. 23 dropped back into the seasonable 80's. The high temperature for the nation Friday was 109 degrees at Bullhead City, Ariz. Hurricane Isidore moved northeast at 9 mph toward North Atlantic shipping lanes. On Friday evening, its center was 700 miles south southeast of Cape Race, Newfoundland, meteorologists said. DOC.HEAD: URGENT
France Sending 4,000 Troops To Gulf, Expels Iraqi Attaches
DOC.TEXT: President Francois Mitterrand today announced France will send 4,000 more soldiers to the Persian Gulf and he expelled Iraqi military attaches, a day after an Iraqi raid on the French diplomatic compound in Kuwait. Mitterrand said other Iraqi diplomats will be confined to Paris in response to what he called Iraqi aggression against the French Embassy in Kuwait. He also urged that the embargo against Iraq be extended to air shipments. ``We will do what must be done,'' the French president said at a press conference following an emergency meeting this morning of his inner Cabinet. ``But we won't be taking hostages,'' he said. Iraqi troops raided the diplomatic compounds of France, Canada and Belgium in Kuwait on Friday, briefly detaining five Western consuls - including an American - and capturing four French citizens. One of the four, France's military attache, was freed after several hours. Mitterrand said in a press conference today that the remaining three had joined other hostages held by Iraqi forces. The 4,000 troops to be sent to the gulf will include helicopter and antitank units, Mitterrand said. He did not elaborate on just where they would be stationed. France already has sent 180 paratroopers to the United Arab Emirates and has nine warships in the region or enroute. The aircraft carrier Clemenceau is among those that have arrived. The United States has deployed about 150,000 military personnel in the Saudi Arabian desert south of Kuwait and on dozens of warships in the region, where troops and ships of other nations also have been sent. France will demand an emergency meeting of the U.N. Security Council to examine holes in the United Nations embargo of Iraq and occupied Kuwait, Mitterrand said. The embargo has been enforced by a massive buildup of naval forces in the Persian Gulf. Mitterrand said France would continue to rely on the embargo to dislodge Iraqi troops from Kuwait. To make the embargo more effective, it must be extended to air traffic to and from Iraq and occupied Kuwait, Mitterrand said. In addition to throwing out the military attaches, France will also expel 26 Iraqi civilian and military personnel who were taking training courses here when Iraq invaded Kuwait Aug. 2. There courses were immediately suspended. The personnel have been living under virtual house arrest in a handful of cities.

DOC.TEXT: American troops in the Middle East will soon be able to send home a moving picture from the front. More than $2 million of video equipment is being donated and shipped overseas so military men and women will be able to tape personal messages. The ``Better Than a Letter'' program was initiated by Montgomery Ward & Co., with help from its vendors and World USO, a non-profit organization serving more than 5 million American military families worldwide. The donation includes about 450 video cameras, 350 televisions, 370 video cassette recorders, 250,000 video tapes and video mailing materials. Families without a VCR can arrange a private viewing at a local Montgomery Ward store.

DOC.HEAD: Stoppard's Debut Film Unexpectedly Awarded Golden Lion
DOC.NOTE: Eds: New throughout to UPDATE with Stoppard film winning top prize. No pickup
DOC.HEAD: By DENNIS REDMONT
DOC.TEXT: English playwright Tom Stoppard's debut movie, ``Rosencrantz and Guildenstern Are Dead,'' captured the top prize today at the Venice Film Festival. The film, starring Richard Dreyfuss, reinterprets Shakespeare's ``Hamlet'' from the point of view of the prince's two old school chums, Rosencrantz and Guildenstern, who become unwittingly involved in, and ultimately victims of, the power play between Hamlet and his stepfather. A screen treatment of Stoppard's 1966 hit tragi-comic play by the same name, the film was not generally expected to take the Golden Lion prize despite the favorable reviews it received after its screening. The favorite had been Martin Scorcese's ``Goodfellas,'' which instead won the second place Silver Lion Award for direction. The film provides a vividly realistic portrait of life in the American underworld, with Oscar-winning actor Robert De Niro in a supporting role. The award for Best Actress went to Gloria Munchmeyer for her starring role in Chilean director Silvio Caiozzi's film ``La Luna En El Espejo'' (The Moon in the Mirror). The Best Actor award went to Oleg Borisov, protagonist of ``Edinstvenijat Svidetel,'' (The Only Witness) by Bulgarian director Michail Pandurski. New Zealand director Jane Campion's entry, ``An Angel at My Table,'' won the jury's ``special grand prize,'' and received a long standing ovation from an appreciative crowd at the awards ceremony. A nine-person jury headed by American author Gore Vidal judged the 21 films from 18 countries running in the competition at this year's 47th edition of the festival. Meanwhile, some critics at the festival have blasted ``Henry and June,'' a controversial American movie about Henry Miller that has earned an ``X'' rating for its erotic scenes. But many critics at the festival, which ends today, also have signed a petition urging the repeal of the ``X'' rating on grounds that it limits artistic freedom. Set in the literary scene in Paris in the 1930s, the film is based on sections of the diaries of Anais Nin and the autobiographical novels of Miller, an American expatriate. Both Miller and Nin were entranced with the young June Smith. ``It was just a bad film,'' commented Irene Bignardi, critic of Rome's La Repubblica, after the world premiere Friday. ``But even Americans who are rather infantile would not be shocked by it.'' ``It's enough to put you off sex,'' quipped The Guardian's critic, Derek Malcolm. The film stars Swedish-American Uma Thurman, whose first break came as a seduced adolescent in Stephen Frears' ``Dangerous Liaisons.'' It was directed by Philip Kaufman, whose other movies include ``The Unbearable Lightness of Being'' and ``The Right Stuff.'' Produced by Universal Pictures, the film was rated ``X'' last month by the U.S. Motion Picture Association's rating board, meaning no one under 17 can be admitted for viewing. Universal has vowed to appeal the rating in an attempt to challenge the 22-year-old rating system.

DOC.HEAD: Man Fills Basement With Thousands of Toy Trucks
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 5th graf, `The 6-inch-long...', to delete extraneous word `dollars'.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto CX3
DOC.TEXT: Jim Lord's basement is chock-full of tractor-trailers, moving vans, dump trucks and gasoline tankers. There's so many of them, the traffic jam has spread to his barn. At last count, the retired pipefitter had 2,700 toy trucks, but not just any trucks. The ones Lord collects are reproductions of big-name company haulers that can't be found in stores. Lord, 75, is one of about 4,000 enthusiasts to search out the handcrafted gems made by Winross Co. for such companies as Exxon Corp., the Adolph Coors Co. and Campbell Soup Co. ``You can't get them in stores, so we have to find out about them via the grapevine,'' he said recently. ``It's really the challenge of getting them that makes them so sought-after.'' The 6-inch-long trucks are sold to companies by Winross, a family-owned business in Rochester, N.Y., for about $30 each. They look like the companies' real trucks, logos included, and are used as promotional giveaways. When Winross makes too many of one model, it sells off the overflow to enthusiasts. Lord also finds rare models at toy shows or buys them from other collectors. Winross began making the silk-screened, metal toy trucks about 30 years ago. They were initially sold retail, but then the company began filling only bulk orders for companies that wanted their logos advertised. ``We were amazed that people got so interested in collecting them,'' said Phyllis Austin, co-owner of Winross. ``I still don't understand it. I always thought of collectibles as being things that were antique. These become collectible as soon as we make them,'' she said Thursday. Lord says he's long been a collector of items ranging from stamps to Matchbox toy cars. He became interested in Winross trucks in the mid-1970s. Now, shelves of the toy vehicles line his basement, leaving room for only a washer and a dryer. More of them are beginning to fill his barn. Winross does not put out a complete list of all models it makes, so Lord does the job himself. In 1977, he began compiling and publishing a list of Winross trucks he knew existed. Subscribers pay $2 a year for his monthly newsletter. Lord also sells a photo catalog of the latest truck models for $70 to $80. He resells duplicate models for up to $400, using the profit to buy the nearly 250 new trucks he estimates Winross puts out every year. Lord estimates his collection is worth about $150,000. Lord's wife, who recently died, never shared his enthusiasm for model trucks. ``My wife put up with me,'' he says. ``The rule was no toys upstairs, but she never minded me having them.''

DOC.HEAD: Demos Blame Bush On Oil Dependence
DOC.NOTE: EDS: TOPS with 3 grafs to UPDATE with Brown speech; EDITS to remove 2nd full reference to Brown and PICKS UP 7th graf pvs bgng, `At a record'
DOC.TEXT: Democratic Party Chairman Ronald H. Brown said today his party stands firmly behind President Bush's Persian Gulf policy. ``Saddam Hussein will get no mixed signals from America or from this party,'' he said. In a speech to a meeting of the Democratic National Committee, Brown coupled his support for the U.S. commitment in the Middle East with a slashing attack on Republican domestic policy. ``We'll stand up to Saddam Hussein, but we won't stand by as the new Republican recession wreaks havoc on our economy,'' he said. Democratic Party leaders, meeting today uptown from the White House, are formally endorsing Bush's decision to send troops to block Iraq's aggression in the Middle East. But that backing for the Republican president doesn't extend to his domestic policy, which the Democrats say characterize a ``decade of Republican greed and debt.'' On the agenda for the meeting of the Democratic National Committee were resolutions denouncing ``the failure of three successive Republican administrations to develop a national energy policy'' and blaming the GOP for the savings and loan crisis. The resolution demanded that the president ``explain why high-ranking Bush administration officials have made concerted efforts to suppress new conservation measures developed to respond to the Iraqi oil crisis.'' Brown praised the party regulars for completing what he called ``housekeeping'' matters related to the 1992 nominating convention. At a record early date, the Democrats have selected their convention city - New York - and now are ready to adopt the convention call, which includes the formula for allocating delegates. The number of delegates allocated to individual states won't be determined until after the final 1990 Census figures define changes in House seats and the November elections change the political makeup of the nation's governorships. What is known is that the 1992 convention, like the 1988, will have more than 4,000 delegates. Each Democratic convention is always a little larger than the one before and the 1992 meeting will have at least 80 more unpledged delegates. That allocation was inserted into the call to please state party leaders who wanted additional slots for state and party officials. A highlight of the meeting Friday of the party's executive committee was the appearance of Sen. Sam Nunn, D-Ga., a figure never before seen at a national committee meeting. Five years ago, Nunn was a founder of the Democratic Leadership Council which was created as a conservative counterweight to the national party. Nunn's denied his appearance before the executive committee was a signal of his interest in running for president in 1992. ``I have no inclinations or plans to run for president,'' Nunn told reporters who crowded around him as he left the party meeting. But the senator continues to stir presidential speculation with such actions as his resignation from an all-male golf club and his recent declaration of support for abortion rights after decades of being in the opposition camp. Nunn said his interest in party politics began with formation of the DLC which he described as an effort to ``get the Democratic Party back in the mainstream.'' Asked if he believed the people he'd just spoken to were now in the mainstream, Nunn replied, ``Well, I don't know everybody here.'' Nunn said he didn't believe the tendency of Americans to rally around the president in a time of crisis would hurt Democratic candidates in the fall. ``I don't think it's a partisan issue,'' he said. ``I don't think the public's going to be voting in November based on the Middle East.'' The executive committee approved without dissent a resolution that began by saying: ``Today, our nation stands united in support of America's mission in the Middle East, united in opposition to Iraq's aggression. We, the Democratic Party of the United States, do here formally express our support for our armed forces and the Persian Gulf policy of our commander in chief.'' But the next paragraph called on the nation to ``abandon Republican economic policies.'' The party voiced agreement with Bush's call for spending reductions but added, ``We insist that those reductions must not discriminate against those who benefited least from a decade of Republican greed and debt.'' It said, ``The S&L crisis is the certain result of do-nothing Republican public philosophy, hear-nothing Republican regulatory policy, and see-nothing Republican administration of justice.''

DOC.HEAD: Iraqi Official Says Man Was Released Because of Mom's Letter
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Flight due at Baltimore late afternoon EDT; should stand for PMs.
DOC.HEAD: With PM-Gulf-Evacuees
DOC.TEXT: Iraqi President Saddam Hussein ordered the release of a 25-year-old Connecticut man in Baghdad after receiving a written plea from his mother, a spokesman at the Iraqi Embassy in Washington said. Thomas Hart Benton Ewald, 25, was one of about 250 Americans allowed to leave Baghdad on a U.S.-chartered flight that arrived in London late Friday, U.S. officials confirmed. Saddam Hussein ``gave the order to allow him to go free and to return to his nation,'' said Iraqi spokesman Riyadh Jawad. ``His excellency, he wants to give examples to prove that our behavior is not aggressive to our guests.'' ``We did not treat them as hostages as in Lebanon. . . . We treat them as guests in our country,'' he said. Jawad said Mary Ewald's plea for her son's release was the only one the Iraqi embassy has received and that Saddam is open to other humanitarian pleas. Ewald was one of only a few men on the plane carrying almost 400 passengers. Iraq has been holding most foreign men hostage, while releasing women and children. Ewald, of Greenwich, was scheduled to arrive at Baltimore-Washington International Airport later today after an overnight stop in London, said U.S. Chief of Protocol Joseph Verner Reed. Ewald began work this summer with the Al-Ahli Bank of Kuwait, arriving in Kuwait City two days before the Aug. 2 Iraqi invasion, Mrs. Ewald said. Jawad said he believed Ewald had been moved from Kuwait to Iraq after the invasion. He was allowed to enter the U.S. Embassy compound in Baghdad on Thursday. Jawad said the Iraqi Embassy received Mary Ewald's letter about one week ago and forwarded it to Baghdad. ``After two, three days, (Saddam) ordered to allow (Ewald) to return to his nation,'' said Jawad. Mrs. Ewald declined to release a copy of the letter. Ewald called his parents from London on Friday and told them that people still being held hostage wished him well, said his father, William Ewald. ``When the other hostages learned he was being released they said `Tell your mom we're proud of her,' '' the elder Ewald said. ``We are grateful for him having responded this way with Tom,'' the elder Ewald said. ``It was a humanitarian appeal and response.'' ``I also hope the other hostages get out,'' said Mrs. Ewald. ``Their parents and families are still going through this.'' About 1,350 Americans remain in Kuwait and 200 in Iraq, with about 75 being held as so-called human shields, according to the State Department.

DOC.HEAD: Bomb Placed in Metal Sculpture Damages Federal Building
DOC.TEXT: A bomb exploded inside a metal sculpture outside the federal building early today, causing some damage to the building but no injuries, police said. The explosion, which may have been a prank, was felt blocks away, said police Lt. Randy Nisleit. ``Some people in the area saw four `military-looking type' people running from the area and laughing, so it was probably just a prank of some kind. But we're checking the area out just in case,'' Nisleit said. He said the device appeared to be a pipe bomb attached to a freon gas cannister to give it more explosive force. ``There's a large piece of modern art sculpture in front of the building, and they apparently threw some kind of charge down one of the tubes,'' Nisleit said. He said the 12:45 a.m. explosion shattered a large window in the building and damaged a guardrail, but did little damage to the sculpture. ``A few people called who live blocks away to say the blast shook the ground, so (the explosion) must have been substantial,'' Nisleit said. Agents from the FBI, the federal Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco and Firearms, and the Fire Department's Metro Arson Strike Team were also investigating.

DOC.HEAD: General Motors, Union Extend Contract; Canadian Ford Workers Strike
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 8 grafs to UPDATE with talks resuming in Detroit, Toronto. Picks up 8th graf pvs, `In the...'.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto DT5
DOC.TEXT: The United Auto Workers union and General Motors Corp. resumed contract talks today after extending the current pact for more negotiations affecting about 300,000 workers nationwide. The union appealed to workers to stay on the job while bargaining continued today. ``Until you are notified otherwise ... I urge you to demonstrate solidarity and discipline and report to work as scheduled,'' UAW Vice President Stephen Yokich said on a telephone recording for UAW members. Negotiators had faced a midnight deadline, but the deadline was extended after hours of talking Friday. The union and the world's largest automaker agreed to extend the current, three-year contract on a day-to-day basis. Talks resumed at 8 a.m. today after breaking for the night at 12:40 a.m. The only GM assembly plant scheduled for operation today in the United States was the Corvette factory in Bowling Green, Ky. Meanwhile in Canada, the Canadian Auto Workers union struck Ford Motor Co. when that union's contract with the No. 2 U.S. automaker's Canadian subsidiary expired at midnight Friday. About 12,800 unionized Ford workers were on strike early today. None of Ford's Canadian plants was scheduled to operate during the weekend. Talks resumed this morning in Toronto. In the United States, the GM workers were among more than 450,000 active workers employed by GM, Ford Motor Co. and Chrysler Corp. whose UAW contracts technically expired at midnight Friday. The union froze negotiations at Ford and Chrysler pending the outcome of the GM talks. The UAW plans to use an agreement ratified by GM workers as a pattern for contracts with Ford and Chrysler. When the GM-UAW contract extension was implemented, there was no official word from GM or the union about what issues remained unresolved. Bargaining Friday included job security, health care, wages and pensions. Union members nationwide have been kept pretty much in the dark about the talks going on at GM headquarters in Detroit. That has caused some problems. Gary Sorrell, president of UAW Local 977 at GM's Marion, Ohio, stamping plant said he and other leaders were feeling some heat from members. The extension, he said, ``put us in a situation where the members feel we're keeping something from them, and we're not.'' Speculation about the extension rose during the final days of the 1987 GM-UAW national agreement. Friday night, the union was faced with three choices: sign a tentative agreement, extend the existing contract or strike. ``I think with the economy today and with the market share we have today, we couldn't afford to strike,'' said Paul Mitchell, financial secretary of UAW Local 5960 at GM's Lake Orion car assembly plant near Pontiac, Mich. During the 1980s, the Big Three's collective market share dropped about 6 percentage points to about 68 percent last year. During the same time, the Japanese companies' share rose by about the same amount to more than 25 percent. That forced GM, Ford and Chrysler to shrink their operations and their work forces. In response, the UAW's primary emphasis has shifted to job security from wage increases. The last time the UAW struck GM was in 1984. That walkout, which affected about two dozen factories, lasted a week.

DOC.HEAD: Stoppard's Debut Film Awarded Golden Lion
DOC.TEXT: English playwright Tom Stoppard's debut movie ``Rosencrantz and Guildenstern Are Dead'' received the top prize Saturday at the 47th Venice Film Festival amid boos and whistles from some of the media. The film, starring actor Richard Dreyfuss, reinterprets Shakespeare's ``Hamlet'' from the point of view of the prince's two old school chums, Rosencrantz and Guildenstern, who become unwittingly involved in the power play between Hamlet and his stepfather. Stoppard's 1966 play by the same name was a hit, but the film was not predicted to take the Golden Lion prize despite favorable reviews. The favorite, Martin Scorsese's ``Goodfellas,'' won the second-place Silver Lion Award for direction. The film depicts life in the American underworld, with Oscar-winning actor Robert De Niro in a supporting role. The award for Best Actress went to Gloria Munchmeyer for her starring role in Chilean director Silvio Caiozzi's film ``The Moon in the Mirror.'' The Best Actor award went to Oleg Borisov, protagonist of ``The Only Witness'' by Bulgarian director Michail Pandurski. New Zealand director Jane Campion's ``An Angel at My Table'' won the jury's ``special grand prize'' and received a long standing ovation. A nine-person jury, headed by American author Gore Vidal, judged 21 films from 18 countries.

DOC.HEAD: Primary Nears In Search For Dukakis Successor
DOC.TEXT: Democrat John Silber is trying to recover from his latest political blunder while Republican William Weld is enjoying a last-minute surge as primary election day approaches in the chaotic Massachusetts governor's race. Weld is running Tuesday against State House Minority Leader Steven Pierce, with Republicans in the best position in two decades to capture the governorship they last won in 1970. During the tenure of Michael Dukakis, the Massachusetts Miracle of economic growth has become an economic debacle. The state that once had the lowest unemployment rate among major industrial states now is tied for second highest at 6.7 percent. After his unsuccessful bid for the presidency, Dukakis returned to a state heading for serious economic trouble and announced he wouldn't seek re-election. The Legislature passed the largest tax increase in the state's history this year, $1.2 billion, but the current budget already is spiraling into deficit. ``I think either Republican would be highly competitive,'' said Ralph Whitehead, a University of Massachusetts journalism professor and political analyst. ``This is going to be a tightly contested election.'' Weld, who is independently wealthy, has pumped more than $1 million of his own money into the campaign. Pierce had maintained a comfortable lead in polls, but Weld has surged within striking distance. Weld, a former federal prosecutor, credited his campaign's resurrection to his summer-long whistle-stops and to his performance in two televised debates where he was considered more aggressive than Pierce. The two candidates and political analysts predict dwindling interest in the Democratic contest may attract a record number of the state's 1.35 million independents to the GOP primary. Weld and Pierce support a tax rollback initiative on the November ballot. Pierce is personally opposed to abortion, while Weld favors abortion rights. On the Democratic side, Silber faces the front-running former state attorney general, Francis Bellotti, who benefited from Lt. Gov. Evelyn Murphy's decision earlier this month to drop out of the race. Silber's campaign has been marked by controversies over harsh-sounding statements - they became known as ``Silber shockers'' - concerning immigrants, welfare mothers and health care for the elderly. The latest flap came during a televised debate, with Silber saying he saw no point going to an inner city area to talk to a ``a group of drug addicts'' about crime. Later, Silber said he did not mean to imply that all residents of the predominantly minority area were on drugs. Bellotti's performance in the debate was lackluster and even he admitted that his stumbling closing statement was ``terrible, terrible.'' Independent tracking polls conducted for The Boston Globe and WBZ-TV showed Bellotti with a commanding lead after the Tuesday debate, but Silber's campaign said its polling showed a tighter race. Murphy, who was tied in voters' minds with Dukakis, trailed badly in public opinion polls and fund raising when she dropped out. Her decision to leave the race came after she attempted to impose a different budget-cutting plan than Dukakis while the governor was on a European trade mission. Whitehead said Silber's campaign was shot when Murphy left the race and the Democratic political establishment united behind Bellotti. ``Silber never had a chance in a two-person field,'' Whitehead said. One of Silber's leading supporters, state Senate President William Bulger, remained confident. ``I tell you what the `Silber shocker's' going to be next Tuesday: Silber wins,'' he said while making a campaign swing through western Massachusetts. In the U.S. Senate race, incumbent Democrat John F. Kerry is unopposed in Tuesday's primary. Two Republican businessmen, James Rappaport and Dan Daly, are competing for the GOP nomination, with Rappaport considered the favorite. The only serious congressional primary involving an incumbent is in the district of Democrat Richard Neal of Springfield, a former mayor being challenged by another former mayor, Theodore DiMauro. Democratic Rep. Barney Frank, reprimanded by the House for his relationship with a male prostitute, is unopposed in the primary but will face some Republican opposition in the general election. Elections were scheduled in two other states Tuesday. In Oklahoma, there will be run-off elections to choose a Democrat and Republican nominee for governor. In Washington, where there is no Senate or governor's race, voters were selecting party nominees for the U.S. House.

DOC.HEAD: Auschwitz Railway Wagon Presented to Israeli Institute
DOC.TEXT: A freight car once used to transport Nazi prisoners to the Auschwitz concentration camp was presented by Polish railway workers to Israel's Holocaust museum. Aleksander Janiszewski, director general of the Polish State Railways, presented the ``death wagon'' to the Yad Vashem Holocaust memorial during a ceremony at a Warsaw locomotive shed on Friday. Zvi Rav-Ner, the Israeli charge d'affaires in Warsaw, accepted the gift on behalf of the Jerusalem-based memorial organization. ``We will never forget all those Poles who saved Jews from destruction, often paying the highest price of their own life for this,'' said the Israeli diplomat. The wagon was recently found at a railway repair shop in southern Poland and renovated in World War II style. The Nazis transported millions of people, mostly Jews, by freight trains to death and concentration camps around Europe during the war. An estimated 6 million Jews died in the Holocaust.

DOC.HEAD: New S&L Fraud Squads: Potent Enforcers or Bureaucratic Showpiece?
LaserPhoto
DOC.TEXT: On a hot, overcast day last June, as a band played military music at the Justice Department, President Bush announced the formation of elite platoons that would be dispatched to the front lines in his administration's war on savings and loan fraud. The new ``rapid response teams,'' Bush said, would be ``teams of razor-sharp prosecutors and auditors ... striking city by city, teams that will jump right into the paper chase, teams that will hit the trail while that trail is still hot.'' The paper trail of S&L fraud may have cooled a bit since June, but so far, at least, the new teams apparently haven't responded rapidly - or at all. ``There is just no business for these people right now,'' Justice Department spokesman Doug Tillett said this past week. ``They really haven't done anything at this point.'' Tillett said the new teams of hundreds of lawyers and accountants coordinated by the department are intended to be a ``resource pool'' that can be tapped by S&L enforcers already in the field. So far, he said, the U.S. attorneys, FBI agents and support staff already investigating S&L fraud in locations around the country haven't needed to call on the specialized expertise of the new squads. ``I find it very hard to believe that there is no work for the rapid response teams,'' said Rep. Charles E. Schumer, D-N.Y., a member of House Banking Committee, which is investigating the savings and loan crisis. ``The American public assumed that fast action was forthcoming'' after the teams were appointed, he said. ``I'm sure they would be shocked to learn that S&L fraud has dissipated so greatly that urgency may no longer be needed. ``There are a great deal of allegations to be investigated,'' Schumer said. ``Every resource possible should be used to its fullest.'' More than 165 people have been convicted in S&L cases since October 1988, but the Justice Department has a backlog of 21,000 cases. James G. Richmond, the Justice Department official appointed to direct the teams, said this summer that the fraud squads would be available whenever local investigators needed their special expertise. But so far, Tillett said, local prosecutors are ``dealing with things they've seen before.'' ``They haven't been thrown any curve balls at this point,'' he said. In the Dallas area, for example, where a special task force has been prosecuting some of the largest and most scandalous S&L fraud cases for some time, the locals have had only an ``educational'' contact with the new teams. The help from Washington hasn't been needed ``because of the large presence we already have,'' said Marvin Collins, the U.S. attorney for northern Texas in Fort Worth. Bush's announcement of his new initiative on June 22 followed weeks of heated criticism by Democrats that the administration was not vigorously prosecuting S&L fraud. Abuse by some thrift operators was partly responsible for the collapse of hundreds of institutions in recent years. It will cost U.S. taxpayers an estimated $500 billion to pay for the bailout of the federally insured S&Ls. The scandal had reached Bush's doorstep. His son Neil had made a highly publicized appearance in May before a congressional committee investigating the $1 billion collapse of a Colorado thrift, Silverado Banking, Savings and Loan Association. Federal regulators have accused Neil Bush, 35, of conflict of interest in his role as a former director of Silverado. In addition to establishing the S&L fraud squads, the president also moved to double spending for Justice Department and Internal Revenue Service S&L investigators and prosecutors from $50 million to $100 million in fiscal 1991, which begins Oct. 1. Bush also created the new special counsel position at Justice - the administration's ``top gun'' on S&L fraud. ``My mandate is to basically get this entire program of administration initiatives up and running,'' Richmond told the AP this summer. ``We need to put those people in jail and call them to account for their conduct.'' Richmond, a large, jovial man who also seems to have a tough-guy aspect, has been both an FBI agent and a lawyer in private practice. He bristled at the suggestion that the new fraud teams and interagency group might be a showpiece, adding another layer to the federal bureaucracy. ``The purpose is to cut through the bureaucracy,'' he said, noting that government employees in the S&L enforcement effort have easy access to him. ``We'll be here long after the klieg lights are gone on this issue,'' Richmond said.

DOC.HEAD: Mother Teresa Hopes to Open New Missions in Soviet Union, Albania
DOC.TEXT: Mother Teresa said Saturday she hopes to open eight more missions in the Soviet Union and send nuns to Albania, an officially atheist nation. The 80-year-old Nobel laureate also said she received permission from ``my friend Fidel Castro'' to increase the number of homes operated by the Missionaries of Charity in Cuba from four to seven. Asked about the Persian Gulf crisis, she said, ``People have told me to write to (Iraqi) President Saddam (Hussein), and I am thinking about it.'' Mother Teresa, who was recently re-elected head of the order despite her request for retirement, was in Vatican City to address an international priests' retreat and meet with Pope John Paul II. She said she seeks to have 15 homes for the poor and outcast in the Soviet Union. Her order currently has six homes in the Soviet Union and has been invited to open seven more, she said. She also said she asked Albania's leader Ramiz Alia if she could send nuns to the country, which is slowly undergoing reforms after years of strict isolationism. ``He wrote back asking me to go there, but I answered, `I can't go without my family, which consists of my fellow nuns,' and I am praying that this will happen,'' said Mother Teresa, who was in Vatican City to address an international priests' retreat and meet with Pope John Paul II. Mother Teresa was born in Skopje, Yugoslavia, to ethnic Albanian parents. The Missionaries of Charity operate about 430 homes in 95 nations. The order has about 3,000 nuns.

DOC.HEAD: Flood Mop-Up Continues; Death Toll at 114
DOC.TEXT: More than 400,000 government workers, reserve forces and soldiers were mobilized Saturday to help clean up after flooding from the nation's worst rainstorms on record. In Seoul, army reservists with shovels and brooms mopped up muddy roads, and others collected piles of trash. The Central Disaster Relief Center put the death toll from three days of torrential rains last week at 114. Officials said 37 others were reported missing and some 180,000 people were left homeless. Officials said damage to homes, farmland, roads and public utilities would top $400 million.

DOC.HEAD: Another Day, Another Death in Soweto
With AM-South Africa, Bjt
LaserPhotos JOH1-6
DOC.NOTE: EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: Almost 800 people have died in black faction fighting in townships around Johannesburg since August. Here is a firsthand account of one of those deaths.

The sun rose brightly in Soweto Saturday, shining through the smoky haze. People walked along the roads and swept their red dirt yards. Dogs scampered through piles of garbage. At Inhlazane train station, a man would soon die. Shortly after dawn, groups of residents milled about on one side of the train platform. They pointed at a small crowd of blacks on the other side of the tracks who live in a nearby migrant workers hostel. The station formed a 150-yard barrier between them. When trains arrived, people getting off crouched low and scurried across the platform and tracks, using the coaches as a shield. Someone fired a handgun. Everyone ducked. Robin Oupa, 36, said he was supposed to go to work at a hospital. ``Right now, I can't even go to the (train) terminal,'' he said. On the platform, a group armed with machetes and crude spears questioned people getting off a train. Suddenly, they began pushing a large man in a blue worksuit down the stairs toward the street. The man resisted but did not fight. More people joined the shouting crowd. Attackers kicked the man, then hit him with fist-sized stones. Several plunged small daggers into his head, back and chest. They kicked him down and some hurled boulders the size of anvils at his head. He continued to crawl. More rocks hit him and he collapsed. Someone poured petrol on him. When the match struck, he burst into flames and leaped in the air. Onlookers yelled what sounded like a cheer. A woman danced. He ran in circles before falling for the last time. A youth hacked at his head with a machete. Some attackers said the man had failed to correctly answer their questions. They said he was a Zulu spy from the hostel dwellers on the other side of the tracks. Oupa said Zulu supporters of the conservative Inkatha movement lived in the hostel. He said they attacked residents of the small, brown houses on the near side, most of whom support the African National Congress. ``They take a young boy, kill him and cut off his private parts,'' he said. ``Those people are wrong. ... When they kill a young boy, it is wrong.'' Inkatha blames the ANC for the fighting. Charges of police and right-wing whites provoking the ongoing violence also have surfaced. Attacks on trains and taxis last week killed dozens of blacks. ``We can't go by trains, no taxis, what can we do?'' Oupa said. ``We must fight.''

DOC.HEAD: Capital A Kinder, Cleaner Place For Asian Games
DOC.TEXT: This city of gritty air, bicycle gridlock and hostile sales clerks has become a kinder, cleaner, emptier place on the eve of hosting its first major world sports event, the Asian Games. The repaved streets are lined with flowers. Buildings have been washed and painted, with false facades hiding the ugliest houses. An army of 20,000 students patrols the sidewalks, ready to fine spitters or litterbugs. Most out-of-town Chinese visitors, averaging 1 million per day, have been ordered to stay home. Vehicle traffic also has been cut for the Sept. 22-Oct. 7 games, a kind of Olympics for 38 Asian and Mideast nations. Most striking of all, China's normally cranky service personnel are being polite - to foreigners, anyway. ``Can I help you?'' clerks rush to ask in newly learned English in hotels and shops adjoining the shiny new Asian Games Village. Even police have added ``please'' and ``thank you'' to their vocabularies as Beijing orchestrates an unprecedented public relations campaign directed at an often critical outside world. ``Of course it is a political event more than a sports event,'' said a Chinese reporter. The Communist leadership is determined to vindicate socialism, and especially the army attack that killed hundreds of peaceful pro-democracy protesters in Beijing last year, drawing international condemnation. Officials have said the 100,000 foreign tourists expected in the city of 10 million for the games will see firsthand a China that is stable and loyal to the Communist Party. To ensure nothing happens to spoil that, work units across the city are telling their employees to stay off the streets on the games' opening day, and watch the ceremonies on television. Large gatherings are banned for the 17-day period and college students, China's most volatile citizens, are to stay on campus. Security is at its heaviest since martial law was lifted in January. Paramilitary police drill openly with riot gear and helicopters buzz overhead in unexplained security exercises. Appeals for cooperation and order are being made in the name of patriotism, not sportsmanship. The tens of thousands of students and office workers who spent weekends aiding a last-minute dash to finish building stadiums and hotels were told that voluntary labor is a ``glorious revolutionary tradition.'' Privately, many Beijing residents say they are sick of the Asian Games even before they start. Most of the nightly television news has been given over to progress reports on the preparations, and messages on public etiquette during the games are everywhere. Hardly a storefront in the city lacks decals of Pan Pan, the games' smiling panda mascot. The Beijing television news perhaps inadvertently acknowledged the public annoyance in brief footage shown this summer. An irate bicyclist being fined for violating traffic regulations was shown screaming at a policeman, ``Everything is Asian Games. It's all nonsense.'' Normally unruly Beijing commuters are learning that it pays to obey traffic rules these days. Some private street vendors and repairmen have been ordered out of business on the grounds that their operations are unattractive. Supplies of electricity to other parts of the city are being cut so the games venues can have enough. Heavily polluting factories are being shut down for the term of the games. People with unregistered pets are being ordered to kill them to reduce the chance of a rabies outbreak. Heavy trucks and vehicles deemed unattractive, such as locally made jeeps, are barred from main roads. But authorities don't want to hear any complaints. Chinese sources say that officials in their work units have warned that all public comments on the Asian Games must be positive. For malcontents, the message is summed up in a proverb: ``The bird that sticks out its head will be shot down.''

DOC.HEAD: France, In Angry Response to Iraq, Sends More Troops, Expels Diplomats
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with 8 grafs to UPDATE with Baker saying West Germany promising substantial aid; pick up 8th graf pvs, `In Madrid..'
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhotos NY5,6,9,LON1
DOC.TEXT: France announced today it will dispatch 4,000 more soldiers to the Persian Gulf and expel Iraqi military attaches in Paris in response to Iraq's raids on French, Belgian and Canadian diplomatic compounds in Kuwait. ``We will do what must be done,'' French President Francois Mitterrand told a news conference following an emergency Cabinet meeting. ``But we won't be taking hostages.'' President Bush pledged beforehand to support any French response to Friday's raids. Bush also said the U.S. Navy fired warning shots and boarded an Iraqi tanker in the Gulf of Oman on Friday as part of the effort to enforce trade sanctions against the Baghdad government. Secretary of State James A. Baker III said today after meeting with West German Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher that Bonn has made a ``significant'' offer of financial help for the U.S.-led campaign against Iraq. But Baker said he did not want to reveal the exact figures until after meeting with Chancellor Helmut Kohl later in the day. In other developments, another planeload of Americans left London for the United States today after their release from Iraq and Kuwait. Iraq is holding Westerners as human shields to deter any attack by U.S. forces in the gulf. Also, one report said Iraqi troops were eating zoo animals in Kuwait, where food has been short since the world embargo against Iraq's invasion of the country six weeks ago. In Madrid, the chairman of NATO's Military Committee appealed today for more multinational force deployments to be committed to the gulf. ``We should be prepared for a sustained operation if that's what is necessary to avoid war, '' said Norwegian Adm. Vigleik Eide, the committee chairman, at a news conference.``That's why it's so important to have more military contributions as well as logistical support.'' Iraqi troops raided the diplomatic compounds of France, Canada and Belgium in Kuwait on Friday, briefly detaining five Western consuls and capturing four French citizens, including the French military attache. The diplomat was freed after several hours, but Mitterrand said today the others were sent to join about 400 French nationals already held by Iraqi forces. Mitterrand also urged widening the U.N. embargo of Iraq and occupied Kuwait to air traffic. The new French forces bound for Saudi Arabia include a squadron of 30 warplanes, an 1,100-man helicopter regiment with 48 combat choppers, an armored regiment with 48 tanks, and an infantry regiment with anti-tank and anti-air missiles. France already has nine warships in the gulf region as well as 300 ground troops in Saudi Arabia and the United Arab Emirates, for a total of 3,800 servicemen. In addition to throwing out the military attaches in Paris, France will also expel 26 Iraqi civilian and military personnel who were taking training courses when Iraq invaded Kuwait Aug. 2. Iraqi Ambassador to France Abdelrazzek al Hachimi said Iraq ``will take reciprocal measures at a diplomatic level.'' He did not specify what those measures would be. Baker told Italian officials today the next six weeks will be crucial for efforts to resolve the gulf crisis. Asked whether Baker meant there would be no hope for a diplomatic solution beyond that period and military action then would be the only recourse, an Italian government spokesman said he was not authorized to interpret the remarks. Iraq denied its soldiers entered the foreign compounds and said the troops were under strict orders not to enter the embassies. Saddam's troops invaded and annexed Kuwait after the Baghdad government demanded the oil-rich emirate relinquish border territory, compensate for billions in oil pumped from disputed land and forgive billions in loans. The invsion prompted a U.N. embargo and a multinational military effort to deter possible Iraqi aggression. Late Friday, an Iraqi Airways jetliner landed at London's Gatwick airport with more than 350 evacuees, mostly American women and children. The Americans, believed to be among the last who agreed to leave behind their husbands and fathers in Kuwait, were traveling to the Washington area this afternoon. About 2,200 Americans remain captive in Iraq and Kuwait, and some Western men have been transferred to strategic Iraqi installations to deter attacks by Western forces. Galina Suliman of San Francisco, who arrived on the Boeing 747 from Baghdad, said before the plane took off for the United States: ``The Kuwaiti resistance has been put down ruthlessly by the Iraqis in the past day or two.'' Another passenger, Andrea Hanson from Portland, Ore., said Kuwaiti groups did not have enough weapons to fight the Iraqis. The Times of London today quoted Victor Watkins, an official of the World Society for the Protection of Animals, as saying Iraqi soldiers in Kuwait have eaten 70 percent of the edible animals in Kuwait's zoo. The newspaper did not specify how Watkins got his information or how many animals were in the zoo. ``It is a dreadful situation. Things are desperate enough for the people, so anyone might understand how bad it is for the animals,'' he was quoted as saying. Iraq has an estimated 265,000 troops in and around Kuwait. The United States has led the multinational buildup in Saudi Arabia and the gulf, with 150,000 troops and more than 30 warships in the region. Britain on Friday said it was sending the 7th Armored Brigade, successors to the Desert Rats of World War II, to Saudi Arabia with 120 tanks and 6,000 combat troops to bolster the multinational force. Canadian Prime Minister Brian Mulroney said a squadron of 12 CF-18 jets would be sent to fly cover for three Canadian warships en route to the gulf. Several other nations, including Italy, Belgium and South Korea, pledged either money or equipment Friday to support the multinational contingent. Baker this week urged NATO allies to send ground troops, even in token numbers, to symbolize shared involvement with the military buildup. Baker's meeting with Italian officials in Rome came before his West German trip. A day earlier, the West German government - prevented by its constitution from deploying forces outside the NATO area - said it had given Washington a list of more than 50 merchant ships that could be used to transport American troops to the gulf. Bush on Friday asked Congress for $1.9 billion more to cover the costs of deploying the U.S. troops in the Middle East. Operation Desert Shield is costing Washington an estimated $1 billion a month, officials have said. The administration also is preparing ask Congress to approve the sale to Saudi Arabia of $18 billion in weapons, including F-15 fighter jets, tanks and other sophisticated arms, a U.S. official said on condition of anonymity. The administration has already proposed selling Saudi Arabia $3 billion in new weapons to bolster its defenses, congressional sources said. A senior security officer in Egypt said today Cairo is intensifying its campaign against Iraq's occupation of Kuwait by restricting entry of Iraqis and citizens of Arab countries that support President Saddam Hussein. The official said the curbs apply to Jordanians, Yemenis and Palestinians.

DOC.HEAD: For Exiled Kuwaiti Children, Luxury Is No Cure For Homesickness
DOC.TEXT: DIVONNE-LES-BAINS, France (AP) - Although she lives in a posh vacation villa and rides to school in a luxury car, 12-year-old Dalal finds that enforced exile is no fun. Tears of homesickness give her away. Dalal is one of 60 Kuwaiti children who last week entered French public schools in this spa town 11 miles north of Geneva. Their wealthy families, who for years have spent summers here, were stranded when Iraqi forces occupied Kuwait on Aug. 2. The children face the prospect of their first cold winter - and their first taste of financial hardship. During a recess, Dalal turned on her Walkman casette player to listen to patriotic Kuwaiti songs. She began sobbing, and two of her Kuwaiti friends, clad in tight blue jeans and baggy sweatshirts, cried with her. ``Living in France is not a problem - the people are very kind,'' said 16-year-old Shaika. ``The trouble is that we are outside our country and we can't go home. We feel alone, but when we talk to each other it helps.'' Divonne-Les-Bains, a town of 6,000 people nestled in the foothills of the Jura Mountains, boasts luxury hotels, a man-made lake with sand beaches, a casino, golf course and race track. Several dozen Kuwaiti families live in lakeside and hillside villas surrounded by high iron fences. Many of the homes have tennis courts, swimming pools, and satellite dishes. The families are worried about security, and school officials asked that the children be identified only by their first names. But the students spoke freely about the new uncertainties in their lives. They said their families had become budget-conscious for the first time because some bank accounts were inaccessible. Kuwaiti assets were frozen by many governments in order to shield them from plunder by the Iraqis. ``My parents used to take us out to dinner all the time,'' Dalal said. ``Now its out to the supermarket and back.'' ``We used to go shopping and choose anything we like. We had everything,'' added Hawazen, 16. ``Now my mother tells me to pick something cheap, something I'll wear a lot.'' Many of the fathers, who include diplomats and businessmen, used to spend the evenings at the casino. Now they offer assistance to the Kuwaiti Embassy in Geneva and drink tea together while watching nightly television news reports. The youths said a return to Kuwait now would be dangerous, possibly even fatal, but they all said they would not have fled if they had been home when the invasion occurred. Most have relatives left behind. For Haifaa, a 21-year-old Kuwaiti university student, picking up her brother and cousins at school is the main daily activity. She finds the waiting intolerable. ``I would rather go back to Kuwait to be with my other brothers and sisters and die than be separated like this,'' she said. School officials have gone out of their way to accommodate the Kuwaitis, whose children speak Arabic and English, not French. No tuition is charged, and alternative meals are offered on days when the French students are fed pork, which is taboo for Moslems. One Western custom has not been modified: co-ed classes. Dalal said she didn't mind her first exposure to male classmates. But one 14-year-old Kuwaiti boy, Sabih, complained about girls in his class. The director of the secondary school, Chantal Daux, said she initially suggested that multilingual private schools in Geneva would be more suitable. But the parents insisted on the Divonne-les-Bains schools, apparently mindful of $10,000 annual tuition at the private schools. ``The parents expect us to teach the children French, discipline and the European way of life,'' Ms. Daux said. ``Our goal is to help them adapt smoothly ... without pampering them in a gilded ghetto.'' A additional English-speaking teacher has been hired to assist the children in special language courses aimed at preparing them to do all their studies in French as soon as possible. Ms. Daux said she never questioned the importance of welcoming the Kuwaitis into her school. ``It's a terrible human tragedy for anyone who loses his roots,'' she said. ``I thought about the children and their despair. I put myself in the place of their mothers and did what I would want done for my children.''

DOC.HEAD: New Transcript Reveals Senator's Early Vietnam Frustration
DOC.TEXT: In 1965, the year that U.S. forces in Vietnam grew from 23,300 to 184,300 troops, Sen. J. William Fulbright complained bitterly in private that the Johnson administration had misled him about the war's progress, according to newly declassified documents. Defense Secretary Robert S. McNamara had testified in 1964 that the Americans could get out of Vietnam by April 1965, and Fulbright, chairman of the Senate Foreign Relations Committee, told fellow senators on July 23 that he had allowed himself to be taken in. ``I think maybe we have been too easy on McNamara and some of those in the years gone by, in accepting their optimistic statement. ... I did not know enough to say, `Why you are a bloody fool, this is absolute nonsense,''' Fulbright said at a closed-door hearing of the committee. ``I just did not know enough. ``He (McNamara) said it and he has been out there,'' Fulbright continued. ``It was long after the fact that it began to be apparent that they had utterly misjudged the seriousness and the character of the whole thing.'' Fulbright's frustration comes to light in transcripts of the committee's closed hearings in 1965. Released Saturday by the panel, the transcripts provide a footnote to the history of that period. Fulbright, an Arkansas Democrat, is now a Washington attorney. Attempts to reach him by telephone on Saturday were unsuccessful. Fulbright, later to become one of the Senate's foremost critics of President Lyndon Johnson's war policies, was playing the role of a reluctant supporter. But in an interview with The Associated Press on April 12, 1965, he called for a temporary halt in bombing raids on North Vietnam as a spur to peace talks. Secretary of State Dean Rusk replied that such an act ``would only encourage the aggressor.'' And Johnson, reacting to Fulbright, said that until the independence of South Vietnam was guaranteed ``there is no human power capable of forcing us from Vietnam.'' Three years later, on March 31, 1968, Johnson went before a nationwide television audience to announce a unilateral halt of the bombardment of North Vietnam and his own decision not to seek re-election. Three days later, North Vietnam agreed to open negotiations in Paris. The United States withdrew from Vietnam in 1973 and the war ended with the North Vietnamese capture of Saigon in 1975. In August 1964, the year before Fulbright's private disenchantment, he steered through the Gulf of Tonkin Resolution which Johnson used as the equivalent of a declaration of war. It passed the Senate 88-2 and the House 416-0 a few days after two U.S. Navy vessels reported they had come under attack in the Tonkin Gulf, off the coast of North Vietnam. The resolution authorized Johnson to ``take all necessary measures to repel an armed attack ... and to prevent further aggression.'' Many times in the ensuing years, Fulbright expressed dismay that he used his influence to help pass so open-ended a resolution. The transcript shows that as early as April 1965 Fulbright was concerned about the way resolution was being used as a de facto declaration of war. ``The existing mission, I thought, was a rather limited one,'' he told Rusk. ``But in effect, for all practical purposes, we arewaging war on North Vietnam ... It would seem to me not out of order if we are going to send 30,000, 50,000, 100,000 men, that the Congress might have the say about it.'' He added: ``The operation in Vietnam has obviously become quite controversial. A lot of us have been quiet. We do not want to embarrass the administration. We have not discussed it in public.'' Rusk replied ``Well, Mr. Chairman, it is very hard to look into the future to that extent...'' ``We have the impression that Hanoi is not yet convinced that it cannot win in the south. We also have the impression that they are relying heavily on the buildup of international and domestic opinion in this country to cause the United States to in some way pull back from the situation.''

DOC.HEAD: Jordan Fears It May Be First Casualty in Gulf Crisis
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: As Iraq and its foes dig into the sand for a long, hard war of nerves, leaders in Jordan fear their once-thriving desert kingdom will be the first casualty. ``We could simply disappear,'' observed an influential banker, who spoke on condition of anonymity. He recalled an old proverb: When elephants fight, the grass gets trampled. Jordan was rocketed to prosperity by the Persian Gulf oil boom in the 1970s. Amman joined chaotic Beirut as a regional capital. But since 1985, regional recession has plunged Jordan into hard times. Now, economists warn, the gulf crisis might deliver a fatal blow. If it drags on for a year, Jordan could lose $2 billion. Its annual budget is only $3.7 billion. Jordan and other countries in the gulf region will loose billions of dollars worth of trade, service fees and worker remittances as a result of the U.N.-imposed economic sanctions against Iraq, and the crisis itself. Tourism, another source of income for Jordan, is also at a low. At Petra, only the flutes of Bedouin children tending goats echo off the ancient ruins that once attracted 1,000 foreign tourists a day. ``This has gone beyond crisis,'' said Riad Khouri, a Jordanian who directs Middle East Business Associates in Beirut. ``This is catastrophe.'' ``The future is a black abyss,'' one European diplomat put it. ``Jordan might get smothered by circumstances.'' Saudi Arabia, a reliable if reluctant benefactor, has turned off the tap. A foreign debt of $8.5 billion, rescheduled at great pain, cannot be repaid. Even if foreign aid promised by the European Community and Japan, among others, offsets some losses, the disrupted economy threatens the livelihood of many Jordanians who now must compete with the thousands who have come home from Iraq and Kuwait. In Amman, knots of Asian refugees huddle under trees on empty lots, giving the flowered, comfortable capital an air of wartime despondency. Everywhere, stalled construction projects leave the New Hampshire-size nation of 3.1 million hanging somewhere between biblical times and the space age. And economics is only part of it. Jordan's historic role as a mediator among regional extremes is now in question. In the stormiest part of the political world, King Hussein's Jordan has been the lightning rod. The country has bent in each wind and sprung back to center. But this time, the winds may be too strong. ``We're trying to maintain this position at the center,'' said a senior Jordanian official, spreading his fingers in reflection. ``But it's true, this will be very difficult.'' Western powers want Jordan to seal off Iraq and condemn Saddam Hussein as an outlaw. Saddam wants his ally and trading partner to help him evade what he calls anti-Arab sanctions. King Hussein is obliged to lean toward Iraq not only by the strong popular support for Saddam within Jordan, but by the Palestinians who straddle both banks of the Jordan River. His position has angered Western allies. Israel regards Jordan as a potential corridor for invasion from Iraq. Its right-wing government rejects negotiation with the Palestinians over the Israeli-occupied territories. The economic and political strains promise only to worsen. Nearly 300,000 Jordanians work in the gulf, and possibly half of them might return. Even in normal times, Jordan's population growth rate of 4 percent is among the world's highest. Unemployment was already at 20 percent when Iraq invaded Kuwait Aug. 2, and it could soon double. Inflation, now near 15 percent, could also double if the Jordanian dinar loses more value. Food subsidies have been cut. The price of sugar tripled overnight. Authorities fear crime will no longer be a rare phenomenon among Jordanians, who are mostly devout Moslems. ``We're being flooded with people who've lost everything, and desperate people cannot afford morality,'' said Sabri Rubeihat, a police major who teaches sociology and criminology. ``This will be very serious.'' Developments so far have stung the royal family which, aides say, feels it has been tragically misunderstood by its friends. Crown Prince Hassan, writing in the Washington Post, blamed hostility in Washington on ``uninformed, naive'' American columnists. He wrote: ``The shrieks of important media pundits have all too often a distressing way of shaping public perceptions - particularly in the United States, a country that Jordan has always felt close to because of shared democratic and cultural values. ``We do not wish to lose the friendship and goodwill of Americans, and especially not on account of impressions sustained by malevolent editorializing.'' But U.S. officials watch not only the newspapers but also food and supplies slipping across the border to Iraq in defiance of the U.N. economic sanctions. Public criticism has been muted, but U.S. sources say they are concerned. One Jordanian political analyst, who also spoke on condition of anonymity, added his voice to a generally pessimistic mood. ``Jordan did not exist in 1920,'' he said. ``There is no reason for it to exist in the year 2000.''

DOC.HEAD: Stone Thrown by Mower Kills Man Passing By in Car
DOC.TEXT: A tractor mower being used to cut brush threw a four-pound rock through the open window of a passing car, hitting the driver of the car in the head and killing him. Michael Polski, 71, of Millerstown was struck Friday afternoon, said state police Trooper Richard Geedey. Polski's car then drifted off the road into a cornfield. Polski was declared dead at the scene by a Perry County deputy coroner, Geedey said. No charges have been filed against the person operating the tractor mower, whose name was not released, according to Geedey.

DOC.HEAD: Number Of Meningitis Victims Rises To 380
DOC.TEXT: At least 380 Ugandans have died during an outbreak of meningitis, and a health worker predicted the death toll may rise, a newspaper reported Saturday. New Vision newspaper, citing unidentified government officials, said about 180 deaths occurred in the Moroto district, about 315 miles northeast of the capital city of Kampala. On Friday, a senior official in the Mbarara district, about 165 miles southwest of Kampala, said about 200 people had died in a 2-month-old outbreak. Meningitis, a viral disease that attacks the brain and spinal cord, can be fatal if not treated early. Andrew Lobur, a health worker in a Moroto dispensary, said the toll could rise. ``Many others are still dying in far away villages where they could not reach the dispensary or health centers,'' he was quoted as saying. Henry Rwigymera, Mbarara district administrator, said Uganda's stocks of anti-meningitis drugs were exhausted. New supplies are expected next week.

DOC.HEAD: Desert Shield Planned From Underground Command Center
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
LaserPhoto DHA5
DOC.TEXT: Five floors under the streets of this desert capital lies the ``War Room'' where U.S. and Saudi officers plan strategy for the troops, tanks and aircraft hundreds of miles to the north. The emphasis is on equal partnership as top officers gather behind the vault-like doors twice a day for briefings on the latest situation in the confrontation with Iraq. Officials familiar with the workings of the top-secret command post say the operation's joint nature is intended to keep the massive U.S. military force from overwhelming the Saudis in their own country. U.S. officers acknowledge that the lines of command authority often appear fuzzy, but insist there is no major conflict over who is in charge. Two Associated Press journalists were granted access to the command post on condition they did not name any officers or reveal the location of the center.
