In interviews, U.S. and Saudi officers agreed the system has worked relatively smoothly. ``Decisions can be taken jointly and then communicated to the separate command lines in the field,'' said a senior U.S. officer, speaking on condition of anonymity. But he noted his Saudi counterpart at the center is free to issue orders to American officers. Even the name of the underground bunker is meant to symbolize harmony: the Coalition, Coordination, Communications and Integration Center, or CCCIC, which is based on NATO and other integrated military headquarters. ``We've taken pieces of experiences elsewhere and put them together. The pieces - intelligence, operations, air, surface, naval - are all pretty standard. How we've glued them together is what's different,'' the senior officer explained. The center, set up in the early days of Operation Desert Shield and still being assembled, is run by two major generals - one American and one Saudi - who sit at adjoining desks. The rest of the large, high-ceilinged room is taken up with groupings of desks for separate air, land and sea operations. Officers, mostly colonels and majors from the two countries, work side by side to collect and analyze information from the field. ``We try to keep the ranks as even as we can,'' said a U.S. officer. Business is conducted in English, since few of the Americans are proficient in Arabic. Many of the Saudi officers trained in the United States or Britain. The U.S. general heading the American side is a veteran of service in Saudi Arabia. His Saudi counterpart wears a graduate's ring from the U.S. Army War College at Carlisle Barracks, Pa. ``Some of us have a cultural awareness, but even though we know each other, we're very conscious of the difference. We don't dominate, we specifically try to balance things,'' said one U.S. officer. At the field command level, U.S. officers maintain control over their own troops. The Saudis lead their units, as well as the Egyptian, Syrian, Moroccan, and other Arab forces. Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf, commander of the U.S. forces in Saudi Arabia, and his counterpart Prince Khaled Bin Sultan, the Saudi Chief of Staff, are frequent visitors to the command center. But in the event of war, they would ``move around, stay flexible'' because they can be in instant touch with the command center from anywhere, the senior officer said. Should fighting actually break out, he said, there would be ``some sort of early warning. The Iraqis could not take us by surprise. Then there would be a focused integrated defense plan bringing all the U.S. and Islamic forces together.''

DOC.HEAD: `Skinhead Mentality' Teen Booked With Shooting Black Woman
DOC.TEXT: A 16-year-old dropout tattooed with white supremacy slogans has been accused of killing a 59-year-old black woman, allegedly because she pulled away from a stop sign too slowly for his taste. Chad Sullivan, 16, who had been kicked out of his grandmother's house two weeks ago, was booked Friday on a charge of murder in the death of Dorothy Mae Gourrier, police said. Police speculated that the killing was racially motivated. Sullivan was tattooed with white supremacy and satanist slogans, police said. The walls of an apartment where Sullivan recently had stayed were covered with slurs against blacks, Jews and police, according to police and the apartment's owner. An Orleans Parish Juvenile Court judge is to decide Monday whether Sullivan should stand trial as an adult. Mrs. Gourrier was shot Wednesday while driving in New Orleans. Sullivan had been arrested Thursday on a trespassing charge after police caught him swimming in a canal. The Times-Picayune quoted an unidentified source Saturday as saying that one of Sullivan's friends called police Thursday and said the youth had been bragging about killing Gourrier. Other friends confirmed the report, the source told the newspaper. He also was booked on a charge of assault Thursday, after Officer Earl Woolfolk, who is black, identified him as the person who hit him with a beer bottle and broke his nose while he was jogging Sept. 7. Police said they have not found the gun or the car from which Mrs. Gourrier was shot. Sullivan's grandmother, Meldean Cowen, said she and her husband, Everett, kicked Sullivan out of their home about two weeks ago, after he took her car without permission and wrecked it. ``My husband told him he couldn't live here anymore if he was going to do things that way,'' Mrs. Cowen said. ``He had been going in and out of the window. My husband and I are over 65 and we can't handle that kind of behavior.'' She said Sullivan had lived with them off and on for more than two years, never staying more than a few weeks at a time, and had dropped out of school in ninth grade. He no longer lives with his mother in Metairie because of family problems, she said. ``He was in trouble all the time for one thing or another,'' she said. Sullivan's mother, Karen Dussor, would not comment. ``The family has been struggling with this kid forever,'' said his attorney, Alice Jacobs. ``I don't know if he's had a violent crime up to now. Basically he's been joy-riding in cars.''

DOC.HEAD: Carroll College Gunman Changes Pleas to Guilty
DOC.TEXT: A man accused of gunning down two women college workers in a drunken shooting spree in a campus cafeteria has pleaded guilty to charges of murder and attempted murder. John W. Aills faces a maximum of 100 years in prison on each count when he is sentenced Oct. 25. He also faces extradition on another charge to South Carolina, where he could get the death penalty. Aills originally pleaded innocent and indicated he would claim the May 18 shootings at Carroll College, a small Roman Catholic college in Helena, were a result of a mental disease or defect. But a series of psychological evaluations this summer failed to support that defense, Lewis and Clark County Attorney Mike McGrath said before Friday's hearing. Aills, 34, from Dayton, Ohio, said little in court other than to acknowledge that he understood the charges against him and the consequences of his guilty pleas to deliberate homicide and attempted deliberate homicide. Asked about a possible motive, McGrath said Friday there appeared to be none. ``What the record shows is that he was very drunk and very mean,'' he said of Aills. ``He had a long history of alcoholism and has had a gun fetish for a long time.'' Security was tight for the hearing because authorities had received several death threats against Aills over the past two weeks, said McGrath. He refused to elaborate. The court was filled with relatives of the victims. Defense attorney Nick Jacques said Aills did not remember anything of the shootings. He said the guilty plea reflected Aills' belief that the evidence against him would be enough for convictions. McGrath recounted some details of the incident, noting that there were witnesses and the murder weapon - a .44-caliber revolver - was next to Aills when he was found hiding under a fir tree on the campus shortly after the shootings. Aills, a former ranch hand but unemployed at the time of his arrest, has been held without bail since his arrest for the murder of Sharon Hance, 52, a Carroll College secretary, and the wounding of Emma Peschke, 42, a food service worker. The two women were shot while they sat with a group of college workers on their coffee breaks. After his sentencing, he will be extradited to South Carolina where he faces another murder charge in a 1987 stabbing. McGrath noted that Aills could face the death penalty in that state.

DOC.HEAD: NASA Counting Down for Tuesday Launch of Columbia
DOC.TEXT: NASA's fourth countdown for Columbia began Saturday as scientists prepared once again for the long astronomy mission and tried to keep their excitement in check. Columbia has been grounded for 3{ months because of leaking hydrogen. Officials will not know for sure whether all of the leaks have been plugged until the shuttle is fueled for Tuesday's early morning launch. ``This is the fourth countdown we're going through. We're getting a little bit too used to it,'' said mission scientist Ted Gull. ``But the nervousness of the first flight isn't there. We know we're ready, and that's a very positive thing to say.'' Since the last launch attempt 1{ weeks ago, NASA has replaced two leaking components in Columbia's aft compartment. A new set of recirculation pumps also was installed, but engineers later determined there was nothing wrong with the ones that were removed. Hydrogen flooded Columbia's aft compartment during fueling for the Sept. 6 launch attempt. But no leaks were detected around new fuel lines between the orbiter and external tank, the site of extensive leaking during fueling for the first launch attempt in late May. Columbia's second countdown was halted late last month after communication with one of four telescopes aboard the shuttle was disrupted. The telescopes constitute a $150 million observatory called Astro that will probe ultraviolet light and X-rays emitted from some of the hottest objects in the universe. Gull and other scientists have had to revise Astro's observing schedule after each launch delay. The mission originally was scheduled for March 1986, but was put on indefinite hold when Challenger exploded earlier that year. Only three or four targets were lost as a result of the latest 12-day postponement, Gull said. Among the more than 260 objects Astro is set to observe are a comet making its first recorded pass through the solar system, a supernova and Jupiter. Four astronomers who are part of Columbia's seven-man crew will operate Astro's three ultraviolet telescopes round-the-clock. The X-ray telescope will be managed by computer commands sent from the ground. The observatory will remain in the shuttle's cargo bay throughout the nine-to-10-day mission, the first in five years devoted entirely to scientific research. ``There's guarded excitement,'' Gull said. ``I think it's about time. Astro deserves success. NASA deserves a success, too.'' NASA has not launched a shuttle since April, when Discovery carried the Hubble Space Telescope into orbit. Two months later, the $1.5 billion telescope was found to have a badly flawed mirror that blurs images. Launch director Bob Sieck said Columbia will have two chances to lift off - Tuesday and Wednesday. If it isn't launched by then, its mission will be postponed until after Discovery's October mission to deploy a sun-probing satellite. Discovery must lift off by Oct. 23 or wait until late 1991 when Earth is in proper alignment again with the sun and Jupiter. The satellite, called Ulysses, needs Jupiter's gravity to achieve the right solar orbit. Gull already is mapping out an observing schedule for November in case Columbia does not get off the ground this week. ``We're trying to hedge our bets,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Party Chairman Praises Bush Gulf Strategy, Attacks GOP Domestic Stands
DOC.TEXT: The chairman of the Democratic Party offered a preview Saturday of his strategy for the 1990 elections: full support for President Bush on the Persian Gulf coupled with an all-out attack on Republican domestic policies. ``Saddam Hussein will get no mixed signals from America or from this party,'' Ronald H. Brown told a meeting of the Democratic National Committee. He declared that the opposition party ``stands behind our president as he acts to roll back Iraq's blatant aggression.'' But Brown made clear where partisan politics begins. ``We'll stand up to Saddam Hussein,'' he said ``but we won't stand by as the new Republican recession wreaks havoc on our economy.'' The closest Brown and his fellow Democrats came to criticizing the Republican president on the Middle East was to denounce Bush and Ronald Reagan for failing to have an energy policy that would make the nation less dependent on imported oil. On domestic issues, Brown pulled no punches. He hammered at Bush for proposing ``massive tax cuts for America's plutocrats'' and he blamed the Republicans for the savings and loan crisis. ``We're in the fall campaign for real and we Democrats are running hard,'' Brown told the DNC. His speech reflected the election-year dilemma created by Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait and the Bush administration's military response. On the one hand, the Democrats feel they have no choice but to back the president at a time when American troops are confronting a hostile force overseas. At the same time, the Persian Gulf crisis has made it difficult for the Democrats to get voters to pay attention to issues on which the Republicans looked vulnerable before the invasion. ``People are angry,'' about the S&L scandals, said Ohio Democratic chairman Jim Ruvolo. ``And they blame Republicans more than Democrats.'' ``But now that's faded into the background,'' he added. ``There's this big screen between voters and information and that screen is Iraq.'' The two-day Democratic Party meeting was remarkably free of the internal bickering has characterized such sessions in past years, which was just what Brown had hoped for. The Democrats adopted the formal call for their 1992 nominating convention, including the rules which will determine how more than 4,000 delegtes will be allocated among the states and territories. The precise allocations won't be known until after the 1990 Census and the shift in congressional seats. California will have the largest convention delegation and its share of the total will increase dramatically. Preliminary Census figures show California likely to gain seven new House seats. In the past, bitter fights have been waged around such arcane matters as the wording of the call, but this time it passed without debate or a dissenting vote. The Democrats also adopted resolutions criticizing the Republicans for lacking an energy policy and urging the president to sign legislation now moving through the Democratic-controlled Congress that would strengthen laws barring discrimination in the workplace. Bush has threatened to veto the legislation on the grounds it would force businesses to adopt quotas and would promote increased litigation. With Brown's strong backing, the Democrats tabled a resolution that would have urged budget negotiators to ``reject new taxes as a way to balance the Bush federal budget.''

DOC.HEAD: Campus Struggling To Return to Normal After Killings
DOC.TEXT: University of Florida senior Jodie Spencer has been commuting 60 miles home to Jacksonville ever since the bodies of five students were found in off-campus apartments. ``I'm terrified,'' said Miss Spencer. ``I have an apartment here, but I haven't spent one night here (since Aug. 28) and I will not until someone is arrested.'' This college town has been reeling since the discovery of five murdered students, three of them mutilated, including one who was decapitated. Hundreds of students fled the campus on Labor Day weekend. The fact that the most-publicized suspect, Edward Lewis Humphrey, 18, is in jail on unrelated charges has caused some students to let down their guard but has not eased the tension for many others. Humphrey, a University of Florida freshman with a fondness for military fantasy and knives, has not been charged in the slayings. ``I'm not back to normal even though I think everyone else is,'' Miss Spencer said. ``The severity of the mutilation is what bothers me.'' University officials said an estimated 500 students have withdrawn from school as a result of the slayings, which occurred as fall classes were starting. Michelle Hager, a 20-year-old junior from Miami, says she's concerned that many students are neglecting their own safety now that three weeks have passed. ``Students are pretty much back in the swing of things, but many are starting to slack off,'' she said. Some of her friends are even walking alone at night, she said. ``Most people think it is Humphrey,'' she said. Humphrey is being held in lieu of $1.1 million bond in Brevard County. He has been charged with beating his 79-year-old grandmother at their home in Indialantic, about 180 miles away. He also faces warrants in an Aug. 25 assault on two male University of Florida students and an October 1988 armed burglary and attempted rape in Indian River County. The only other suspect whose name has been disclosed, Stephen Bates, 30, also is jailed on unrelated charges, in the Polk County Jail in Bartow. While most of the public attention has focused on Humphrey, search of Bates' Lakeland home has turned up a hangman's noose, personal satanic writings and books on satanism and Jack the Ripper, The Lakeland Ledger reported Saturday. Police have said there are eight suspects. ``I think a lot of people are letting down their guard because they think Edward Humphrey is the guy, but I think the attacker is still out there,'' said Desiree Mooney, 22, a senior from West Palm Beach. Debbie Rohlfing, 20, a senior from Montclair, Va., lives in the Hawaiian Village Apartments, where Humphrey also had an apartment. She never met him. ``I think a lot of people are trying to get on with their lives, but some students are still paranoid,'' she said. She said she is acting as if the killer is loose, and added, ``People are being real careful.'' Danny Grissom, 22, a senior from Miami, said he and his roommate had taken precautions against attack. ``My roommate has a gun and I have a knife,'' he said. ``I feel safe, but even now I feel you have to be careful.'' Police said they've seen a noticeable decline in tension. ``Things are calming down and leveling off,'' said police Lt. Sadie Darnell, who added that extra patrols around apartment complexes are continuing. A dramatic jump in the number of calls to police was reported the week after the slayings. Calls to the 911 emergency number were up 81 percent, and calls to the main police telephone number jumped 557 percent. Calls are still more frequent than normal but are decreasing, Ms. Darnell said. Media attention also has dwindled, but the killings are never far from the consciousness of University of Florida students. Christopher Cairns, a 25-year-old engineering student, said business has picked up in the pub where he works. Immediately after the killings, no one came in at night. ``I'm more relaxed, but still cautious,'' he said. ``That's how I am and I perceive others to be.''

DOC.HEAD: Analysts Say Saddam's High Command Is Weak Link In Iraqi Military
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 1 graf fpr 9th pvs, `As a...' to correct spelling error.
DOC.TEXT: Should war break out in the Persian Gulf, the weak link in Iraq's formidable, combat-seasoned military machine could well be Saddam Hussein's high command, military analysts say. His tightly centralized chain of command allows field commanders little tactical initiative, a factor that frequently cost the Iraqis dearly in the 1980-88 war with Iran. Analysts say that Saddam's 1 million-man military, the fourth biggest in the world after the United States, the Soviet Union and China, is led by men promoted because of loyalty rather than professional skills. ``He surrounds himself with people who have very little operational ability,'' said Bernard Trainor, a former U.S. Marine general who has visited Iraq several times. ``Their job is to keep the boss placated. They'll even allow casualties in the field to do that.'' ``The problem for Saddam is that when you're in that kind of environment, told only what you want to hear, you lose your perspective and the ability to act decisively and quickly,'' said Trainor, who heads the national security program at Harvard's John F. Kennedy School of Government. He spoke in a telephone interview from Boston. Zeev Eytan, a former Israeli Army colonel who is now an analyst with the Jaffee Center for Strategic Studies in Jerusalem, noted: ``Saddam controls all military affairs, so it's safe to assume that corps and divisional commanders will do only what they are ordered to do.'' Eytan and others believe that the tight rein Saddam keeps on his commanders inhibits their ability to conduct effective rapid maneuvers. ``In the Gulf war, the Iraqis performed better in defense than in offense. They did well in offensive operations only when their missions had been well rehearsed,'' Eytan said. As a civilian strategist with no formal military training, Saddam ``is reminiscent of Hitler,'' Eytan said in a telephone interview. ``Hitler always intervened in high strategy, often disastrously. He trusted his own intuition more than the advice of the professionals around him,'' he noted. ``Perhaps after fighting for eight years against Iran Saddam has acquired some grasp of military strategy,'' Eytan said. Many analysts don't think so. Saddam invaded Iran in September 1980 expecting a quick victory. Instead, he triggered the longest conventional war this century, one that caused a million casualties - by conservative estimates. Saddam's inner circle of military advisers are Air Marshal Hamid Shaaban, 59, who commanded the air force until last year and is now an adviser to Saddam; Gen. Abdel-Jaber Khalil Shansal, the 70-year-old defense minister and former Chief of Staff; and Brig. Gen. Hussein Kamel, 50, the Minister of Industry and Military Industrialization. The current Chief of Staff is Lt. Gen. Nizar Abdul-Karim al-Khazraji, a corps commander during the Persian Gulf war. Shaaban and Kamel, who is Saddam's cousin and son-in-law, are both members of his clan from Takrit, his hometown in northern Iraq. Kamel is widely considered to be the rising star in Baghdad and a possible successor to Saddam. Shansal was made defense minister after Gen. Adnan Khairallah, Saddam's cousin and brother-in-law who held the post throughout the war, died in a mysterious helicopter crash in 1989. The Iraqis said the helicopter went down in a sandstorm. But word was Khairallah had been feuding with Saddam. Since he took power in 1979, Saddam has made sure that the military has been put under the complete control of the ruling Baath Party, the only political organization military men can belong to. The army is riddled with informers from Saddam's security apparatus. All senior military posts are held by Baathists and there are party cadres assigned to all heaquarters down to battalion level. ``Saddam doesn't trust the army. It's the only institution that could threaten him,'' said Trainor. Eytan said Saddam constantly shuffles commanders around to prevent any of them from establishing a power base. He regularly purges the military, particularly of important officers or war heroes whose popularity he perceives as a threat. ``This discourages initiative in the officer corps,'' said Eytan. ``Everyone's very careful in Iraq.'' Diplomats in Baghdad have recently reported signs of unrest in the officer corps. Unconfirmed reports have said as many as 120 officers have been executed for opposing the invasion of Kuwait. It's not clear how the army views Saddam's decision to throw in the towel with Iran last month, relinquishing all territory seized in the war and giving Tehran sovereignty over the eastern half of the Shatt-al-Arab waterway. Saddam did that to secure his eastern border with Iran while he was locked in the escalating confrontation with the United States. ``It must have been a bitter pill for the army to swallow. They must have wondered what the hell they fought the Iranians for eight years for,'' said Hans-Heino Kopietz, a Middle East specialist until recently with London's International Institute for Strategic Studies.

DOC.HEAD: Military Worries About Impact of Lengthy U.S. Deployment
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: The likelihood of a lengthy U.S. military deployment in Saudi Arabia is fostering nervousness among commanders, who doubt diplomacy will resolve the crisis and think time may be on Saddam Hussein's side. Apprehensions became apparent over the last week that a long wait in the desert could try the patience of Saudi hosts, hurt soldiers' morale and make a scapegoat of the U.S. military. As the feeling that war with Iraq is inevitable has given way to uncertainty, discontent has surfaced among U.S. troops. Complaints have flowed from both Americans and Saudis about the cultural strains caused by the U.S. presence. Despite public statements to the contrary, top U.S. officers in Saudi Arabia are increasingly saying in private that time is more an enemy of the United States and Saudi Arabia than of Saddam. While the final decision may be out of their hands, U.S. commanders are engaged in a debate over whether to push for a deadline after which force would be used. Saudi leaders clearly oppose a long deployment. ``Six months will be pushing it,'' a Saudi diplomatic official said recently in a private discussion. ``Our society will not be able to take more than that. If there's no war by then, we'll start one for you.'' A Saudi government official in oil-rich Eastern Province, where most U.S. troops are settling in, said: ``There's a big group of people out there who wish to see a military action quickly.'' For now, diplomacy must be given a chance, U.S. commanders say. Some hold out slim hopes a resolution will be reached; in any case, the United States needs 6-10 weeks to complete its military buildup. Gen. Michael Dugan, the Air Force chief of staff, said the two possible courses of action now were ``patience and sweat or ... violence and blood.'' Dugan endorsed patience. But he acknowledged ``if there's any culture in the world that's impatient it's mine, it's the United States.'' ``By late October we're going to be faced with a fundamental decision,'' said a ranking officer, speaking on condition he not be named. ``Did we come here to sit and watch and wait, or did we come here to put Saddam Hussein in his place? We're going to need a clear mission or we're going to be in big trouble.'' The prospect of waiting much past the end of October alarms military commanders. Politically, they fear that Arab support, even Saudi support, for the deployment might begin to waver. A greater worry is that the American public's support might begin to erode. ``I'm not sure the American people will be with us for the long haul,'' a senior officer said during a visit to Saudi Arabia last week. ``There's great support now, but it's an uneasy support and could disappear quickly.'' He said he believed the Helsinki summit between President Bush and Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev ended with a gentleman's agreement to give Moscow, for years a close Iraqi ally, time to attempt a ``backdoor'' diplomatic solution. ``My understanding is that in exchange, we asked the Soviets to be supportive, or at least understanding, if it came down to military action,'' he said. But another official on that trip said it was highly unlikely the United States would ever take unilateral military action against Iraq. ``If the world's support collapses and it's us against Saddam, the military will be set up to take the fall. That's what a lot of us are worrying about,'' the official said. Evidence is mounting that neither commanders nor their troops particularly like it in Saudi Arabia, with its harsh desert conditions far from home and rigid social customs, particularly attitudes toward women. At each base camp he visited last week, Gen. Colin Powell, chairman of the U.S. Joint Chiefs of Staff, was asked by soldiers when they could go home. At one point a Saudi officer ran up to a U.S. commander and demanded that U.S. servicewomen be sent home. ``Every day we're running into a new aspect of cultural differences,'' the U.S. commander, Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf, said in an interview. ``There's no magic solution.'' Powell suggested Thursday that rotations are planned to give the troops stationed in Saudi Arabia a break. But many units have brought most of their men and assets with them, leaving little leeway for rotations. ``When the enthusiasm starts to wane, and there are signs that it is already, we'll face some morale challenges,'' an Army general said. ``It's my biggest worry right now, but I don't have any answers.''

DOC.HEAD: Predictions Boost Interest in Quake Museum
DOC.TEXT: If visitors to the Evansville Museum's earthquake exhibit aren't all shaken up, they're certainly attentive - particularly since a scientist has predicted a quake could hit the area this December. ``A lot of times people walk through exhibits, nod their heads and walk out. This one they pay attention to,'' said Mitchell Luman, the museum's science director. New Mexico climatologist Iben Browning, who believes quakes can be triggered by tidal forces putting stress on earthquake faults, has estimated that a major quake could strike the Midwest on Dec. 2 or 3. Although many earthquake specialists scoff at the notion, they say there is no doubt there will be a major quake along the New Madrid fault eventually. ``We tell people it's not necessarily going to appen in December, but it is going to happen,'' Luman said. ``We tell people to be prepared all the time.'' The temporary exhibit, sponsored by the Independent Insurance Agents of Evansville, was planned three years ago, long before Browning's prediction caused a sensation, Luman said. But the museum welcomes the attention. The ``Shake, Rattle and Roll'' display, which includes a seismograph, fault-line maps and safety tips, has been extended two months until Dec. 16 because of its popularity. About 16,000 people have visited the museum since the display opened July 8, Luman said. He said there was no way to know how many were attracted by the earthquake information, which uses about 10 percent of the museum's space. But it's obvious that the display is causing a stir. ``People spend two to four times as long in here as they do in other exhibits in this space,'' Luman said. ``They're really serious and engaged by what they see here.'' Maps show the location of the New Madrid fault system, which reaches through Kentucky, Missouri, Tennessee and Arkansas. Paducah, Ky., is just 30 miles from its northern end. Memphis, Tenn., lies 25 miles from the southern end. In 1811 and 1812, a series of violent quakes centered in New Madrid, Mo., were felt across much of the eastern United States. They have been estimated at around 8 on the Richter scale - far higher, for example, than last year's San Francisco area quake. There is a 50 percent chance that the area around the New Madrid fault will be hit by an earthquake of at least 6.0 on the Richter scale within the next 10 years, Luman said. There is a 90 percent chance of such a quake within the next 50 years, he said. The museum quotes a Federal Emergency Management Agency study that says a major New Madrid earthquake, 7.6 on the Richter scale, would kill 227 people in the Evansville area if it hit during a school day. More than 1,000 people would be injured and 11,000 would have to leave their homes, the study predicts. Nevertheless, Luman said, the museum tried to get its safety message across while keeping the exhibit's tone light. ``It's not doom and gloom. We're not trying to get too serious,'' Luman said. ``That's why the title is ``Shake, Rattle and Roll.'' It's not ``Live Now, Die Later.'' Visitors walk through a three-room model of a house where the safest areas to go during a quake are marked off. Those include doorways and underneath strong tables. The exhibit also shows how to make homes safer in case of a quake. A quake's destructive potential was not lost on 8-year-old Zach Fussner of Newburgh, who recently viewed the museum's photographs of the Oct. 17 San Francisco earthquake with his mother. ``What's scary about it is am I going to live or what?'' he said. ``What if I die? My house might fall on me.'' Zach said he felt better, however, knowing he should be safer hiding under his desk if a quake strikes.

DOC.HEAD: Magellan Bounces Radar Off Venus as Picture-Making Resumes
DOC.TEXT: The Magellan spacecraft bounced radar off Venus today, trying to make maps of the cloud-covered planet for the first time since the probe was plagued by communications blackouts a month ago. ``We're mapping!'' said Jim Scott, Magellan mission director at the National Aeronautics and Space Administration's Jet Propulsion Laboratory. ``Most people are sighing with relief.'' Magellan started bouncing radar waves off the cloud-covered planet at 9:16 a.m. PDT, he said. The spacecraft is designed to collect the echoes, then send the information to Earth, where they will be assembled into maps and pictures. Confirmation that the radar echoes were collected properly and would result in good pictures was expected later today, Scott said, adding the pictures should be released publicly sometime next week. Engineers lost radio contact with Magellan for 14 hours starting Aug. 16, then for 17{ hours beginning Aug. 21. They still haven't learned the cause of the temporary blackouts, which they have said could happen again. But they gave Magellan new computer instructions so it can recover quickly from future communications breakdowns. Magellan's $744 million mission is designed to produce the most detailed pictures yet of Venus' surface, concealed beneath dense clouds, as well as a global map of the planet. The craft was launched from the space shuttle Atlantis on May 4, 1989, and started orbiting Venus on Aug. 10.

DOC.HEAD: Egypt Restricts Entry of Iraqis, Palestinians
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Egypt, intensifying its campaign against Iraq, said Saturday it has restricted the entry of Iraqis and citizens of countries that support Baghdad and prohibited politicans and journalists from attending a pro-Iraq conference. A senior security officer said the curbs apply to Jordanians, Yemenis, Palestinians and Kuwaitis. Previously, citizens of those countries could get six-month visas automatically on arrival in Egypt, like nationals of other Arab countries. Egypt strongly opposed Saddam Hussein's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait. The Palestine Liberation Organization has backed Saddam, while Jordan and Yemen have been generally sympathetic to him. Under the new regulations, the length of stay in Egypt will be set by entry visas, depending on an applicant's business in the country. The security officer, who spoke on condition he not be named, said the aim of the controls regarding Kuwaitis was to prevent Iraq from sending agents into Egypt with Kuwaiti passports. ``All government departments in Kuwait fell into Iraqi hands after the invasion,'' he said. ``We are afraid that Iraq might try to send Iraqis or non-Kuwaitis into Egypt with what might appear to be genuine Kuwaiti passports.'' In a related move, President Hosni Mubarak's government prevented two Egyptian politicians - Ibrahim Shukry, chairman of the left-of-center Socialist Labor Party, and Mohammed Hamed Abul-Nasr of the fundamentalist Moslem Brotherhood - from traveling to Jordan for a pro-Saddam conference. Two journalists of the leftist National Unionist Progressive Party also said they were not allowed to go. Participants at the conference planned to draw up an Arab peace plan they would propose as an alternative to the multinational force opposing Baghdad.

DOC.HEAD: New Anti-Violence Measures Announced; ANC Says It's Not Enough
LaserPhotos JOH1-6
DOC.TEXT: Police on Saturday announced ``iron fist'' measures intended to halt savage street fighting that has killed almost 800 blacks. But the African National Congress called them too little, too late. The measures include curfews, roadblocks and the deployment of more police and soldiers in black townships plagued by almost five weeks of violence, Maj. Gen. Gerrit Erasmus told a news conference. ANC leader Nelson Mandela has repeatedly called for stronger government action, including use of the military, to quell the unrest. After meeting Friday with President F.W. de Klerk, Mandela accused the government of instigating the fighting and warned of civil war if it continued. ``Mr. Mandela wants an iron fist - we will give an iron fist,'' Erasmus said Saturday. ``Iron Fist'' is the operation's code name. He said razor wire would be placed around migrant worker hostels and squatter camps, flashpoints for much of the fighting. Anyone entering or leaving the compounds would be searched for weapons, Erasmus said. Police vehicles would have machine guns installed on top to protect officers from attacks by blacks with assault rifles, the official said. Police patrols already carry sub-machine guns in addition to shotguns. The government last month sent police and army reinforcements into the townships and imposed emergency regulations. But the violence raged on and has spread into Johannesburg itself. Almost all the fighting occurs at night, when there are virtually no police patrols in the townships. The main combatants are Zulus loyal to the conservative Inkatha movement and Xhosas and other blacks who support Mandela's ANC. Police said Saturday the townships were quiet. However, Associated Press staffers witnessed an unarmed black being stoned, stabbed and then burned to death at a train station in Soweto on Saturday morning. The attackers said they were supporters of the ANC and the victim was a Zulu who backed Inkatha. Mandela told a news conference later Saturday he believed the new police measures would be ``totally ineffective.'' He noted more than 700 blacks had been killed in the fighting since Aug. 12, but the new measures came after attacks in recent days that killed several police officers, including two whites. ``If these two policemen had not died, I can assure you, the government would not have come out with these measure,'' Mandela said. ``It looks like the government is arming itself to deal with the liberation movement,'' he said, adding that other countries used water cannon and tear gas, not live ammunition, to control crowds. Asked who he thought was behind recent attacks on blacks in train stations and townships, Mandela said ``certain state agencies'' were involved. ``The security forces are suspect,'' he said. He gave no indication the ANC intends to reverse its decision last month to suspend its 29-year armed struggle against the government. But he said people have the right to be armed to defend themselves in their homes. Inkatha leader Mangosuthu Buthelezi said Saturday he believes the primary cause of the violence is the ``ANC's decades-long calls on South Africans to kill for political purposes.'' The ANC and Inkatha, the two main black opposition groups, blame each other for the violence. Both oppose apartheid but differ over tactics and plans for a future South Africa. Black leaders also have charged that a secret ``third party'' - possibly right-wing whites - has taken part in attacks on blacks. Right-wing whites have rejected de Klerk's reform efforts and threatened armed struggle against attempts to end white domination in South Africa. De Klerk said Friday that unidentified groups were attempting to sabotage government efforts to end apartheid and draw up a new constitution free of racial discrimination.

DOC.HEAD: Judge Rejects Man's Bid To Freeze Head Before Death
DOC.TEXT: A judge rejected a mathematician's bid to have his head frozen before he dies so that future scientists can find a way to cure a malignant brain tumor and attach his head to a healthy body. Superior Court Judge Ronald Stevens dismissed a petition Friday by Thomas Donaldson for the right to have cryonics technicians freeze his head before he is pronounced legally dead. Stevens said the courts have allowed the terminally ill to refuse medical treatment. But it would mark a ``giant step'' to allow others to freeze Donaldson before he is declared dead, the judge ruled. Assistant Attorney General Kristofer Jorstad said Donaldson can ``put a bullet into his own heart. ... But he can't have people associated with cryonics put that bullet into his heart. That's murder one.'' Donaldson, 46, of Sunnyvale, says he wants his head quick-frozen using a process known as cryonic suspension. The procedure is allowed after death from natural causes. But Donaldson contends that if he waits until then, ``there would be no point in being revived.'' ``Under the current, stupid criteria, my brain could be entirely destroyed before I'm declared dead,'' said Donaldson, a computer consultant to Silicon Valley companies. ``That's why I filed the lawsuit.'' Donaldson said his tumor cannot be surgically removed and has not responded to chemotherapy. According to court papers, it's currently stable and he has a 40 percent chance of living until August 1993. Donaldson has 30 days to amend his suit and resubmit it to the judge. He said he would appeal if it is rejected again. ``If the case goes all the way to the Supreme Court and they turn me down, I'll just starve myself to death. Then I can be frozen before my brain goes and no one can be prosecuted,'' he said. Donaldson said he believes scientists eventually will be able to safely remove the tumor, then use his cells to create another body. ``As I see it, this is the only alternative to death,'' he said. ``I know we don't have all the technology right now, but I think it's entirely possible in the future.''

DOC.HEAD: URGENT
West Germany To Give More Than $2 Billion for Gulf Aid
Precede BONN
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES with Kohl saying aid will amount to 2.1 billion dollars; EDITS throughout; NO pickup
DOC.TEXT: West Germany will provide more than $2 billion in immediate support for the U.S.-led military operations in the Gulf, Chancellor Helmut Kohl said today. Kohl announced the figure of $2.1 billion after talks with U.S. Secretary of State James A. Baker III at the chancellor's home in this town in the southwest of the country. The United States has been pressing West Germany, its richest European ally, to help meet the mounting costs of stationing some 150,000 troops in Saudi Arabia and participating in the naval armada that is enforcing the U.N.-imposed sanctions on Iraq. Before the specific number was made public, Baker had told reporters after a luncheon meeting with West German Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher that, ``We're very pleased with the numbers that were presented at lunch.'' Baker had described them as ``significant and substantial figures.'' West Germany had been sharply criticized in the United States for the small size of its assistance thus far. Genscher said the West German government was determined to help with the enforcement of U.N. sanctions against Iraq. Baker arrived in Bonn this afternoon on the most difficult stop of his latest trip abroad. He was determined to overcome West Germany's sluggish response to helping out in the campaign against Iraq. Baker was bolstered in his talks in West Germany by separate letters from the Pentagon and the State and Treasury departments and a pledge from the Italian government of eight fighter planes and a warship to join the international naval force in the Gulf. U.S. officials said the letters laid out the case for helping to meet the mounting costs of the Gulf effort. Britain on Friday became the first European country to commit ground forces to the Gulf, ordering an armored brigade of 6,000 troops and 120 tanks to Saudi Arabia. And Baker said in Rome that Canada was sending forces to help prevent any additional actions by Iraq, which invaded neighboring Kuwait on Aug. 2. ``All of this taken together, I think, can only send a very clear signal that the international community is united in wanting to see a reversal of this aggression,'' Baker said as he posed for pictures with Italian President Francesco Cossiga. The West German Transport Ministry already has given the United States a list of more than 50 merchant ships that could be used to transport U.S. troops to the gulf. The United States also has made contact with West German civilian airline companies to determine whether planes could be chartered to ferry troops to the Middle East. The West German government, however, says that it is up to the individual companies to decide whether they wish to put the ships and planes at American disposal. Baker last week raised $12 billion from Saudi Arabia, the United Arab Emirates and the overthrown Kuwaiti regime. Syrian President Hafez Assad told Baker in Damascus on Friday that he would send more troops to Saudi Arabia. Syria has sent 3,000 troops there already, and Western sources estimated Assad might send as many as 15,000 more. Japan announced, meanwhile, that it would contribute $4 billion. Other countries have offered lesser amounts or logistical support. But in the meantime, the situation appeared to worsen as Iraqi soldiers swarmed the diplomatic compound of France, Canada and Belgium on Friday in Kuwait.

DOC.HEAD: Dwindling Number of Envoys Hang On In Kuwait
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Three weeks after Iraq ordered embassies in Kuwait to close their doors, governments around the world are pondering the purpose of an embassy and the duty of a diplomat. As of Saturday, 20 embassies - about one-third of the diplomatic missions in the conquered emirate - were still defying the order to shut down. In the sweltering heat of the Persian Gulf, the Iraqi occupiers have steadily stepped up the pressure on the diplomats, surrounding their missions with soldiers and cutting off water, electricity and food supplies. Tensions reached a new high last week when Iraqi troops raided the diplomatic compounds of France, Canada, Belgium and the Netherlands and temporarily detained half a dozen diplomats. France announced Saturday it would dispatch 4,000 more soldiers to the Persian Gulf and expel Iraqi military attaches in Paris in response to the Iraqi raids. Six days after its Aug. 2 invasion, Iraq annexed Kuwait, and subsequently told the embassies they had no further business in the emirate. Kuwait was now an Iraqi state, Baghdad said, and diplomats who chose to stay on would no longer have diplomatic immunity. That was a serious threat in a country where Western civilians have been rounded up and taken to key installations to serve as human shields against potential U.S. attack. Nations which have many citizens trapped in Kuwait have an incentive to stay open as long as possible. But even those diplomats who are doggedly remaining at their posts, behind locked doors, with dwindling supplies and patchy communications, may no longer be able to help anyone. Even so, the principle is important to many governments. They believe closing down their embassies could be interpreted as tacit recognition of the Iraqi rulers. The application of that principle has taken many forms. Some ambassadors have declared that their embassies remain open, but have abandoned their compounds or flown home. At the Swiss embassy, the flag is still flying - and the gardener is in charge. Finland and Turkey pulled their diplomats out of Kuwait early on but said their empty embassies were symbolically open. The Soviet Union evacuated all its citizens and closed the embassy, but said it still maintains diplomatic relations with Kuwait. Norwegian Foreign Ministry spokesman Bjorn Blokhus said it was not worth staying open once the risk to diplomats' safety became too great. But the Norwegian ambassador, whose government ordered him to leave last week, said he could have held out longer. One Western diplomat in Oslo suggested some envoys may have their own reasons for facing down the Iraqi threat. ``Frankly, holding out for two weeks without food or water in terrible heat is a great career booster,'' said the diplomat, who spoke on condition of anonymity. Some envoys, including Dutch Ambassador Joop Veling, have been cautioned not to engage in any exaggerated heroics. But others, including the Egyptians, were told ``to hold out in Kuwait as long as was humanly possible and until conditions became impossible to endure,'' said a Foreign Ministry official in Cairo. That point came last Thursday, when Egypt pulled out its staff. It is difficult for foreign ministry officials to assess misery levels from thousands of miles away. The decision to evacuate is usually taken in consultation with the diplomat in the field. But with telephone lines cut and generators that power shortwave radios wearing down, communication is difficult. Even in embassies where living conditions have been tolerable, the diplomats' lot has been difficult. ``The psychological stress is heavy. Life is monotonous. There is always the chance for trouble,'' said Belgian Foreign Ministry spokesman Johan Verbeke. At the U.S. Embassy, once a posh, palm-shaded compound, food is reported to be scarce, or spoiling. The diplomats have boiled water from the swimming pool to drink, burned furniture for cooking fuel, and slept outside with the bugs to escape the heat. Still, Ambassador W. Nathaniel Howell has been low-key about the hardships. ``It isn't very pleasant,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Support For Servicemen Causes Ribbon Shortage
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: American troops' presence in the Middle East is causing shortages in this southern West Virginia town - ribbon shortages. The Williamson City Council told City Clerk June Blevins to decorate City Hall and a flag pole at the town fire station with yellow bows and red, white and blue ribbon streamers to show support for servicemen in the Middle East. Buying ribbon in Williamson, however, proved to be a difficult assignment, Blevins told the City Counil on Thursday. Dozens of area residents have purchased ribbon for their own displays, and hardly any stores in the Williamson area had ribbon in stock, she said. Many homes, businesses, churches and other buildings throughout the area sport yellow bows or colorful streamers. At least 14 soldiers from the Williamson area have been sent to the Middle East since Iraqi troops invaded Kuwait on Aug. 2, officials said. Blevins said she made an arrangement of ribbons and bows for City Hall. She has promised to make a better arrangement once more ribbon becomes available.

DOC.HEAD: U.S., Allies Discuss Further Steps Against Iraq
DOC.TEXT: The Bush administration said Saturday it was consulting with France and other allies on further possible steps ``to bring home to Iraq the cost of its aggression'' against three embassies in Kuwait. Such steps, under discussion through the United Nations and in President Bush's phone calls to world leaders, included tightening the United Nations-passed economic sanctions, White House spokesman Sean Walsh said. France on Saturday called for an emergency U.N. Security Council meeting to condemn Iraq's invasion Friday of the embassies and to expand the trade embargo against Iraq to include air traffic. France was expected to request a widening of the U.N. trade embargo to block flights to Iraq and punish countries violating the blockade, U.N. officials said. Walsh had no comment on the French initiative. The White House hailed France's dispatch of 4,000 additional troops to the Persian Gulf and its expulsion of Iraqi military attaches from Paris. French President Francois Mitterrand announced the steps Saturday, a day after Iraqi troops stormed his country's diplomatic compound in Kuwait and kidnapped four French citizens. ``We consider such steps appropriate and justified in view of Iraq's continued infringement of diplomatic conventions covering the presence of foreign embassies in Kuwait,'' a White House statement said. ``We continue to consult with France and our other friends on further possible steps to bring home to Iraq the cost of its aggression, including tightening of the sanctions in all possible ways.'' Bush on Friday pledged to support Mitterrand in whatever he decided to do in response to the violation of the embassy compound. The Iraqis released one French citizen, the country's military attache, but three other French citizens remained hostages, Mitterrand said Saturday. As a result, Mitterrand expelled Iraqi military attaches from France and said other Iraqi diplomats would be confined to Paris. Iraqi solders also invaded the embassies of Canada and Belgium on Friday. They did not invade the U.S. Embassy, where Ambassador Nathaniel Howell and a handful of aides held out despite a cutoff of electricity and water. State Department spokesman Mark Dillon said Saturday that their situation remained the same, and there had been no word of any Iraqi moves on the U.S. compound, despite the continuing presence of soldiers outside. The administration, meanwhile, prepared to submit to Congress a request to sell Saudi Arabia $18 billion worth of weapons, including F-15 fighter planes, tanks and other sophisticated arms, according to an official. The administration has already proposed selling Saudi Arabia $3 billion in new weapons to bolster its defenses, including F-15 fighter planes, M-60 tanks, 15,000 rounds of armor-piercing anti-tank ammunition and 200 Stinger anti-aircraft missiles. The official late Friday that the package was not yet finalized, but would result from U.S. analysis of Saudi Arabia's military needs to stand against a potential invasion threat from Iraq's President Saddam Hussein. The expanded package has been under review, but ``no recommendations have come to the White House,'' another administration official said Saturday. The New York Times said in Saturday's editions that the new package includes 24 additional F-15s, as many as 48 Apache helicopters, 385 M-1A2 tanks, 400-500 M-2 Bradley personnel carriers and thousands of trucks and jeeps. The Washington Post said the package would range from $18 billion to $23 billion and also would include Patriot air defense systems, naval command and control systems and thousands of tons of ammunition.

DOC.HEAD: Four Former Followers of Bhagwan Charged With Conspiracy to Murder
DOC.TEXT: Four former disciples of the late Indian guru Bhagwan Shree Rajneesh have been arrested and charged with conspiracy to murder a federal prosecutor several years ago, the Justice Department says. Three of the four were leaders of Rajneesh's 64,000-acre commune in north-central Oregon where Rajneesh presided beginning in 1981. The commune, which became famous for its free-love philosophy, its fleet of Rolls-Royces and its squabbles with longtime residents, collapsed in late 1985 after Rajneesh pleaded guilty to federal immigration charges and was deported. Another top aide served more than two years in jail. Rajneesh died in January in India. The alleged target of the murder conspiracy was U.S. Attorney Charles Turner, the lead prosecutor of Rajneesh. The plot reportedly was thwarted by a power struggle within the commune. The arrests were made over the past week in West Germany, England and South Africa, the Justice Department said Friday in Washington. The four also were charged with illegal interstate transportation of firearms. On Tuesday, a former bodyguard to the guru's personal secretary pleaded guilty to conspiring to murder Turner. Alma Peralta, formerly Ma Dhyan Yogini, was sentenced to two years in prison in exchange for cooperating with federal officials. Attorney General Dick Thornburgh said the arrests followed a five-year investigation. According to court papers filed in Peralta's case, she was recruited in 1985 by Rajneesh's personal secretary, Ma Anand Sheela, to be part of an all-woman assassination squad. Sheela, a native of India, was deported after serving 29 months in federal prison for her role in various criminal activities, including the attempted murder of the guru's doctor. She also pleaded guilty to poisoning several Wasco County officials and to masterminding food poisonings that sickened more than 750 diners at restaurants in The Dalles, the county seat, as part of a plot to gain political control of the county. The commune was home to 4,000 red-clad followers who toiled 12-hour days to feed Rajneesh's dream of a model community and his penchant for jewels and a collection of Rolls-Royces, one of which he drove past his adoring followers each day. The crowd swelled to 15,000 during summer festivals. His views on free love changed after the advent of AIDS. Rajneeshpuram was incorporated as a city on part of the commune in 1982. Disciples also moved into nearby Antelope, a town of 40 people, eventually holding all its elected offices and changing its name to City of Rajneesh. The name was changed back to Antelope in 1985 at Rajneesh's suggestion, as a way to make peace with the angry Oregonians. Those whose arrests were announced Friday were: -Catherine Jane Stubbs, 45, also known as Ma Shanti Bhadra, a native of Australia who was vice president of Rajneesh Medical Corp. and treasurer of Rajneesh Foundation International. She earlier served time in federal prison for trying to kill Rajneesh's physician. -Ann Phyllis McCarthy, 43, also known as Ma Yoga Vidya, a native of South Africa. She was president of the Rajneesh Neo-Sannyas International Commune. -Susan Lissanevitch, 43, also known as Ma Anand Su, a native of England. She was president of Rajneesh Investment Corp. -Richard Kevin Langford, 40, also known as Swami Anugiten, a native of Syracuse, N.Y. He was a member of the Rajneeshpuram Peace Force, or police department. Stubbs and Langford were arrested in West Germany, Lissanevitch was arrested in England, and McCarthy was arrested in South Africa. The Justice Department will try to extradite the four. If convicted, they face a maximum of life in prison.

DOC.HEAD: Meeting Ends In Dispute Over Test Ban
DOC.TEXT: An international conference seeking tighter nuclear export controls ended without a formal accord Saturday after the United States and Mexico disagreed on the issue of atomic weapons tests. Oswaldo de Rivero of Peru, chairman of the meeting reviewing compliance with the 1970 Non-Proliferation Treaty, said Mexico blocked consensus on a final declaration ``which would have contained important advances in the non-proliferation of nuclear weapons.'' Earlier, Mexico appeared ready to drop its call for a halt to nuclear testing by 1995 in return for a commitment by the United States, Britain and the Soviet Union to begin negotiations on a ban, conference sources said. The compromise collapsed when Western countries wanted to insert a reference to ``step-by-step'' negotiations. Mexico apparently saw the phrase as an attempt to water down the pledge by the nuclear powers, said the sources, speaking on condition of anomyity. U.S. policy states testing is needed to ensure the safety and reliability of nuclear weapon stockpiles. U.S. officials also note two of the world's five nuclear weapon powers, France and China, are not members of the treaty organization. The treaty binds states that do not possess nuclear weapons from building or acquiring them. In return, the three nuclear weapon states in the pact - the United States, Britain and the Soviet Union - pledge to work toward nuclear disarmament and to provide non-military atomic technology to other nations. The four-week meeting, attended by about 100 of the the group's 141 member countries, ended early Saturday after unsuccessful negotiations between Mexico, the United States and other nations. Spurred by Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait, delegates agreed Friday on draft measures aimed at strengthening the treaty's ban on the spread of nuclear weapons. Iraq is a member of the group, but has tried to acquire possible nuclear bomb parts. The draft measures were to have been included in a final conference declaration. ``Because there was no final document adopted, the texts which had been negotiated in the conference have no legal status,'' conference spokeswoman Lucy Webster said. Members of the treaty organization meet every five years.

DOC.HEAD: People in the News
LaserPhoto NY44
DOC.TEXT: It's not easy playing second fiddle to the nation's No. 2 man, especially when someone is an ambitious person, says Vice President Dan Quayle's wife, Marilyn. Mrs. Quayle was a straight-A law student at Indiana University and a career-minded woman when she met Quayle 18 years ago. ``I was never going to get married. I was never going to have children,'' The Detroit News quoted her in Saturday's editions. She married Quayle 10 weeks after they met. She certainly didn't envision a full-time career as a spouse, said Mrs. Quayle, who was in Grand Rapids to address the Michigan Bar Association while her husband played golf with the Detroit Pistons' Bill Laimbeer at a Republican fund-raiser. But she has taken on the job with relish. ``I'm one of those people. You take me where I am and I'll do the best job I can, and I'll take every advantage of the situation, every advantage of the moment,'' she said. On Saturday, the vice president and his family were in West Virginia, rafting down one of America's toughest white water rivers, the Gauley River. They were surrounded by Secret Service agents and raft guides. --- LOS ANGELES (AP) - A gathering of rap music artists will star in a Hollywood benefit this week for soul singer Curtis Mayfield, who was paralyzed by an accident at a New York concert last month. The lineup for the Monday night show at the Palace includes Ice-T, Tone Loc, Eazy E, Mellow Man Ace, Kid Frost, C.P.O., King Tee, and Def Jef. Mayfield's original group, the Impressions, wll also appear. Proceeds from the $25 tickets will go to Curtis' family, Capitol Records announced. Most of the show's stars had recorded with Mayfield on his new soundtrack album, ``The Return of Superfly,'' which was released by Capitol on Aug. 21. ``Everyone who performed on the `Return of Superfly' soundtrack donated their talents immediately to come to Curtis' aid in his time of need,'' record company official Tim Devine said in a statement. Mayfield, 48, was about to take the stage at an outdoor concert in Brooklyn Aug. 13 when a gust toppled a light tower, causing critical head and neck injuries. He has since been moved from New York to a spinal care treatment center near his Atlanta home. Mayfield was one of the founders of the Impressions and he composed the best-selling ``Superfly'' soundtrack. --- FRANKLIN, Tenn. (AP) - Country music singer Dottie West, who lost her mansion to foreclosure, says she will be off the premises by Friday. First American National Bank bought the mansion for $800,000 at a foreclosure sale earlier this year. An eviction order was filed in Williamson County General Sessions Court on Aug. 1 when West did not leave the premises. A hearing on the matter was delayed when she filed for bankruptcy protection. West has been beset by financial problems that include an outstanding debt of $110,000 claimed by her former financial manager. She is known for hit records such as ``Every Time Two Fools Collide,'' a duet with Kenny Rogers. --- FINDLAY, Ohio (AP) - The Dalai Lama, Tibet's spiritual leader, will visit this northwestern Ohio city next spring to take part in a ``Year of Tibet'' celebration. The event, sponsored by the University of Findlay and others, is being staged throughout the year to make people more aware of Tibet and its culture. The Dalai Lama will speak March 25 to local high school class presidents on ``Compassion and Leadership,'' said Carole Elchert, a professor at the university. The stopover will be the first on his scheduled spring tour of the United States. The Dalai Lama fled Tibet in the 1950s when it was occupied by China and has since lived in exile in Dharmsala, India. He won the 1989 Nobel Prize for peace for his dedication to nonviolence in his efforts to achieve independence for Tibet.

DOC.HEAD: Magellan Resumes Venus Mapping After Communications Woes
DOC.TEXT: The spacecraft Magellan bombarded Venus with radar Saturday in the first attempt to make pictures of the planet's cloud-shrouded surface since engineers temporarily lost touch with it last month. ``Most people are sighing with relief,'' said Jim Scott, Magellan mission director at the National Aeronautics and Space Administration's Jet Propulsion Laboratory. ``We're just happy to get into the position where we wanted to be.'' Acting on computerized commands radioed 154.9 million miles from Earth, Magellan started bouncing radar off the planet during the morning and engineers received confirmation 13 minutes later, Scott said. NASA's Deep Space Network tracking station at Goldstone, Calif., started receiving data on the radar images, and computers will assemble it into pictures that will be released to the public early this week, said Ed Sherry, technical assistant to Magellan's project manager. ``I'm just delighted. I'm happy as a clam,'' he said. Magellan's $744 million mission is designed to produce the most detailed pictures yet of Venus' surface, totally concealed by clouds, as well as a global map of the planet. It was launched from the space shuttle Atlantis on May 4, 1989, and started orbiting Venus on Aug. 10, after a looping 948 million-mile voyage from Earth. The spacecraft's radar makes pictures 10 times more detailed than those produced by Earth-based radar or radar on the Soviet Venera 15 and 16 spacecraft, which reached Venus in the mid-1980s. Engineers lost radio contact with Magellan for 14 hours starting Aug. 16, then for 17{ hours beginning Aug. 21. They still haven't learned the cause of the temporary blackouts, which they believe could happen again. But they gave Magellan new computer instructions so it can recover quickly from future communications breakdowns. The Aug. 16 blackout happened only hours after Magellan used its radar for its first pictures of Venus during two orbits around the planet. Only 1{ orbits worth of picture information was sent to Earth before contact was lost. Half the remaining picture information was radioed to Earth on Wednesday and the rest was sent back Saturday before mapping resumed, Scott said. The first pictures showed Venus has large flows of solidified lava; pervasive ``Venusquake'' faults; big meteorite impact craters; volcanic cinder cones; large collapsed volcanic craters, called calderas; and parallel mountain ridges and valleys like those in the Great Basin that covers most of Nevada and western Utah. NASA's official position is that Magellan's formal mapping mission won't begin until late this month. But if all goes well through the weekend, officials may decide afterward that the 243-day mapping effort began Saturday, Scott and Sherry said. Venus, the second planet from the sun, rotates once on its axis every 243 Earth days. Magellan circles Venus in a nearly polar orbit, so as Venus revolves beneath it the craft should be able to map 70 percent to 90 percent of the planet during its 243-day mission. NASA, however, has said it expects to use Magellan for additional 243-day cycles so the entire planet can be mapped. Venus is considered Earth's virtual twin in terms of size, mass, density and distance from the sun, although the planet's surface has been heated to 900 degrees Fahrenheit by a runaway ``greenhouse effect.'' Magellan's goal to learn exactly what forces shape Venus, and whether its crust is broken into giant drifting plates like those that carry continents across the face of the Earth. Many scientists believe Venusian crustal movements are predominated by ``hot spots'' - rising subterranean plumes of molten rock like those that created the Hawaiian Islands.

DOC.HEAD: Python that Slithered Down Toilet Last Month Found In Yard
DOC.TEXT: A seven-foot Burmese python that slithered to freedom through a pet store toilet has been found after a month on the loose, somewhat skinnier but no worse for wear. The snake turned up in a yard last week about a mile from Wet Pets, where owner Brent Loewer had been keeping it in hopes of selling the snake for its owner. ``He was kind of thin. He hadn't eaten in a while,'' said Lower. Loewer said he normally keeps the snake in a small cage, but sometimes lets it loose in the store restroom for exercise. About a month ago, he forgot one detail when he let the snake out for its exercise slither: ``He loves water and I left the toilet open.'' When he returned, the snake was long gone. Every few days, he said, city employees checked a manhole outside the store, but didn't find the snake in the sewer. He said he'd given up hope of ever finding the snake when a woman walked into the store and asked what a big snake would eat. It turned out that the snake came out of hiding when a neighbor began mowing his lawn Tuesday. Apparently afraid of the noise, the snake headed up a tree in his yard. Loewer said the neighbor ran to his garage and grabbed a hatchet, but the woman's husband stopped him from killing it, got the snake out of the tree and sent his wife to the store to find out what to feed it. When she described the snake, he said, he realized it could be the python. He showed the couple photographs of the snake that had been taken by its owner, and the couple returned the snake. Loewer said the snake is about 2 years old and isn't fully grown.

DOC.HEAD: Father Who Torched Son Denies He Violated Parole
DOC.TEXT: The man convicted of torching his 6-year-old son in a motel room denied he violated his parole this week by ducking out of an Oakland doughnut shop to elude a corrections agent. Charles Rothenberg said he was looking for a job and did not violate conditions of his parole when he disappeared for four hours on Monday. ``I now believe I've been set up!'' Rothenberg said in a letter to the Los Angeles Times. ``The parole agent told me he would assist with employment. He's taken too long, gone on four vacations, had a face lift, gone to golf games, and I sit doing nothing,'' Rothenberg wrote from his cell at San Quentin state prison, where he awaits a hearing on the alleged parole violation. The Times said it received the letter Friday. Excerpts were published in Saturday's editions. ``My parole conditions state I can go anywhere I want in Alameda County from 6 a.m. to 10 p.m. It's as clear as daylight,'' said Rothenberg, 50. Corrections officials could not be reached Friday for comment and did not immediately return a phone call Saturday from The Associated Press. Rothenberg set fire to his son, David, in a Buena Park motel room in March 1983 after a telephone argument in which his estranged wife said he would not be allowed to see the boy again. The child lived with his mother in New York and had been vacationing with Rothenberg in California. David, dragged from the inferno by motel guests, suffered third-degree burns over 90 percent of his body. Now 14, he lives with his mother and stepfather in Southern California and said he was happy his father was back in jail. Rothenberg was convicted of attempted murder, arson and other charges and received a 13-year prison term. After serving about half that, he was released in January for good behavior and placed on three years' parole. Under terms of the parole, he was watched around-the-clock and wore an electronic anklet so his whereabouts could be monitored. State Corrections Department spokesman Tipton C. Kindel said that Rothenberg went with a parole agent to a job interview in Oakland on Monday, only to find the business closed. The agent allowed him to wait inside a doughnut shop. Kindel said Rotherberg left through a side or back door and called a second agent to say he was at another job interview. That agent told Rothenberg to stay put but he left again, Kindel said. Agents found him about four hours later and he was returned to prison, Kindel said. In the letter to the newspaper, Rothenberg did not address the allegations he eluded the parole agents. If convicted of the parole violation, Rothenberg could face a maximum six months in jail.

DOC.HEAD: Palestinian Radicals Attend Leftist Conference in Amman
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Two Marxist Palestinians who were banned from Jordan for 20 years were greeted by loud applause as a conference of leftist and Islamic groups convened Saturday to demonstrate solidarity with Saddam Hussein. The participation of George Habash and Nayef Hawatmeh underscored a growing alliance between Iraq and radical Arab factions that is alarming Western officials. Habash is leader of the Popular Front for the Liberation of Palestine, and Nayef Hawatmeh heads the Democratic Front for the Liberation of Palestine. Habash and other Palestinian leaders were kicked out of Jordan after the 1970 civil war pitting PLO rebels against the Jordanian army. The war started when Habash's guerrillas hijacked three jetliners and blew them up in the Jordanian desert. Habash was welcomed back at the start of a three-day conference of Arab leftists and Islamic activists sympathetic to Iraq who demand that the U.S.-led multinational force leave the Persian Gulf region. Jordan's King Hussein, considered a U.S. ally, has been inclining toward his powerful neighbor Saddam since Iraq invaded Kuwait Aug. 2. The king has said he opposes the occupation of Kuwait but wants an Arab solution of the crisis. In his speech Saturday, Habash urged Washington to avoid double standards in dealing with Iraq's invasion and Israel's occupation of Arab territories. ``We reject the U.S. principle of selectivity in dealing with the U.N. Security Council resolutions,'' Habash said, in a speech marked by ovations from the audience of about 150 delegates. Shortly after the invasion, Saddam said he would contemplate leaving Kuwait only if U.N. resolutions calling for Israel's withdrawal from occupied lands were implemented at the same time. Israel seized the West Bank, Gaza Strip, and the Golan Heights in 1967, and has held a border strip in south Lebanon since 1982. Saddam's declaration threw many Palestinian leaders into his camp. Habash, who had been based in Syria, recently moved his headquarters to Baghdad. Suleiman Arar, speaker of Jordan's House of Representatives, warned against the formation of a U.S.-led alliance in the Gulf. ``The sole successful solution lies in the Arab context without foreign pressures,'' he said. The three-day conference, patronized by the Jordanian monarch, is being held under the slogan of ``expressing solidarity with Iraq in its confrontation of the imperialist offensive in the Gulf.'' The delegates represent about 20 parties and political groups from Morocco, Tunisia, Algeria, Libya, Sudan, Mauritania, Yemen, Lebanon, Syria, Jordan, Iraq, and the PLO. Egyptian opposition parliament members planned to attend but were barred from traveling to Jordan by the government of President Hosni Mubarak, which has sent forces to Saudi Arabia to oppose Iraq. Hawatmeh took a more moderate stance than Habash during a news conference Friday. But he made clear that Palestinians would support Iraq against Western aggression. ``We say to the aggressors: Hands off the gulf region. If an aggression takes place, all of us will side with Iraq,'' Hawatmeh said. He implicitly supported Iraq's withdrawal from Kuwait, however, when he said, ``A solution to the gulf crisis should depend on allowing the right to self-determination to all peoples of the region.''

DOC.HEAD: Reagan Visits Solidarity's Birthplace, Heads to Soviet Union
DOC.NOTE: With LaserPhoto GDA50
DOC.TEXT: Former President Reagan honored the birthplace of Solidarity on Saturday as the ``shipyard that launched a half dozen revolutions'' and met with Lech Walesa, the labor movement's founder. ``It is a thrill for me to be here at the place where Poland's history has been changed forever,'' Reagan told a cheering crowd after laying flowers at the Solidarity monument in this Baltic port, about 180 miles northwest of Warsaw. Reagan, standing next to Walesa, praised the movement's achievements during its nearly 10-year struggle to free the nation from ``communism's stifling embrace.'' ``You have triggered vast changes in the political map of Central and Eastern Europe,'' he told more than 3,000 people outside the main gate of the shipyard where Solidarity was established in 1980. ``One might say this is the shipyard that launched a half dozen revolutions,'' said Reagan, who later went to the Soviet Union as part of a 10-day European trip. Walesa thanked Reagan and the American people for their support of Solidarity, which now controls the government. ``Your position, firmness and consistency meant hope and help for us in the most difficult moments,'' the Solidarity chairman said as the crowd chanted ``Reagan, Reagan.'' After the rally, Reagan and Walesa met privately for about 30 minutes. Reagan made a brief visit to St. Brygida's church, Solidarity's spiritual shrine, and then flew with his wife, Nancy, to the Soviet city of Leningrad. His five-day Soviet visit is scheduled to include talks with Soviet President Mikhail Gorbachev and a speech to members of the Supreme Soviet parliament on Monday, the Tass news agency said. Reagan addressed Poland's Parliament on Friday. He also met with Prime Minister Tadeusz Mazowiecki and President Wojciech Jaruzelski, the army general and former Communist Party leader who last year agreed to turn over the government to Solidarity. Reagan imposed strict sanctions on Poland's Communist regime after Jaruzelski declared martial law in 1981. Many current political leaders credit the sanctions with helping pressure the government into democratic concessions. Reagan's visit to Poland was organized by Project Hope, a charitable organization that runs a children's hospital in Krakow in southern Poland. Reagan arrived in Poland from Berlin, where he chipped at the remnants of the Berlin Wall. He is scheduled to visit Italy after leaving the Soviet Union.

DOC.HEAD: Writer Marya Mannes Dead at 85
DOC.TEXT: Marya Mannes, an outspoken author of several books who also wrote extensively for such publications as the New Yorker and The Reporter, has died at the age of 85. Mannes, who lived most of her life in New York, died Thursday at Laguna Honda Hospital, a geriatric facility. The versatile writer was a social critic and a critic of radio, television and theater. She also wrote satirical verse. Her books included ```Out of My Time,'' an autobiography that was published in 1971, and two novels: ``Message from a Stranger'' in 1948 and ``They'' in 1968. She worked as a staff writer for The Reporter magazine from 1952 to 1963, writing articles, essays and reviews. She also wrote for McCalls and The New York Times. She is survived by a son, David R.J. Blow.

DOC.HEAD: Government Troops Seek Control of Hospital in Rebel-Held Area
DOC.TEXT: Government troops advanced through booby-trapped buildings and mined streets Saturday, seeking to capture an abandoned hospital and gain a strategic edge in war-ravaged Jaffna, military officials said. The hospital is in the center of the rebel-held town and about a mile from Jaffna Fort, controlled by government troops that claim they defeated Tamil separatist guerrillas Thursday to end a three-month siege. The government, meanwhile, warned citizens of possible attack by Tamil forces in the northern Jaffna region, most of which is controlled by the rebels. ``Due to the success of the security forces in the Jaffna Peninsula, the (Tamil Tigers) heirarchy has instructed its cadres to attack civilians,'' said a defense ministry statement issued Saturday. Military officials did not say how far their men had advanced toward the hospital. But a senior officer said troops were under constant rebel fire and progress was slow because of mines buried in the streets and booby traps hidden in buildings along the way. Control of the hospital would give the Sinhalese-dominated government a major base in the town of 60,000 people and, more importantly, a chance to win support among residents by resuming medical services. The overwhelmingly Tamil town 185 miles northeast of the capital city of Colombo has been a rebel stronghold since the separatist war against Sri Lanka's Sinhalese majority began in 1983.
