But recent battles in the area and the rebel's strong-arm tactics of soliciting funds has sapped enthusiasm for the guerrilla cause in Jaffna, recent visitors to the town reported. At least 14,000 people have been killed in the civil war. The government says 25 soldiers have been killed and at least 136 wounded since the siege on the 17th century fort was broken Thursday. It claims more than 100 Tamil rebels have died. The Tamil office in London, however, denied the siege had been broken. The rebels also claimed they downed a government plane with a Soviet-made SAM-7 missile. The government acknowleged a single-engine ground-attack plane crashed in Jaffna Lagoon on Thursday, but it said the pilot ditched the Italian-made Marchetti aircraft when he could not pull out of a dive after attacking a rebel gun position. The pilot was reported missing. Military officials, who spoke on condition of anonymity, also accused the rebels of killing eight unarmed Moslem civilians, including four children, in eastern Sri Lanka Thursday night and Friday. Four guerrillas were killed in clashes with government troops in the region, the officials said. The rebels seek political autonomy or independence for the Tamil minority, claiming Sinhalese discrimination in jobs, education and use of the Sinhala language. The Sinhalese, who comprise 75 percent of the nation's 16 million people, control the government and the military. Tamils account for 18 percent of the people and live mostly in the northern and eastern sections of the island nation. Moslems make up 7 percent of the population.

DOC.HEAD: Disagreement Over Aid for Least-Developed Nations
DOC.TEXT: The world's 41 poorest nations received pledges of solidarity but little else Saturday following a two-week United Nations conference on development. The United States, Japan and Soviet Union refused to set aside a portion of their gross national products to help the developing countries as negotiations ended late Friday, participants said. The poor countries had asked that developed nations devote .2 percent of their gross national products to public development aid. French Foreign Minister Roland Dumas closed the conference with a plea to help the poorest nations break out of a ``vicious cycle of misery.'' Nations represented at the conference also disagreed over some points of an assistance plan, including a proposal for industrialized nations to join in helping Third World nations reduce debt. Some conference participants also proposed linking progress in human rights and political reform with aid and debt relief. Jan Pronk, cooperation minister of the Netherlands, promised to propose a plan to cancel all public debt owed by the poorest nations at the next meeting of the International Monetary Fund in Washington.

DOC.HEAD: Italian Minister: Gorbachev Offers to Restore Ties with Israel
DOC.TEXT: Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev is ready to restore diplomatic relations with Israel after a 23-year gap if Israel agrees to participate in an international peace conference, Italy's foreign minister said Saturday. Israel's Prime Minister Yitzhak Shamir has made it clear that Israel would only consider taking part in an international conference limited to the Persian Gulf crisis. Foreign Minister Gianni de Michelis met with Gorbachev a day after the Soviet president met with Israel's finance and science ministers. That meeting Friday was the first between a Soviet leader and Israeli Cabinet ministers since the nations broke diplomatic relations in 1967. ``President Gorbachev told me about the Soviet side's readiness to recognize Israel immediately if it agrees to participate in an international conference that would determine rules and principles for security and cooperation in the region,'' said de Michelis, whose country holds the presidency of the European Community. On Sept. 4, the Soviets proposed an international conference to discuss the Persian Gulf, the Arab-Israeli dispute and the Lebanese civil war. At the time, Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze said the Soviet Union ``might take a fresh look at the issue of Soviet-Israeli relations'' if the Jewish state agreed to participate. Israel has long opposed Soviet-backed ideas for an international conference over the Palestinian conflict, fearing such a wide forum would try to force Israel to concede territory to the Arabs. Gorbachev met in the Kremlin Friday with Finance Minister Yitzhak Modai and Science Minister Yuval Neeman, who were in Moscow discussing a trade deal. The meeting was not announced beforehand. Neeman said Saturday in Jerusalem that Gorbachev's warm reception of the Israeli ministers set the stage for establishing diplomatic relations. ``We are bringing home a new atmosphere,'' he said on Israel radio, adding that Israeli-Soviet relations had been ``raised to a new level, that, I assume is the last before complete relations.'' Israeli Foreign Minister David Levy and Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze are expected to meet later this month during the U.N. General Assembly in New York. Levy has said he hoped that full diplomatic relations between the two countries would be restored soon. The Soviet Union for years was hostile to Israel, supported the Palestine Liberation Organization and shipped arms to militant Arab states, including Iraq. It cut off arms supplies to Iraq the day after it invaded Kuwait. The two Israeli ministers reportedly discussed plans to build a Soviet-U.S.-Israeli passenger plane and a proposal to send Israeli produce to the Moscow area. Modai belongs to Shamir's right-wing Likud bloc. Neeman, a nuclear scientist and longtime head of Israel's space agency, leads the ultra-rightist Tehiya Party.

DOC.HEAD: PRECEDE Oggersheim, West Germany
Germans To Provide Nearly $2 Billion in Aid for Persian Gulf Effort
DOC.NOTE: EDS: New throughout to UPDATE figures, details, quotes. No pickup. ^By BARRY SCHWEID
DOC.TEXT: Chancellor Helmut Kohl on Saturday extended nearly $2 billion in economic and military aid to the drive led by the United States against Iraqi President Saddam Hussein. The action, announced outside his country home in the Rhineland after a 90-minute meeting with Secretary of State James A. Baker III, overrode the hesitation West Germany had shown to more than nominal participation in the U.S.-led Persian Gulf campaign. ``We are aware of our responsibility,'' Kohl said. ``We are ready and willing to do our share.'' Apart from the $1.87 billion Kohl pledged to the United States and to poor nations, West Germany is contributing $271 million as part of an aid package approved by the 12-nation European Community. There was no indication that West Germany would contribute to the military force assembled in the gulf to guard oil fields in Saudi Arabia against an Iraqi takeover and to police the economic embargo of Iraq authorized Aug. 6 by the United Nations Security Council. Still, the German contribution marked a turnabout and reflected the growing confidence of a nation, already the richest in Europe, that will grow more power after unification. About half the German aid will go this year to the United States to help defray the staggering cost of stationing troops in Saudi Arabia and deploying a naval armada in the Persian Gulf. The other half, Kohl said, will go to poor nations battered by the crisis. Kohl singled out Jordan, Egypt and Turkey. The chancellor said the West German constitution, which he hopes parliament will change after unification with East Germany, prohibits sending troops and warships to the gulf. But he said the forces there ``are also defending our interests.'' Asked if Iraq could be compelled to relinquish its control of Kuwait short of war, the German leader said: ``I hope so. I am no prophet.'' He said Iraq, which invaded the smaller oil-rich gulf country Aug. 2, ``has to acknowledge the largest share of the world community is against it.'' With tears in his eyes, Kohl thanked the United States for helping to fulfill the German dream of unification, which will occur Oct. 3. Baker said as Germany becomes larger and greater its responsibilities grow. ``No one could draw any conclusion but that Germany is doing more,'' he said. ``They go far beyond what we had discussed through private channels - and substantially.'' In all, Baker raised nearly $14 billion during his 11-day trip, which ended with his flight back to Washington from West Germany. Three oil-rich Arab countries - Saudi Arabia, the United Arab Emirates and the Kuwaiti monarchy overthrown by Iraq - volunteered $12 billion after talking to Baker last week. About half will offset U.S. expenses, which will total about $9 billion by the end of the year, and the other half will go to poor countries. ``I think that the trip has been very successful in terms of pointing up the isolation of Iraq,'' Baker said. The West German assistance includes $636 million in radio equipment, cranes, generators and equipment to protect U.S. soldiers against chemical weapons. About 60 armored vehicles worth $127 million are designed to detect chemical weapons. About $254 million will go toward transportation costs. Egypt will receive about $650 million in aid; about $135 million will go to Jordan, which is saddled with caring for thousands of refugees from Iraq and Kuwait; and about $75 million is for Turkey, a NATO member which has lost the revenues of an Iraqi pipeline that ran through the country and was closed at the start of the crisis. Kohl said the Turks also will receive from Germany ``some defense materiel,'' for which he did not offer a pricetag. ``I was very pleased by the numbers that were presented to us,'' Baker said after West German Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher outlined the assistance earlier over lunch at Petersberg, a new government guest house in the hills outside Bonn. Baker called the sums ``very significant and very substantial.'' He later confirmed the offer with Kohl at his country home near Heidelberg. Until Baker's visit, West Germany had offered $65 million in technical aid to the U.S. forces in Saudi Arabia. But the high cost of unification with East Germany - $7.7 billion to the Soviet Union alone to compensate for the withdrawal of 370,000 Soviet troops - stoo in the way of a larger contribution. West Germany imports negligible amounts of oil from the gulf, getting most of its supplies from Norway and Britain. Still, considering its wealth and world power status, the Germans' distance from the U.S.-led campaign against Hussein raised eyebrows in Congress. Italy volunteered a squadron of Tornadoes during Baker's visit to Rome while Egypt and Syria said they would send more troops to Saudi Arabia. Two countries Baker did not visit - Britain and France - said they would send more troops, and Canada joined the international force with a squadron of 12 CF-18 jets to fly cover for three Canadian warships en route. France is sending 4,000 soldiers, including an 1,100-man helicopter regiment, 48 tanks and a squadron of 30 warplanes and 48 helicopters. Britain is contributing an additional 6,000 combat troops and 120 tanks.

DOC.HEAD: Report: Defense Minister Had Links to Secret Police
DOC.TEXT: Three East German government ministers, including Defense Minister Rainer Eppelmann, are suspected by investigators of having cooperated with the former Communist secret police, an East Berlin newspaper reported Saturday. Eppelmann said the allegations were ``totally made up,'' according to the East German news agency ADN. The Berliner Zeitung said Eppelmann, along with Construction Minister Axel Viehweger and former Economics Minister Gerhard Pohl, were also on a list of suspected former agents for the secret police, or Stasi. The list of names was compiled by a committee set up by Parliament to conduct a probe into whether any lawmakers might have been Stasi agents. Officials overseeing the dismantling of the Stasi have said that three government ministers and 68 deputies in the 400-member Volkskammer, or Parliament, are suspected of having been secret police agents. Their names had not been published until Saturday's report in the Berliner Zeitung, which did not say how it obtained the list. Prime Minister Lothar de Maiziere said the government will investigate the latest allegations. Eppelmann, a Lutheran pastor, often sheltered dissidents during the Communist regime and played a leading role in the popular movement that brought down the Communist government last year. He later helped found a small conservative party, the Democratic Awakening, and became minister of defense and disarmament in East Germany's first democratically elected government in April. De Maiziere's government has been rocked by growing allegations that members of his Cabinet and many legislators have past Stasi links. The issue has overshadowed preparations for German unification on Oct. 3, when de Maiziere's government will turn over control of the economically troubled country to the West German government. A fourth Cabinet member, Environment Minister Karl-Hermann Steinberg, also has been named as a suspected former Stasi agent. Meanwhile, Interior Minister Peter-Michael Diestel came under more fire Saturday when an official charged that Diestel has been hindering and delaying the purge of Stasi agents. De Maiziere's spokeswoman, Angela Merkel, said Friday that Diestel had been stripped of the job of dismantling the Stasi apparatus. However, de Maiziere said Saturday that Diestel will remain the top official in charge of the operation, although his deputy Eberhard Stief was given the job of directly supervising the process. On Thursday, Diestel survived a parliamentary motion for his ouster from office.

DOC.HEAD: Civil Rights Official Althea Simmons Dies
DOC.TEXT: Althea T.L. Simmons, head of the Washington office of the National Association for the Advancement of Colored People, has died here. She was 66. The veteran civil rights worker, who had served as the group's chief lobbyist since 1979, died Thursday of respiratory failure following hip surgery. She played a role in shaping a number of civil rights bills on Capitol Hill and was known for keeping a sharp eye on lawmakers and policymakers. Miss Simmons joined the NAACP in the mid-1950s and at one time was associate director of branch and field services in the organization's New York headquarters. A native of Shreveport, La., she was a graduate of Southern University, held a law degree from Howard University and also studied marketing at the University of Illinois.

DOC.HEAD: Israeli Defense Minister To Visit Washington To Push For More Aid
DOC.TEXT: Defense Minister Moshe Arens headed for Washington Saturday to meet with Defense Secretary Dick Cheney, and Israeli media said he would seek more military aid in light of the Persian Gulf crisis. The daily newspaper Al Hamishmar said Arens would ask for U.S. funding of a naval submarine project and discuss the U.S. contribution to the joint Arrow missile project. Washington provided 80 percent of the $158 million in the first phase of the missile project and has agreed to continue funding, but exact amounts have not yet been set. Israel radio said Arens would also ask the Bush administration to forgive a $4.6 billion debt. Bush said he would ask Congress to waive a $6.7 billion Egyptian debt, after Egypt sent troops to the gulf as part of the multinational force facing Iraq. A report in The Washington Post Saturday said Arens would also ask Cheney to consider providing Israel with ``real-time'' links to U.S. spy satellites. Such links would allow Israel to target Iraqi military sites and chemical weapon facilities on short notice. Dan Naveh, Arens' spokesman, confirmed the Israeli defense minister would meet Cheney on Monday but declined comment on both the Washington Post report and on the agenda. ``There are many issues on the table but I do not want to go into them,'' Naveh said. According to the daily newspaper Maariv, Israel has already requested speedy delivery of Apache attack helicopters, additional F-15 and F-16 fighter planes as well as two Patriot anti-ballistic missile systems. In an interview on Israel radio last week, Arens said the dangers faced by Israel in view of Iraq's invasion of Kuwait warranted more American aid. Arens said he belived Washington now had ``a more realistic view of the the dangers confronted by Israel,'' adding: ``I hope that it will also express itself in additional aid.'' The supply of U.S. weapons to Arab states hostile to Israel is also causing concern. President Bush has asked Congress to approve an $18-billion weapons sale to Saudi Arabia. Naveh said in a telephone interview that with Western arms available to Arabs, Israel must develop its own high-technology weapons systems such as the Arrow missile.

DOC.HEAD: Defense Minister Says 178 Iraqis Training in Soviet Union
DOC.TEXT: Defense Minister Dmitry Yazov said Saturday that 178 Iraqi servicemen are being trained in the Soviet Union under contracts that expire in November. Yazov also told the Moscow Pravda newspaper that 149 Soviet miitary experts are training Saddam Hussein's soldiers in Iraq. The number previously had been reported as 190. Of the 178 Iraqis in the Soviet Union, 77 were in Latvia, with the rest in Vladivostok and at the port of Poti, in Soviet Georgia, Yazov said. All are ``due to go back in November when the training program is completed,'' Yazov said. On Thursday, the presidium of Latvia's parliament passed a resolution protesting the training of Iraqi troops at the Soviet Navy Training Center in the Baltic port of Riga. Yazov said the military exchanges were the product of bilateral agreements between the countries. ``They cannot just be torn up,'' he said. The Soviet Union, once Iraq's main military supplier, suspended arms shipments after Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion of Kuwait.

DOC.HEAD: Asian Refugees From Kuwait Board Sri Lanka-Bound Ship
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: After days of waiting in the hot sun of the Jordanian desert, nearly 2,000 Sri Lnakans boarded a passenger ship Saturday for a 10-day trip home that started off with a meal of hot curry. The voyage augmented a 10-day airlift organized by the U.N. International Organization for Migration for tens of thousands of penniless Asians who fled Kuwait after Iraq's Aug. 2 invasion. The group is hoping to charter more ships as a slightly less expensive way of moving the refugees. The voyage of the Sri Lankans was costing about $780,000, said Yahya Maroufi, an agency official. The 1,767 Sri Lankans arrived in Aqaba in a convoy of 41 buses that had picked them up in Amman. The Pakistani ship Safina-E-Arab was starting its voyage Saturday night. Women in colorful saris and men in loincloths balanced bundles and suitcases on their heads as they clambered up the gangway. ``We left Kuwait three weeks ago and have spent three terrible weeks in desert camps. Now, at last, we are on the way home,'' said Mohammed Maizer, a young man from Colombo who was accompanied by his wife. Some were grieved by a traffic accident overnight on the Amman-Aqaba road that killed 10 Sri Lankans. Jordanian officials said it was the worst accident suffered by any of the 600,000 Arab and Asian refugees who have passed through the kingdom in the past six weeks. Arab refugees for the most part have been repatriated quickly. But some of the 80,000 Bangladeshis, Indians, Pakistanis, Filipinos, Sri Lankana and Thais have spent up to three weeks waiting for transportation. The Sri Lankans boarding the ship were informed by loudspeaker as soon as they boarded that a hot curry meal was awaiting them in the dining room. Just down the coast from Aqaba, 800 Sudanese have been stranded for two to three weeks waiting for their government to arrange transportation home. ``We cannot do anything for them until the Sudanese government asks us to help,'' said Maroufi. Maroufi said his agency so far had arranged transportation home for 15,000 refugees, including those aboard the Pakistani ship. ``We hope that the number will increase to 35,000-40,000 by next Saturday,'' he said, estimating the costs to rise by then to $25-30 million.

DOC.HEAD: Jordanian Children Plead for World Peace
With AM-Gulf Rdp, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Jordanian schoolchildren have written letters pleading with world leaders to find a peaceful solution to the Persian Gulf crisis. ``Please ... stop the war because I don't want to die, me and my family and my dogs and cats,'' read one letter to U.N. Secretary-General Javier Perez de Cuellar. ``If there is a war, I will be scared.'' The letter from third-grader Ammar Qweider was one of dozens on display at a downtown hotel. The letters were organized by a women's group called Children's Letters for Peace Committee, which asked children in Amman and a major suburb to write them prior to Perez de Cuellar's peace mission in Amman earlier this month. The letters were accompanied by collages and drawings depicting scenes such as bombings and, in stark contrast, fanciful pastoral settings. Many pictured children killed by war. One drawing showed two globes. One, labeled ``war'' in red print, had horns, an angry snarl and a knife in its side with drops of blood coming from it. The other, labeled ``peace,'' showed a smiling, bright-eyed world. ``Please world leaders, I ask you to sort this out before someone makes a rash decision and pushes the little button that can ruin the world,'' read another letter by Dina Tinam. Not surprisingly, many of the letters struck a sympathetic chord with Iraq and the Arab world in general. ``I'm sorry to inform you that the decision you took against Iraq was a bit unfair,'' said Rami Bisher. ``There was no need for any military action. The blockade itself was enough, 'cause I'm sure there are some kids in Iraq suffering from the shortage of milk and other goods.'' Angie Hussanni wrote: ``Please tell Mr. George Bush that the Arabs are not that bad. We are a civilized nation. Once upon a time we were the best, and I can assure you we will be the best again sometime in the future.'' ``Please talk not fight,'' wrote fourth-grader Aboud Nasser. ``If there will be a war I will never get the chance to grow up and become an architect. Just give me and my friends a chance to make the world a better place.'' The Amman talks between Perez de Cuellar and Iraqi Foreign Minister Tariq Aziz ended without progress as the diplomats were unable to agree on an Iraqi withdrawal from Kuwait, which Saddam Hussein's troops overran Aug. 2.

DOC.HEAD: Thousands of Mourners Gather at Funeral for Slain Albanians
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of mourners, some traveling on trucks and tractors, gathered Saturday for the funerals of two ethnic Albanians killed in a gunbattle with police, the official news agency Tanjug reported. The two men killed Thursday are among at least 64 ethnic Albanians who have died in unrest in the southern Kosovo province since Serbian authorities clamped down on the province's autonomy in March 1989. Posters around the province urged attendance at the funerals, which drew between 5,000 and 6,000 people to the tiny village of Palatna, about 18 miles north of the provincal capital of Pristina, the news agency reported. Extra police units were posted at surrounding villages, but the mourners dispersed peacefully following religious and political speeches. The men died in gunfire after police raided the village looking for arms and foreign currency. Two policemen were injured in the shootout. Early Friday, two other ethnic Albanians were shot and killed by police at a roadblock, Tanjug reported. Serbia, which administers Kosovo and regards it as the heartland of its medieval kingdom, dissolved the province's parliament in July after ethnic Albanian delegates declared sovereignty. Albanian-language newspapers were closed and radio and television stations were seized. Serbian officials claimed the measures were needed to protect the Slav minority in Kosovo from harassment by the ethnic Albanians, who make up about 90 percent of the province's 1.9 million inhabitants. Serb authorities on Friday detained several ousted ethnic Albanian political leaders on charges they met in secret Sept. 7 to adopt a constitution and proclaim the province Yugoslavia's seventh republic, media reports said.

DOC.HEAD: Memorial Dedicated For Church Bombing Victims On Anniversary
DOC.TEXT: Twenty-seven years ago, four black girls attending church on a Sunday morning died in a racist bombing that tore at the conscience of Birmingham. On Saturday, at an ill-kept hillside cemetery where three of the girls are buried, several dozen people, whites and blacks, gathered in sweltering heat to remember them as martyrs for social change. The group also dedicated a state historic marker in honor of the four and called for the restoration of the nearly abandoned Greenwood Cemetery in downtown Birmingham. The girls - Addie Mae Collins, Carol Robertson and Cynthia Wesley, all 14, and Denise McNair, 11 - died when a dynamite bomb exploded in a stairwell of the Sixteenth Street Baptist Church on Sept. 15, 1963. The church bombing stunned the civil rights movement and broke down resistance among many whites who were shocked by such violence against children in a house of worship. ``They forever changed the face of this state and the history of this state,'' said state Sen. Roger Bedford. ``Their deaths made all of us focus on the ugliness of those who would punish people because of the color of their skin.'' ``They died so freedom could live,'' said Kenneth Mullinax, who spearheaded the drive for a state historic marker and for a grave marker for Addie Mae Collins. Robert Edward Chambliss, a white man linked to racist resistance, was convicted of murder in the bombing and sentenced to life in prison. He died in 1985 at age 81. Besides remembering the girls' short lives, participants Saturday called for help restoring the cemetery where three of the girls are buried. Denise McNair is buried in Shadowlawn Cemetery. Rev. Fred Shuttlesworth, a black leader in Birmingham during the civil rights movement, said the bombing ``shook Birmingham. It shook the world, in fact.'' Among those affected was then-governor George Wallace, said his son, State Treasurer George Wallace Jr. Until the bombing, the governor was an outspoken segregationist. But Wallace Jr. said his father was ``shaken by the deaths'' and condemned those responsible. ``He agonized over it.'' The four-term governor later voiced racially moderate views and won strng black support in his final victory in 1982. Mullinax, who worked in the last Wallace administration, said he was angry about the condition of the cemetery. The grave of Addie Mae Collins had been marked only by a thin piece of wood, with the writing on it worn off. Mullinax and other donors bought a marker for the child's grave. Two of Collins' sisters attended the ceremony, but did not speak during it and declined to talk to reporters later. Wilheminia Anchrum earlier organized a drive to clean up the cemetery, which once was an elite black cemetery in segregated Birmingham but fell into bankruptcy and neglect in recent years. Graves have been dug up and markers turned over. Anchrum and other volunteers cleaned up part of the cemetery for the memorial Saturday and are raising money to establish a permanent maintenance program.

DOC.HEAD: Hearings Begin On Charges Against Bhutto
DOC.TEXT: A tribunal on Saturday began reviewing corruption charges against ousted Prime Minister Benazir Bhutto in what her followers have characterized as a political witch hunt. President Ghulam Ishaq Khan, a conservative, dismissed Ms. Bhutto and her government on Aug. 6. Last week, an army-backed caretaker government filed four corruption charges against the 37-year-old former prime minister. Several of Ms. Bhutto's Cabinet ministers face similar changes, and hundreds of supporters of her Pakistan People's Party have been arrested. The special tribunal was set up to try corruption cases and determine whether Ms. Bhutto and her allies will be able to run in a new election scheduled for Oct. 24. If convicted, Ms. Bhutto would be disqualified from elections for up to seven years. Criminal charges could follow. The special tribunals originally were created in 1977 to try Ms. Bhutto's father, Prime Minister Zulfikar Ali Bhutto, who was overthrown in a military coup and hanged two years later. The caretaker government has promised that many of Ms. Bhutto's political opponents also would be investigated for corruption. But so far the only inquirites have been into Ms. Bhutto's government, elected in November 1988. Pakistani politicians, speaking on condition of anonymity, said the trials were bolstering Ms. Bhutto's image as a martyr, like her father. They predicted the trials ultimately would fail unless they were broadened to include her opponents. ``There is a feeling among many Pakistanis that this has not been very fair so far,'' said a member of the Senate for the right-wing coalition, known by its Urdu initials IJI, which opposes Mrs. Bhutto. U.S. Ambassador Robert Oakley has said the tribunals should also look into corruption from 1985-88, when the IJI parties and politicians ran the government for the military. ``Otherwise, the proceedings will inevitably be seen as partisan and further divide the country,'' Oakley said in a speech to the Asia Society in Washington last week. The powerful army chief of staff, Gen. Mirza Aslam Beg, has reportedly urged Ishaq Khan to broaden the scope of the tribunals to lend credibility to the process.

DOC.HEAD: Rain From Arizona To Florida
DOC.TEXT: Rain extended along the southern tier of states from Arizona to Florida on Saturday and unseasonably warm weather continued on the southern Plains. Thunderstorms developed over southern Arizona with a possibility of heavy rain and a threat of desert flooding. Showers and thunderstorms also were scattered over the southeastern third of New Mexico and into Texas. From Texas, showers and thunderstorms continued eastward, extending across southern and central Louisiana, southern Alabama, southern Georgia, Florida, and the southern coast of North Carolina. In the Northwest, showers and thunderstorms reached from Washington and western Oregon across the Idaho Panhandle, with showers scattered southward over west-central Utah. Elsewhere, rain fell over parts of New England, west-central Pennsylvania, and from northeastern through west-central Wisconsin. Heavier rainfall during the six hours up to 2 p.m. EDT included 1.30 inches at Mount Washington, N.H., and 1.23 inches at Concord, N.H. Temperatures remained higher than normal for mid-September over a large section of the southern half of the Plains. In Colorado, Colorado Springs warmed to a record 88 and Pueblo tied its record of 94. Saturday's low for the Lower 48 states was 32 at West Yellowstone, Mont. Temperatures around the nation at 3 p.m. EDT ranged from 46 in Michigan at the Chippewa County Airport and Sawyer Air Force Base at Marquette to 97 at Wichita Falls, Texas.

DOC.HEAD: Italy Granting Soviets $2.7 Billion in Credits
DOC.TEXT:
Italy agreed to give the Soviet Union $2.72 billion in credits Saturday, one day after Soviet President Mikhail S. Gorbachev warned that his nation is in danger of bankruptcy. Italian Foreign Minister Gianni de Michelis announced the loans at a news conference following his Kremlin meetings with Gorbachev and Soviet Foreign Minister Eduard Shevardnadze. On Friday, Gorbachev presented an economic plan to the national Parliament that proposes market-oriented policies and other measures to halt the nation's slide toward bankruptcy. Gorbachev described the country's international economic position as ``catastrophic'' and warned of possible government insolvency on international markets. For decades, the Soviet Union was considered a good international credit risk because the government always promptly paid its import bills. But because of a widening trade gap, the Soviets have fallen behind on their payments and are seeking trade credits from other nations. West Germany has already agreed to give more than $3 billion in credits to the Soviet Union. That is on top of the $7.6 billion Bonn has pledged to pay to cover the costs of withdrawing Soviet troops from East Germany in connection with German reunification. Other Western European countries are also expected to grant loans to the Soviets, but the United States has so far rejected proposals for direct financial aid to Moscow. The Bush administration has said the any massive infusion of funds might be wasted if the Soviet economy does not first undergo a major overhaul. Washington instead has offered technical assistance, including advice on improving the collapsing food distribution system or how to establish private banking.
De Michelis also said he talked with Soviet leaders about the creation of a stabilization and currency reform fund as well as a balance-of-payments support fund for the Soviet Union. Western countries provided a $1 billion backup fund for Poland to support its currency, the zloty, when it became internally convertible on Jan. 1 as part of its crash transition to a market economy. The fund has not been touched and is viewed as a successful confidence-builder for the zloty. But a similar project for the Soviet Union would be far more expensive, given the size of the Soviet economy. De Michelis said the aid proposals were related to the Soviet economic reform plan, which envisions a crash program of budget-cutting and selling off government property to the public to stabilize the nearly worthless ruble. After the money supply is balanced and store shelves refilled, Gorbachev proposes completing the switch to a market economy by gradually freeing prices. De Michelis said the two sides also discussed deals involving fuel, electric power and telecommunications. The Soviet Union reportedly is trying to gain Western help to develop its oil reserves. He said $1 billion of $2.72 billion in Italian credits would not be tied to particular trade deals. He said the two countries also agreed to write a new treaty on friendship and cooperation, to be signed when Gorbachev visits Rome before the end of the year. On the gulf crisis, de Michelis said one topic of discussion was an Italian proposal to extend sanctions to countries that violate the U.N. trade embargo against Iraq. He said they also discussed extending the sea blockade to air shipments. ``We agreed we should put maximum political and economic pressure on Iraq to ensure its political isolation,'' de Michelis said. De Michelis also reported that Gorbachev is ready to restore diplomatic relations with Israel after a 23-year gap, if Israel agrees to participate in an international Middle East peace conference.

DOC.HEAD: Germans To Provide Nearly $2 Billion in Aid for Persian Gulf Effort
DOC.NOTE: EDS: Inserts grafs 20-25, ``Later, at xxx to update with Baker remarks at news conference; subs 4th graf to bottom, ``Italy volunteered xxx to include Italy's monetary contribution of $145 million; Note this reports proper keyword line, AM-Gulf-Baker, stead AM-Baker-Gulf as erroneously transmitted in a0565
DOC.TEXT: Chancellor Helmut Kohl on Saturday extended nearly $2 billion in economic and military aid to the drive led by the United States against Iraqi President Saddam Hussein. The action, announced outside his country home in the Rhineland after a 90-minute meeting with Secretary of State James A. Apart from the $1.87 billion Kohl pledged to the United States and to poor nations, West Germany is contributing $271 million as part of an aid package approved by the 12-nation European Community. There was no indication that West Germany would contribute to the military force assembled in the gulf to guard oil fields in Saudi Arabia against an Iraqi takeover and to police the economic embargo of Iraq authorized Aug. 6 by the United Nations Security Council. Still, the German contribution marked a turnabout and reflected the growing confidence of a nation, already the richest in Europe, that will grow more powerful after unification. About half the German aid will go this year to the United States to help defray the staggering cost of stationing troops in Saudi Arabia and deploying a naval armada in the Persian Gulf. The other half, Kohl said, will go to poor nations battered by the crisis. Kohl singled out Jordan, Egypt and Turkey. The chancellor said the West German constitution, which he hopes parliament will change after unification with East Germany, prohibits sending troops and warships to the gulf. But he said the forces there ``are also defending our interests.'' Asked whether Iraq could be compelled to relinquish its control of Kuwait short of war, the German leader said: ``I hope so. I am no prophet.'' He said Iraq, which invaded the smaller oil-rich gulf country Aug. 2, ``has to acknowledge the largest share of the world community is against it.'' With tears in his eyes, Kohl thanked the United States for helping to fulfill the German dream of unification, which will occur Oct. 3. But he said the United States would not water down its demand for Iraq's withdrawal from Kuwait and was keeping all options option to attain that end. He characterized Saddam Hussein as mercurial and said, ``I don't think anyone can predict what action he will take.'' On a related subject, Baker, who telephoned President Bush before boarding his plane for the flight home, said he had asked the Soviets during his stop in Moscow to help transport the additional troops Syria was sending to Saudi Arabia and that the request would be considered. The West German assistance includes $636 million in radio equipment, cranes, generators and equipment to protect U.S. soldiers against chemical weapons. About 60 armored vehicles worth $127 million are designed to detect chemical weapons. About $254 million will go toward transportation costs. Egypt will receive about $650 million in aid; about $135 million will go to Jordan, which is saddled with caring for thousands of refugees from Iraq and Kuwait; and about $75 million is for Turkey, a NATO member which has lost the revenues of an Iraqi pipeline that ran through the country and was closed at the start of the crisis. Kohl said the Turks also will receive from Germany ``some defense materiel,'' for which he did not offer a pricetag. ``I was very pleased by the numbers that were presented to us,'' Baker said after West German Foreign Minister Hans-Dietrich Genscher outlined the assistance earlier over lunch at Petersberg, a new government guest house in the hills outside Bonn. Baker called the sums ``very significant and very substantial.'' He later confirmed the offer with Kohl at his country home near Heidelberg. Still, considering its wealth and world power status, the Germans' distance from the U.S.-led campaign against Hussein raised eyebrows in Congress. France is sending 4,000 soldiers, including an 1,100-man helicopter regiment, 48 tanks and a squadron of 30 warplanes and 48 helicopters. Britain is contributing an additional 6,000 combat troops and 120 tanks.

DOC.HEAD: Carter's Former Pilot Says He May Return to Iran
DOC.TEXT: Jimmy Carter's former pilot, who left Iran last week after being imprisoned there for nine years, said Saturday he may return to that country. E. David Rabhan said Saturday he had been told by Iranian court officials he could resume his work there if he chose. ``They've given me a letter saying I could come back to Iran, travel in Iran, just be free in Iran,'' he said in a telephone interview from the home of his mother, Frances Rabhan, in Savannah. ``If I choose to go back, I feel that I can.'' Rabhan, 64, who had worked as a businessman in Iran, flew to Savannah late Friday following a private reunion with former President Carter at Hartsfield Atlanta International Airport. Rabhan's relationship with Carter dates back to at least 1970, when he volunteered his services as a pilot during Carter's second campaign for governor of Georgia. He credited Carter's efforts to get him released. ``They are dear friends,'' said Rabhan's sister, Joan Jacobson, who also met him at the Atlanta airport. He said he was unprepared for the reporters who met his flight from Zurich, Switzerland, and peppered him with questions. ``Really, I didn't expect to have anybody be concerned about it,'' Rabhan said, adding that he objected only to what he called ``the stupid questions like, `How does it feel to be free?' What do they expect me to say?'' Rabhan went to Iran in 1976 to begin a business using a fish protein concentrate to make breads and snack foods. He was arrested in September 1981, according to his attorney Phillips D. Hamilton of Statesboro, Ga. His arrest came almost two years after the attack on the U.S. Embassy in Tehran, which started the 444-day hostage crisis that contributed to Carter's 1980 re-election defeat. Initially Rabhan was charged with violating Iran's financial laws. He told Carter by telephone later that he had been charged with spying. After leaving the presidency, Carter described Rabhan as a ``hostage,'' but neither the Reagan nor Bush administrations considered him a hostage and his plight went largely unreported. According to letters he managed to get out of Iran, Rabhan said he was physically abused and his weight once fell by 44 pounds. He spent part of his imprisonment in solitary confinement in a windowless cell, his letters said. He said his treatment had improved during the last two years. ``I think one reason was because of the concern that President Carter had for me,'' he said. ``I also think the attitude of the Iranian government started to change their attitude toward humanitarianism.'' ``The Iranians reassessed David Rabhan's case and determined that he had never been guilty of any crime, and so they apologized and let him go,'' Carter said Friday after meeting Rabhan's flight. ``He was never a spy. He never had any kind of connection with the CIA or any sort of espionage or spying,'' Carter earlier told The Atlanta Journal. Rabhan said Saturday he wanted to spend his time in Savannah visiting with relatives and planned no special activities. ``I've been without things so long that anything I do seems to be special to me,'' he said.

DOC.HEAD: Police Crack Down as Nation's Capital Succumbs to Lotto Craze
DOC.NOTE: Eds: INSERTS 1 graf after 4th graf, They sad, to describe law under which operations were closed down.
DOC.TEXT: Police raiders here and in the Maryland suburbs have shut down computerized operations in which they say customers purchased chances in Florida's $100 million state lottery. Thriving sales at both locations reflected a spreading nationwide craze over the towering jackpot in the Lotto drawing set for Saturday night. Police in Prince George's County, Md., raided a photo service shop and seized betting slips and gambling paraphernalia as well as a computer terminal. They said the terminal had been used to relay purchases to a point in New Jersey and from there to Florida. They said no arrests were made. Under local laws, only licensed vendors are allowed to sell lottery tickets, and even they are allowed to sell only those for the local lottery. Earlier, Washington police seized a computer terminal and $1,000 in cash from a dry cleaners. Police said customers paid $2 each and received receipts for purchase of $1 lottery tickets. They said the same establishment was selling chances on the California and Arizona lotteries.

DOC.HEAD: Weekend Reprieve for Nation's Longest-Running Daily Newspaper
LaserPhoto NY19
DOC.TEXT: The rumored tabloid headline ``BANG, WE'RE DEAD'' was shelved for ``AIN'T OVER YET!'' as the nation's longest-running daily newspaper dodged a bullet with help from its unions. Post owner Peter Kalikow said the 505,000-circulation paper known for its racy headlines would have to close Saturday without union concessions because it has been losing $27 million a year. Ten of the New York Post's 11 unions agreed late Friday to a $19 million concession package that would eliminate jobs and shorten work weeks. The holdout was the Newspape Guild, which represents 352 white-collar employees, mainly reporters and advertising staff. Its negotiating committee voted 7-3 to reject the concession deal. ``They were saying, `Shut it down,''' said Thomas Pennacchio, secretary-treasurer of Guild Local 3. Kalikow said the paper would publish until the Guild's members voted on the concessions. A vote on whether to accept elimination of 43 jobs and four work days a week was scheduled for Monday. ``I feel optimistic that when the members see it they will approve it,'' said Post owner Peter Kalikow. ``If they turn it down, the paper will stop publishing immediately.'' The Post said in Saturday's editions the concessions from its 960 employees include 100 fewer truck driver jobs, down from 263; its 70 printers cutting to a four-day work week and five fewer paper handlers, cutting from a staff of 17. After the agreement was announced, a cheer erupted in the Post's newsroom, where workers had gathered for what might have been their final edition. Two versions were prepared and newsroom scuttlebutt predicted the ``BANG, WE'RE DEAD'' headline if no agreement had been reached. The Post, founded by Alexander Hamilton in 1801, was sold to heiress Dorothy Schiff in 1939. Australian media baron Rupert Murdoch bought it in 1976 and sold it to Kalikow in 1988. The possible salvation of the 189-year-old paper aside, one writer chafed at the idea of a four-day work week. ``What am I supposed to do, drive a cab on the fifth day?'' Peter Moses said. Guild president Barry Lipton, who supported the offer, said ``It was the best we could make. ... I hope that the sense of the membership is to swallow what may be a bitter pill.'' Drivers gathered at the Post loading dock Saturday, angry over looming cuts and Kalikow's tactics. ``Today is no celebration,'' said driver Stan Infante. ``People are losing jobs.''

DOC.HEAD: U.S. Cruiser Rescues Youths
DOC.TEXT: An American warship on blockade duty rescued two Omani brothers drifting in a disabled motorboat in the Gulf of Oman, U.S. military spokesmen said Saturday. They said the missile cruiser USS Jouett spotted the pair, ages 12 and 17, while on patrol Friday and took them aboard. The youths said they had been drifting for six days. A medical examination showed them to be dehydrated but otherwise in good condition, the spokesmen said. The rescue was reported to Omani authorities who were asked to notify the youths' family. The Jouett is a member of the battle group headed by the aircraft carrier USS Independence. The Gulf of Oman lies between Iran and Oman and is separated from the Persian Gulf by the Strait of Hormuz.
