DOC.HEAD: Acres of Tanks, Troops Still on the Move
DOC.NOTE: EDITOR'S NOTE
DOC.TEXT: AP Military Writer Susanne Schafer recently traveled to Fort Hood with General Carl Vuono, the Army's chief of staff, where elements of the 1st Cavalry and 2nd Armored Divisions are preparing to ship out to Saudi Arabia. This is the first of three reports.

During the first hectic weeks of Operation Desert Shield, the Pentagon said it moved enough troops, weaponry and supplies to fill a mid-size town. But this fort's acres of tanks - and the 15,000 troops going with them - are only just beginning to leave for Saudi Arabia. And they aren't scheduled to get there until well into October. The row upon row of M-1 tanks, M-109 howitzers, armored personnel carriers and assorted war-making machinery has become the stuff of dreams. ``We'll all sleep better when it gets there,'' growled one colonel accompanying a group of visitors on a tour of the 217,000-acre base. Fort Hood's 1st Cavalry and 2nd Armored Divisions represent the heavy forces that the top U.S. military commander in Saudi Arabia, Gen. H. Norman Schwarzkopf, says he'll need to have on the ground before he can defend Saudi Arabia against any kind of Iraqi attack. But moving such massive amounts of material isn't an easy job. So the Army's chief of staff, Gen. Carl Vuono, came to this post on the rolling Texas savanna to check whether his commanders had prepared their men, women and machinery for the trip. ``It's show time!'' Vuono called out to a room of generals, colonels and top-level sergeants, gathered to give him the update. ``Are you ready?'' Lt. Gen. Richard Graves, the three-star commander of Fort Hood and the Army's III Corps, briefed Vuono on the multiplicity of headaches brought on by moving nearly one-third of his personnel and hundreds of 60-ton vehicles some 9,000 miles to Saudi Arabia. It's been nothing but frenzied activity here since people learned they'd deploy on Aug. 10. First, they had to get several hundred tanks, troop carriers and howitzers ready for transport by rail to the port at Beaumont, Texas. From there, the tons of war machinery was to be transferred to huge container ships for the lengthy trip to Saudi Arabia. ``We've got lift constraints,'' Graves reminded Vuono during their talk. In the intervening weeks, it had become clear the system for sealifting equipment needed improvement. The rapid deployment forces from the 24th Infantry Division (Mechanized) from Fort Stewart, Ga. - the first group to deploy to Saudi Arabia with the heavy M-1 tanks - showed up at portside with bridging equipment. Instead of the seven ships thought necessary, 10 were needed. So at least 13 ships - instead of the original eight - have been scheduled to move the Texas units, a spokeswoman for the Navy's Sealift Command said. And after the heaviest weapons are sent on their way, the troops must be checked to ensure they've got the latest training and most up-to-date supplies. ``Every soldier going is carrying a weapon that he's fired and carrying a gas mask that he's trained with,'' Graves said. ``We've got 12 days of personal training scheduled.'' Before departure, hundreds of rounds of ammunition for each tank and artillery piece must be prepared for shipment, Graves said. Gun barrels were replaced on the many of the units' more than 230 M-1 tanks. Metal treads on all armored vehicles were being checked to see whether they'd sustained a minimum of 300 miles of wear. On the individual level, commanders had to ensure that each service member had the correct vaccinations, next-of-kin records filled out and even HIV testing done. Families had to be informed and informational telephone support line set up. About 1,200 family members showed up for the first briefing, Graves said. Training reviews on everything from chemical weapons protection to personal hygiene in the desert must be attended to. ``What about the mess cooks? You talking to the mess cooks? We don't want the whole company down with dysentery,'' Vuono demanded. Flipping a series of view-graphs on the wall, Graves showed Vuono that his personnel count was good: more than 90 percent of his troops were deployable. In the count of all the men and women, 1.1 percent of the troops were pregnant - a figure that translated into 8.4 percent of the female troops being pregnant, and therefore ineligible for deployment. Others unable to deploy were the 3 percent in transit because of changes in orders; about 1.8 percent with medical problems; and 1.5 percent with some sort of legal entanglement. Down the road at a motor pool, a cloud of pink dust hovered over a group of jungle-green trucks and tankers that were being painted a rosy, desert beige. The general paused to speak to the officers and sergeants in charge of an artillery unit, telling them in no uncertain terms that they were ``entrusted with the most precious commodity that this nation has - its sons and daughters. ``So when you're humping ammunition, when you're going into position and the temperature is 118 degrees in the shade and you are as bone-tired as you will be ... as a leader you have a responsibility to push that aside and look out for those precious soldiers,'' Vuono said, ``because they ask for so little and they deserve so much from us.''

DOC.HEAD: Saddam Hussein A Hit with Would-Be Rambos
DOC.TEXT: Iraqi President Saddam Hussein may have been a late entry, but he was a hit of the show this weekend as thousands of would-be Rambos gathered to revel in exotic weaponry. ``They're just selling like hot cakes,'' Linda Blaha said as customers eyed a 2-foot target showing a smirking Saddam - with a bull's-eye centered on his nose. A young boy stepped forward with $2 for two targets. Some 10,000 veterans, mercenaries and gun enthusiasts spoiling for a fight turned out for the annual Soldier of Fortune convention, which runs through Sunday. Khaki-clad military types attended seminars on issues such as the Middle East and battles to be won in South America. But the highlight of the annual convention, as it has been for the last decade, was a collection of exotic weapons and gear ranging from automatic weapons that fit snugly in the palm of your hand to rocket and grenade launchers, knives, ammunition, stun guns, tear gas and brass knuckles. The convention and its legion of warriors are never at a loss for enemies. But Saddam made the list late, following last month's invasion of Kuwait. One of the most popular T-shirts being sold at the sprawling exposition showed a turbaned figure riding a camel fixed in a gun sight. The message read: ``I'd Walk 10,000 Miles to Smoke A Camel.'' Richard Saindon, who was hawking the shirts at $12 each, said they were ``going fast'' and there was a lot of anti-Saddam sentiment. Blaha said the Saddam target, marketed by Quartermaster Sales of Albuquerque, N.M., was one of the company's most popular items at the show. How were buyers responding? ``They say they're gonna shoot straight.'' One T-shirt read ``Operation Desert Shield: No Slack for Iraq'' while another showed a Marine choking a Middle Eastern figure and asking: ``How Much is the Oil Now?'' There were hundreds of books, including ``Surviving Hostage Situations,'' ``Armed and Female,'' ``Nuclear War Survival Skills,'' ``Survival Shooting for Women'' and even one titled ``Divorce Dirty Tricks.'' Other T-shirts carried messages such as ``Gun Control is Being Able to Hit Your Target,'' ``Mercenary - Dirty Deeds Done Dirt Cheap,'' and ``Armed Men are Citizens. Unarmed Men are Subjects.'' One shirt pictured three armed chipmunks with the message: ``Happiness is a Warm Machine Gun.'' Another featured an American flag and the challenge: ``Try to burn this one.'' One booth was peddling boxes of photos, including several of Adolf Hitler. One carried the inscription: ``No More Mr. Nice Guy Next Time.'' Nearby, Brian Barlow of San Francisco stood under a Soviet flag and peddled Soviet pins, hats and military insignia. ``I've been surprised at the interest of the people,'' he said, reflecting on the changing times.

DOC.HEAD: Search of Bates' Apartment Turns Up Noose, Satanic Writings, Pornography
With AM-Gainesville Slayings, Bjt
DOC.TEXT: Police searching the apartment of a man under investigation in a string of student slayings found a hangman's noose, personal satanic writings and books on Satanism, a newspaper reported Saturday. Authorities also found books on Jack the Ripper, pornography, two pairs of women's panties and several knives in the Lakeland home of Stephen Michael Bates, The Lakeland Ledger reported. The search was carried out Aug. 30, a day after Bates' arrest for allegedly breaking into a home and threatening a woman and her daughter with a knife. The last of five bodies in the college student slayings were discovered Aug. 28. The newspaper did not identify its sources and said Florida Department of Law Enforcement officials refused to comment on the reported search findings. Bates, 30, has been identified by Gainesville authorities as a possible suspect in the series of killings at off-campus dwellings discovered between Aug. 26 and Aug. 28. The victims attended either the University of Florida or Santa Fe Community College. Bates allegedly entering an apartment east of Lakeland on Aug. 21 and menaced a woman and her teen-age daughter with a knife. He is in custody awating trial, with bail set at $100,500. Polk County Sheriff Lawrence Crow Jr. said Friday despite interest in Bates, he isn't convinced. ``He's not a real strong suspect but he certainly needs looking into,'' Crow said. ``I don't consider him to be an extra strong suspect. More of a possible than a probable.'' In Brevard County, Public Defender J.R. Russo predicted that Edward Lewis Humphrey, 18, the other man named by Gainesville authorities as a possible suspect, would be released soon. Humphrey is charged with attacking his grandmother, Elna Hlavaty. She first told authorities that Humphrey had choked her and hit her during an argument at her Indialantic home after his return from Gainesville. In a hearing last week, however, the 79-year-old woman told authorities her injuries were accidental and that she wanted the charges dropped. Humphrey still faces possible prosecution in two other cases. In Indian River County, he faces charges of attempted rape and armed burglary for an attack on a woman in Vero Beach. In Alachua County, Humphrey is accused of threatening two students at the University of Florida. Russo said he thinks those charges will never be filed. School records show Humphrey was in school when the Vero Beach woman was attacked. The victim also described her assailant as a man in his mid-20s with a mustached. Humphrey was a baby-faced 16-year-old at the time and has never worn a mustache. Humphrey has been in custody, with bail set at $1 million, since the alleged attack on his grandmother.

DOC.HEAD: Sierra Communities Threatened By Wildfire
LaserPhoto XSOR1
DOC.TEXT: Three towns of about 5,000 people were threatened Saturday by a fire in the Stanislaus National Forest in the Sierra Nevada that had charred more than 2,200 acres. Although the fire was considered 50 percent contained, its eastern edge was still burning freely, a U.S. Park Service spokeswoman said. That edge was less than two miles from the small resort towns of Mi-Wuk, Sugar Pine and Sierra Village and about 5,000 people were warned to be ready for possible evacuation, she said. A shift to damp weather Friday night caused unexpected problems for firefighters. They had planned to set a backfire to control that edge of the fire but it was too damp, and as a result the fire threatened Saturday to go into the Tuolumne River Canyon. ``We are concentrating all our efforts on the eastern side, because if it goes into the canyon, then Mi-Wuk, Sugar Pine and Sierra Village are in some real trouble,'' said Park Service spokeswoman Mary Hale. ``It's in a real bad area,'' Hale said. ``If it gets in the canyon, those firefighters out there are looking at a long haul.'' On the other hand, fire officials said they expected containment by Sunday morning. ``It's like a see-saw today, it could go either way,'' she said. As of Saturday afternoon no structures had been destroyed and fire officials reported only three minor injuries. Fire officials allowed about 400 people who had evacuated earlier from a subdivision southeast of Twain Harte, in the Sierra Nevada 150 miles east across the state from San Francisco, to return to their homes Saturday. At one point before dawn Friday, flames crept within 100 yards of the houses there, Hale said. The blaze, called the Cotton Fire, began Thursday in the Riverside campground on the north fork of the Tuolumne River. ``We know this is human-caused,'' said fire spokesman Jeff Fontana. ``We haven't had lightning around here.'' He could provide no details about how the fire got started. A 147,000-acre burn tore through the Stanislaus forest around Labor Day 1987.

DOC.HEAD: President Suspects Security Forces Link in Death of U.S. Citizen
DOC.TEXT: President Vinicio Cerezo said in a letter to the U.S. ambassador that Guatemalan security forces may be linked to the June decapitation of an Illinois man in northern Guatemala. U.S. Embassy spokesman James Dickmeyer confirmed on Saturday that Ambassador Thomas Stroock had received the letter, dated Sept. 6. ``People linked to the security forces could be responsible for the death of U.S. citizen Michael Devine,'' Cerezo said in his letter, a copy of which was obtained Friday night by The Associated Press. ``It is our aim to pursue every investigation to determine such responsibility, and if that's the case, find those responsible for the act and apply the sanctions the law establishes,'' Cerezo said. Devine's body was found on June 9, one day after his wife, Carole A. Moore, reported her husband's disappearance. Devine, 49, of Belleville, Ill., was owner of the Xobel de Poptun inn and served as a guide for tourists. He also worked transporting merchandise between ranches in the Poptun region near the Guatemalan border with Belize. He was transporting goods when he disappeared, and he was robbed of an undisclosed amount of money and his wristwatch. His body was found in a clump of bushes about two miles from the town of Poptun, located 240 miles northeast of Guatemala City in the province of Peten. It was bound and showed signs of mistreatment. Cerezo said he has ordered the national police to clear up the case as soon as possible, and has asked the Defense Ministry to assist in the investigation. He said he has asked that arrest warrants and legal proceedings be expedited. Diplomats in Guatemala have been pressuring Cerezo to put a lid on violence. The Central American nation of 8 million people has been torn apart by 28 years of leftist insurgency and brutal military tactics to crush it. Earlier this month, the U.S. State Department put out a travel advisory for Guatemala that warned of indiscriminate terrorist attacks, crime and fighting between the armed forces and rebels. Cerezo blames the latest violence on right-wing elements trying to destabilize his centrist administration. He has been the victim of two military coup attempts that had conservative backing.

DOC.HEAD: Hikers Warned To Stay Off Trail; Search Continues
DOC.TEXT: Police searched rugged hills Saturday for a killer who shot and stabbed two hikers as they slept in a remote shelter on the Appalachian Trail. Hikers were warned to stay off the trail in Pennsylvania. ``Murders are very rare on the trail, but we can't outguess somebody that is a murderer, so we're taking precautions,'' said Brian King, spokesman for the Appalachian Trail Conference. Geoffrey Logan Hood, 26, of Signal Mountain, Tenn., and Molly LaRue, 25, of Shaker Heights, Ohio, were found dead Thursday by two other hikers. Hood was shot and Ms. LaRue was stabbed repeatedly, said state Trooper Rodney Anderson. Both apparently were slain as they slept in the Cove Mountain lean-to shelter. ``They were caught off guard and somebody attacked them ... sometime before dawn,'' said Perry County Coroner Michael J. Shalonis. He said the couple had been dead 12 to 16 hours when they were found. Police combed the area on foot and in helicopters Saturday. ``We're not assuming anything,'' said state police Cpl. Brady Williams when asked whether the killer was thought to be in the area. Police said they did not have any suspects. The Appalachian Trail Conference, which maintains the 2,140-mile trail, sent out handbills to be posted in a 30-mile area surrounding the shelter. The site is about three miles southeast of Duncannon, a rural town 15 miles northwest of Harrisburg. ``The National Park Service warns Appalachian Trail hikers to exercise appropriate caution, including temporarily bypassing the Appalachian Trail in Pennsylvania,'' the sign warns. The Pennsylvania portion of the trail extends for 230 miles from PenMar, Md., to the Delaware Water Gap at the New Jersey line. More than 3{ million people hike along the Appalachian Trail, which runs from Maine to Georgia. The Pennsylvania segment is one of the most heavily traveled, according to the conference, based in Harpers Ferry, W.Va. King said the murders were the first on the trail since May 1988, when hiker Rebecca Wight, of Blacksburg, Va., was killed in the Michaux State Forest in south-central Pennsylvania. Her companion, Claudia Brenner, 31, of Ithaca, N.Y., was wounded. Stephen Roy Carr, then 28, was convicted of first-degree murder in the slayings.

DOC.HEAD: Auto Workers Union Goes on Strike Against Ford in Canada
DOC.TEXT: Thousands of Canadian auto workers went on strike Saturday against Ford Motor Co. of Canada, as negotiators resumed talks aimed at settling the dispute over pay, benefits and job security. Parallel talks continued Saturday in the United States between the United Auto Workers and General Motors Corp. after negotiators in Detroit agreed to extend a midnight strike deadline. The UAW told its members not to strike while negotiators worked to reach a new three-year agreement covering 300,000 GM workers nationwide. The strike in Canada won't affect production until Monday because Ford of Canada plants do not operate weekends. Up to 12,800 workers were expected to walk off the job at nine plants and two offices in Ontario. The company has two plants in Oakville, five in Windsor, one in St. Thomas and one in Niagara Falls The Canadian Auto Workers union called the strike - the first against Ford since 1976 - after negotiators failed to meet a Friday midnight deadline for reaching agreement on a new contract. Negotiators for both sides met formally and informally Saturday at a Toronto hotel. They were to hold a formal negotiating session on Sunday morning. ``The process is continuing on both sides,'' Ford spokesman Jim Hartford said. ``We are experiencing a strike. We're doing our best to ensure it's a short one.'' Union spokeswoman Peggy Nash said there were still many unresolved issues separating both sides. ``It sounds like the two sides are still very far apart. (Ford negotiator) Don McKenzie said he was still optimistic this could be sorted out quickly,'' she said. ``(Union President) Bob White didn't seem so optimistic.'' The union's contract with Ford expired on Friday. ``Everybody is pretty much ready for this,'' Windsor autoworker Tom Bellmore said after Saturday's strike announcement. ``Everybody is resigned that this is the way it's got to be.'' Like many of his fellow workers, Bellmore said he had stocked up on groceries and other supplies in preparation for the shutdown. Both sides have refused to disclose details of their proposals and demands. The union is seeking higher wages, including money to help offset a proposed federal goods and services tax, better benefits and more time off, White said. The average hourly base pay now is about $15. White said progress has been made on job security, and McKenzie conceded that money is the main problem. The union rejected the company's initial offer on Wednesday. The union made its proposal on Friday, but the company has yet to respond, White said. In Detroit, the UAW and General Motors agreed to extend their national labor contract past its Friday expiration date, and talks continued Saturday. Both sides have refused to disclose the progress of the negotiations, but aspects of job security and benefits for GM workers remain unresolved. In both countries, the auto workers unions target one company in their talks in hopes of fashioning a pattern contract for workers at other automakers.

DOC.HEAD: `Epicenter' Wine Marks Anniversary of Deadly Temblor
DOC.TEXT: Seven Northern California wineries are commemorating last year's deadly earthquake with Epicenter Cuvee, a chardonnay bottled to benefit quake victims. The wine is being sold only at the seven wineries in Santa Cruz County, one of the areas hit hardest by the Oct. 17 quake. The label on each bottle depicts the Richter scale, which measures earthquake intensity, and a drawing of a ground-shock record that tops out at 7.1 - the magnitude of the quake. Only 166 cases of Epicenter Cuvee - nearly 2,000 bottles - were produced, said Marty Bargetto, marketing director of Bargetto Winery, one of the wineries involved. A third of sales proceeds will go to earthquake relief, he said. The quake killed 67 people, injured 4,000 and left 12,000 people homeless. Jeffrey R. Smith of Roudon-Smith Winery promised that the wine ``will age gracefully'' and predicted it will be poured by ``those toasting memories of the cataclysm they survived with their spirits intact.'' For those who want to lift a glass exactly one year after the quake, the wine's label promises: ``This chardonnay should reach its peak on Oct. 17, 1990, at 5:04 p.m.''

DOC.HEAD: Newspaper: Florida Plant Tied to Poison Gas
DOC.TEXT: The Iraqi architect of a Libyan chemical weapons complex invested $5 million in a Florida cherry flavoring plant in an apparent bid to export cyanide to the Middle East, a newspaper reported in Sunday's editions. Two former associates said deceased financier Dr. Ihsan Barbouti used the Boca Raton plant to establish a front through which he could export deadly hydrogen cyanide and the technology to produce it in quantity, The Dallas Morning News reported. The former associates said Barbouti sought to export the poison to Middle East countries identified by the U.S. government as supporters of terrorism. Barbouti acknowledged contracts with Iraq and Iran, they said. Barbouti has been identified in Western news reports as the architect of Libyan Col. Moammar Gadhafi's chemical weapons plant in Rabta. He died July 1 in London on lung and heart complications, according to his death certificate. He was 63. The president of the Florida flavoring plant said he had no role in the diversion of any toxic material, but acknowledged that at least 150 gallons of a cyanide compound were unaccounted for. The cyanide was a byproduct of a process used to extract bitter almond oil, a concentrate for cherry flavoring, from apricot pits. The cyanide could have been taken from Product Ingredient Technology Inc. without his knowledge, Louis S. Champon said. ``My feeling is that it was his intention to ship out (cyanide) to overseas,'' Champon said. Peter Kawaja, whose company installed a $1 million security system at the plant, said the cyanide was removed during ``night trips'' to another site in Florida he declined to identify. ``Shipments have left the U.S. and technology has left the U.S.,'' said Kawaja. ``We're talking about the research and development of chemical weapons in the United States.'' Kawaja declined to identify the final destination of the potentially lethal chemical. The newspaper said U.S. Customs and the FBI have accelerated their investigation of Barbouti's role in the flavoring plant since Iraq's invasion of Kuwait last month. They are examining his vast holdings in Dallas, Houston, Oklahoma City, New Orleans, Tennessee, New Jersey and New York. The federal agencies declined comment. ``If there's an ongoing investigation, we're not going to comment on it. Those are attorney general's guidelines ... I'm not confirming that there is an investigation. I don't know if there is or there isn't,'' FBI spokesman Jeffrey W. Maynard told The Associated Press on Saturday. The Central Intelligence Agency also refused to discuss the investigation. ``We decline to comment at this time. I would say, though, that if there is any indication or intelligence of hostile activities we would bring that to the attention of the appropriate law enforcement authorities,'' CIA spokesman Peter Earnest told the AP. Customs Service spokesman Cliff Stallings in Miami said Saturday that he had been in Washington last week and was unaware of the case. ``You can quote me saying if it's under investigation, then we won't talk about it,'' he said. Barbouti's holdings are controlled by his son, Haidar Barbouti, who lives in New York City. The younger Barbouti has been president and director of 20 to 30 of his father's companies. There was no answer at Barbouti's Manhattan residence or at the Barbouti holding company, IBI Industries Inc., Saturday. Champon said he has filed a lawsuit to sever his business ties with the Barbouti family. Champon said he and Barbouti often quarreled about disposal of the waste cyanide and that Barbouti's funding ``stopped when we flatly refused to send out any cyanide complex.'' ``Dr. Barbouti many, many times mentioned that he wanted this cyanide . . . shipped to Germany,'' Champon said of the cyanide waste from the plant. And according to Kawaja and Champon, the Barboutis asked the plant's architect to computerize the blueprints of the operation without Champon's knowledge. ``They were trying to steal the plans,'' Champon said.

DOC.HEAD: Jury Awards Former Race Promoters $13.6 million
DOC.TEXT: A jury has awarded $13.6 million to auto racing promoters who sued a newspaper for libel over articles about the Cleveland Grand Prix. The case stemmed from articles written by reporter Gary Webb for The (Cleveland) Plain Dealer primarily in 1984 and also in 1985 and 1986. The eight-member jury returned the finding Friday on the second day of deliberations. Alex Machaskee, publisher of The Plain Dealer, said the newspaper intends to appeal. The plaintiffs were Charles K. Newcomb and James H. Foster, along with the company C.K. Newcomb and Associates. They promoted the Indy-style car race at Burke Lakefront Airport starting in 1982, when the event was called the Budweiser Cleveland 500. The company, Newcomb and Foster sought $6 million in compensatory damages and $10 million in punitive damages in the suit filed in 1985. The plaintiffs' lawyer, Jerome S. Kalur, could not be reached for comment; he was not at his office and has no residential phone listing. Newcomb also has no listing. Foster was not at his residence, according to a recorded message. In 1984, a week before the 1984 Budweiser Cleveland Grand Prix, The Plain Dealer reported that Newcomb and Foster paid themselves nearly $1 million from race proceeds in violation of a lease with the city. Newcomb and Foster declined to be interviewed for that story. The newspaper also said the race did not satisfy rent payments to the city because Newcomb and Foster told the city the race was deeply in debt. Lawyers for The Plain Dealer argued during the eight-week trial before Cuyahoga County Common Pleas Judge Joseph F. McManamon that the primary points of the articles were indisputably true. But lawyers for the plaintiffs argued the race in fact lost money its first two years and that the articles were false. Newcomb and Foster sold the rights to the race in March 1985 to businessman and former race car driver Roger Penske, and The Plain Dealer later became co-sponsor of the event. McManamon said the jury awarded C.K. Newcomb and Associates $2.2 million in compensatory damages and $2 million in punitive damages; Newcomb, $2 million compensatory and $3.5 million punitive, and Foster $400,000 compensatory and $3.5 million punitive.

DOC.HEAD: Army Officer Dies in Saudi Arabia Vehicle Crash
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with soldiers identified. No pickup.
DOC.TEXT: An officer from the U.S. Army's 24th Infantry Division was killed when his vehicle left the roadway and crashed in Saudi Arabia's Eastern Province, the Army said Saturday. Lt. Tommie W. Bates, 27, of Coventry, R.I., was killed Friday, said Melanie Shumsky, a public affairs officer at Ft. Stewart in Hinesville, Ga., where the mechanized infantry division is based. Another soldier, Sgt. Paul D. Bonham, 43, of Hinesville, was injured in the crash. He was listed in stable condition at the Air Force Tactical Hospital in Dhahran, she said. The single-vehicle crash occurred Friday ``when the vehicle left the roadway,'' Shumsky said, adding that the Army was investigating.

DOC.HEAD: Drought Highlights Split Between Urban, Farm Water Users
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 14th graf, `Most of...,' to CORRECT California's daily water use to 30.3 billion gallons sted 37.4 million gallons.
DOC.TEXT: California's fourth year of unyielding drought is stirring fears that a continuing shortage could pit thirsty city dwellers against agriculture, the state's No. 1 industry and biggest water user. The drought - with its images of parched lawns, dying trees and depleted reservoirs - is an indication of things to come, said Neil Berlant, managing partner of Water Research Associates, a specialized investment and consulting company in Los Angeles. ``What's emerging out of this is one of the most politically charged issues of our time,'' Berlant said. He sees a future in which drinkable water is an increasingly precious commodity - like crude oil. ``I think there is a great probability of prices exploding more than anybody realizes,'' he said. The drought already has revealed residents' willingness to pay exorbitant prices for water in Santa Barbara, where shortages this summer prompted officials to consider building a costly seawater desalting plant. What Berlant and others foresee is a collision between the irresistible force of California's booming population and the immovable object of available water supplies. They believe political pressures will bear more and more on agriculture to reallocate water to urban users. ``The issue that comes to my mind is not whether you're going to use farm water, but how are you going to do it in a way that's fair and reasonable,'' said Carl Boronkay. He's general manager of the Metropolitan Water District of Southern California, which supplies water to five counties in Southern California, including Los Angeles. Rural water agency officials, on the other hand, predict that political pressures will coalesce to support construction of new dams and aqueducts. ``There's plenty of room to improve our water development in this state,'' said Stephen Hall, executive director of the California Farm Water Coalition. Agriculture accounts for more than $16 billion of the state's $300-billion-plus annual economy. The drought, however, has exposed factors underlying the debate that tend to run against agricultural interests, Berlant said. Imposing rationing on city residents, albeit well-intentioned, focuses on the smallest sector of water users, he said. Most of California's available water - 82 percent, according to the U.S. Geological Survey - is used for irrigating crops. California leads the nation in water use, at 30.3 billion gallons a day. ``An across-the-board cut in urban water use of 25 percent by everybody - homeowners, commercial, industrial - would be the rough equivalent of agriculture cutting its use by 3 percent,'' says state Assemblyman Phillip Isenberg. ``It does tend to suggest that agriculture ought to be doing something in terms of conservation,'' said Isenberg. He also has called attention to the types of water-intensive crops California farmers grow, including federally subsidized crops like cotton. Pastures grown for livestock use at least 4.2 million acre-feet of water a year - enough for 42 million city residents, according to Marc Reisner, author of the 1986 book ``Cadillac Desert.'' In the book, he argues the huge effort needed to turn deserts into farmland is a waste of both money and water. Alfalfa uses almost as much, 4.1 million acre-feet a year, followed by cotton and rice. One acre-foot is the amount of water needed to flood an acre 1 foot deep. Agriculture officials counter that because farms use so much water, they probably have the highest incentive to conserve. During the drought, state and federal water allotments to agriculture have been reduced as much as 50 percent, although many farms made up the difference by pumping groundwater at higher cost. Some farms have implemented drip irrigation and other low-flow methods, but farmers tend to argue that their crops' water requirements are fixed and can't be changed. ``I think the bottom line for me on conservation is that it should be part of everything we do, but if it's all we do, we're destined to have chronic water shortages,'' Hall said. Berlant argues there is little real incentive for farmers to conserve because the water they get is so cheap. Many farms benefit from huge federal or state subsidies for government water, paying less than $50 per acre-foot. In contrast, Berlant estimates that residential water customers in Southern California pay as much as $400 per acre-foot. In the future, widening price disparity could make farmland look cheap to water-short cities, and some fear cities might move to buy farmland solely to acquire the water allotments that go with that land. Hall argues that trying to wring more water out of agricultural conservation and water transfers ``is like a company on the verge of bankruptcy cracking down on how many paper clips they're using.'' While the potential for antagonism is real, Boronkay sees the differences between urban and farm interests as a chance to negotiate rather than an opportunity to incite demagoguery. ``Some farm water represents part of the urban supply of the future,'' said Boronkay, who added: ``God, that's fighting words to some people, and I'm not just going to willy-nilly go around saying it.''

DOC.HEAD: Derwinski Apologizes for Remark About Hispanics
DOC.NOTE: Eds: SUBS 4th graf, `Derwinski was...', to FIX spelling to Milder sted Midler.
DOC.TEXT: Veterans Affairs Secretary Edward Derwinski apologized for referring to Hispanics as ``wetbacks'' during a campaign stop for a Republican congressional candidate. The derogatory expression, derived from the crossing of the Rio Grande by illegal aliens, came up during a discussion on drug trafficking, Derwinski told television station KMTV in Omaha. ``And in the process, I got so carried away with my subject that that term slipped, and I shouldn't have used it, obviously. Again, I will apologize if I must, and I should,'' Derwinski told the station Friday. Derwinski was campaigning for House candidate Ally Milder on Friday. ``We're all sorry it happened,'' Ms. Milder said. ``It should never have been said.'' Derwinski said racist connotations associated with the term didn't apply in his case. ``No, that's I think a phrase that you know is commonly used, certainly it has no intention of being disrespectful other than descriptive,'' he said. Gail Handleman, a spokesman for Ms. Milder's opponent, Rep. Peter Hoagland, said she was ``shocked and outraged'' by Derwinski's remark and also by what she termed his ``callous insensitivity'' toward women. Derwinski has been criticized for using pet names like ``Zsa Zsa'' and ``Little Miss Coffee Maker'' for women who work in his office. Derwinski said Friday he has an informal office and that he intends no slight against women. Derwinski said he has pet names for male employees, too, and that his employees call him the ``Big Cheese.'' Derwinski, 64, a congressman from Chicago from 1959 to 1983, was appointed by President Bush in 1989.

DOC.HEAD: Angry Women Tell Store: No Planned Parenthood Funding, No Christmas Shopping
DOC.TEXT: Abortion rights protesters destroyed symbolic credit cards of a department store chain and threatened a Christmas season boycott unless the store abandons plans to cut donations to Planned Parenthood. The demonstration outside Dayton's department store was attended by about 500 protesters toting signs bearing slogans such as: ``I'm pro-choice and I shop.'' Another sign showed a Dayton's credit card cut in half with the caption, ``You leave us no choice.'' The chanting crowd gathered near doors of the store in the Southdale Shopping Center but did not enter. ``We feel betrayed and sold out by a friend,'' Clare Gravon, chairwoman of the Minnesota Alliance for Choice, told the mostly female crowd. Organizers collected contributions to fund an advertising campaign for the threatened boycott Gravon said would start the day after Thanksgiving. There will be no boycott if the Dayton Hudson Foundation restores funding to Planned Parenthood of Minnesota, she said. The foundation is the charitable arm of the Minneapolis-based Dayton Hudson Corp. ``Providing family planning and health care to low-income women is the right thing to do,'' Gravon told the crowd. ``Caving in to religious pressure groups is not.'' Dayton's announced in August plans to halt a $20,000 educational grant to Planned Parenthood, ending a 22-year relationship. The decision came about the time the Christian Action Council said it would boycott Dayton's and other corporations for supporting Planned Parenthood. Dayton Hudson spokeswoman Ann Barkelew said the decision had nothing to do with pressure from special interest groups, but arose from confusion about the donations, which some misconstrued as support for abortion. Barkelew said foundation trustees are reconsidering the decision not to fund Planned Parenthood. She said talks with the agency were held last week and will continue. ``We're confident we will reach a solution,'' she said. The company had annual sales of $13.9 million last year. About half of its sales come during the holiday shopping season, Barkelew said.

DOC.HEAD: Twister Fans Tangle For Fun
DOC.TEXT: For a while Saturday, those gathered in a tavern's parking lot appeared to falling all over themselves. But what they were really trying to do was put a right foot on blue and a left foot on red. They were playing Twister, a 1960s game that attracted droves of amateur contortionists who relished a chance to become Chicago's Most Twisted Twister. ``We look at this tournament as wholesome entertainment for the truly twisted,'' said Sandy Rose, the owner of the Blue Frog Bar & Grill, who donated a block of parking space for a Twister tournament. The tournament's checkerboards were 25 multicolored, polka-dotted mats the size of tablecloths tacked into the asphalt. The contestants were tall and petite, masculine and feminine, and generally jovial. ``I think you have to be a crazy person, a funny person to play,'' said Brian O'Hara, 34, who last played the game in 1975. ``I love it,'' O'Hare proclaimed minutes before landing on his backside when he tried to place his left foot on a yellow circle during a warm-up match. Players had to shed their shoes, pick a partner and outmaneuver another team by placing their hands and feet on the colored circles haphazardly chosen by the spin of a wheel. The game ends when both players on a team lose their balance and touch the mat with a part of their body other than a hand or foot. The best at putting their hands and feet on the circles Saturday were Keith and Clare Bodner of Kansas City, Mo., winners of the coveted Most Twisted Twister. ``It's a little like very low impact aerobics with more body contact,'' Rose said of the game. Many players ended red-faced and weak in the knees after tangling their bodies into unnatural positions. ``Point your toes. Oh, that hurts doesn't it?'' judge and organizer Scott Phillips joked between commands when moans and squeals emerged from the human knots on the plastic mats. Teams played simultaneously as an announcer gave the commands until the field was narrowed to two teams. ``I myself forgot how fun it could be from when I was a kid,'' said Janis Francis, 32. ``You can enjoy it at all ages.'' O'Hara's team strategy was to outwit his opponent, while Francis took a different approach. ``Knock 'em down, bowl 'em over and entice 'em,'' she said. The event drew about 100 people to raise money for Chicago Easter Seals, organizers said.

DOC.HEAD: $1 Million in Phony $100 Bills Clogs Campus Sewer Line
DOC.TEXT: Plumbers trying to unclog a sewer line found about $1 million in counterfeit $100 bills beneath a university campus. Secret Service agents investigating Friday's discovery under California State University, Long Beach, said the wad of fake money appeared to come from the same lot as 10 phony bills passed in the area over the past 10 days. Investigators said the counterfeiter probably decided to dump the bills after people recognized them as fakes. ``My guess is that they decided it was unacceptable (quality) and tried to destroy it,'' said George Franklin, an agent in the Secret Service's Los Angeles office. Authorities said the money could have been flushed down a toilet or dropped into the university's sewage system through a manhole. Authorities said they had no suspects. ``I'm kind of dumbfounded,'' said University President Curtis L. McCray. ``I suppose it could have been someone here, but I find that hard to believe.''

DOC.HEAD: Old and New Planes Fly Over Palace to Salute Battle of Britain
DOC.TEXT: Spitfires and Hurricanes from Britain's ``finest hour'' in 1940 joined with jets representing the country's Persian Gulf force on Saturday in a salute to the Battle of Britain. The procession of 168 aircraft flew over Buckingham Palace, where Queen Elizabeth II and Prince Phillip were waiting on the balcony at noon. Also in the royal party was Prince Harry, son of Prince Charles, who was celebrating his 6th birthday on Saturday. King Baudouin and Queen Fabiola of Belgium, and Princess Juliana and Prince Bernhard of the Netherlands represented Britain's wartime allies. Prime Minister Margaret Thatcher and members of her Cabinet watched from another stand. The flight marked the 50th anniversary of the turning point of the battle. On Sept. 15, 1940, the Royal Air Force inflicted heavy losses on the Luftwaffe as it staged a daylight attack on the capital. Two days later, Adolf Hitler suspended plans for an invasion of Britain. The 300 pilots and navigators were led by Air Vice-Marshal Bill Wratten, Commander of 11 Group, which fought the Battle of Britain in the summer and autumn of 1940. Wratten piloted a Spitfire Mark 2 credited with shooting down three German aircraft. Two Hurricanes and five Spitfires from the Battle of Britain Memorial Flight led the cavalcade, which included the Red Arrow acrobatic team, a Lancaster bomber and some of the Tornado F3 jets like those deployed with the multinational forces in the Gulf. On the ground, there was a parade of 1,400 Royal Air Force, Royal Auxiliary Air Force, Royal Air Force Volunteer Reserve, Royal Observer Corps, Air Training Corps and other groups escorting the standards of the 17 Battle of Britain squadrons still in operation. The Canadian, Australian and New Zealand Air Forces also were represented. Also taking part were representatives of the Fire Brigade, Metropolitan Police and the Ambulance Service, which fought their own battles in 1940 against fires and explosions during the bombing. A total of 534 air crewmen - one in six - were killed during the battle and many others were seriously injured. The RAF lost 1,017 aircraft and Germany's Luftwaffe lost 1,882. After the battle Winston Churchill paid his famous tribute to the victors: ``Never in the field of human conflict was so much owed by so many to so few.'' It was Britain's lonely resistance to the German onslaught early in World War II that Churchill called the nation's ``finest hour.'' On Sunday, the queen and other members of the Royal Family planned to attend a service of thanksgiving at Westminster Abbey.

DOC.HEAD: Man Freed Thanks to Mom's Letter to Saddam Lands in United States
DOC.NOTE: Eds: UPDATES throughout with quotes, details of capture and use as human shield. No pickup.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto BA2
DOC.TEXT: An American banker released from Iraq because of a pleading letter from his mother to Saddam Hussein said Saturday he's glad to be out although others remain Middle East captives. Thomas Hart Benton Ewald, 25, of Greenwich, Conn., was one of 285 people allowed to leave Baghdad on a U.S.-chartered flight. They arrived at Baltimore-Washington International Airport on Saturday. Ewald said U.S. officials told him he is the first person used as a so-called human shield that Iraq has released. Iraq has deployed foreigners to military and industrial sites considered likely targets in the event of attack. ``It's a very lovely story, really,'' said his mother, Mary Ewald. ``In all this huge world, a letter can get through to somebody.'' Ewald said he was captured in Kuwait when he ventured outside to mail a letter. He was taken to Iraq, where he was kept at an installation he could not describe. ``I'm glad to be out,'' Ewald said. ``My friends and family are very glad I'm out, so I'm very happy for them. I'm also happy I got out because I can give more information about things that are going on in Kuwait and the detainees. ``On the other side, there are the inevitable feelings of guilt. I have some very good friends that I've made over in Iraq and in Kuwait and that's difficult. That's very difficult to leave them behind and not all the Americans are going to get out,'' Ewald said. Robert Gould, a spokesman for Maryland's Emergency Management Agency, said 114 people on the flight were U.S. citizens and 171 were foreigners. One hundred-forty-three were adults and there were 142 children. Also on the flight were two cats. A second planeload of Americans was expected to arrive Sunday at the airport. An Iraqi spokesman said Mrs. Ewald's plea was the only one the Iraqi embassy has received and that Saddam is open to similiar pleas. ``(Saddam) gave the order to allow him to go free and to return to his nation,'' Iraqi spokesman Riyadh Jawad said Friday in Washington. ``His excellency, he wants to give examples to prove that our behavior is not aggressive to our guests.'' Ewald began work this summer with the Al-Ahli Bank of Kuwait, arriving in Kuwait City two days before the Aug. 2 Iraqi invasion, his mother said. Mrs. Ewald said she wrote Saddam a ``humanitarian letter'' asking that her son be allowed to leave. She declined to release a copy. Ewald was one of only a few men on the plane. The Iraqi government has been holding foreign men hostage, while releasing some women and children. About 1,350 Americans remain in Kuwait and 200 in Iraq, with about 75 being deployed as human shields, State Department officials said. Ewald said he was taken into custody by the Iraqis Aug. 30, then taken to a Baghdad hotel before moving on to the unidentified installation Sept. 5. He said he escaped but was recaptured at a military base where he gave himself up after hearing shots around the ruined house where he was hiding. His welcome home included some teasing about how he got out. ``The fact that it's a note from Mom is pretty embarrassing - actually it's a lot embarrassing,'' he said. ``My friends have already started ribbing me pretty harshly.''

DOC.HEAD: Possible Piece of Downed Plane Sighted
DOC.TEXT: A Soviet trawler captain sighted what may be part of the fuselage of a missing Boeing 727 airliner that carried 16 people, Canadian rescue authorities said Saturday. The jet disappeared Tuesday after the pilot reported a fuel emergency and said he would ditch in the North Atlantic. ``Officials are fairly confident that what the captain sighted ... was a portion of the 727,'' said rescue worker Ross Brown. The trawler captain spotted an object 65 feet to 82 feet long that was dark gray with red and white stripes, matching Air Malta colors, Brown said. The plane, owned by Faucett Airlines of Peru, was leased by Air Malta and was carrying airline employees and their families. The Soviet captain made his sightings Friday about 236 miles southeast of Cape Race, Newfoundland, rescue officials said. However, Brown said, searchers had not spotted the object nor had anything else been recovered that was known to have come from the jet. Rescue officials didn't receive news of the sighting until Saturday, when a ham radio operator overheard conversations between several ships at sea. Search officials said at first they doubted the reports, but after discussions with the captain were convinced he had probably seen a piece of the fuselage. Weather conditions were deteriorating Saturday evening as Hurricane Isidore moved northward in the Atlantic, hindering an international group of planes and ships searching a 60,000-square-mile area, he said. The jet had been heading for a routine refueling stop in Gander, Newfoundland, en route from the Mediterranean island of Malta to Miami. The plane had stopped for refueling in Keflavik, Iceland, without incident.

DOC.HEAD: Florida Besieged as People Line Up to Vie for $100 Million Lotto Jackpot
DOC.NOTE: Eds: LEADS with six grafs to UPDATE with winning numbers and FIX to last week sted this week in 2nd graf. Determination of number of winners not exepected until Sunday.
DOC.HEAD: Laserphoto MH1
DOC.TEXT: Forget the $64,000 question. All of Florida and beyond wants to know the $100 million answer - who picked the six numbers in Saturday's drawing to win the nation's second largest jackpot. Lotto fever pulled people to the state like a magnet last week. On Saturday, officials reported people were spending hours in lines outside convenience stores and other outlets, waiting to buy a ticket they hope will make them an instant millionaire. ``There are a couple places, remote places, little out-of-the-way places, where for whatever reason they don't have long lines,'' said lottery spokesman Ed George, who considered a Saturday line of 15 people short. As the minutes ticked toward the 10:30 p.m. sales deadline for the 10:58 p.m. drawing, the enthusiasm kept building. ``Every time you turn on the news it's Lotto, Lotto, Lotto. Everybody's talking about it,'' said Art Yandoc of Miami, who bought 15 $1 tickets before playing tennis. The winning numbers drawn Saturday were: 6-35-34-45-21-5. Lottery officials won't know until Monday exactly how big the jackpot will be, but George said, ``We're well on our way to paying $100 million.'' The jackpot has grown each of the last four weeks as no one has picked all six winning numbers. But with so many people buying tickets, George said it's likely the prize will be divided between several people holding winning tickets this week. And officials didn't expect to know until Sunday whether there were any winners. To win the jackpot, players must pick the six winning numbers between 1 and 49 or have machines select them at random. The odds of winning are 1 in 14 million. Florida's previous record Lotto prize was $58 million, split between five winners in April. Pennsylvania's lottery produced the nation's highest jackpot - $115 million - in April 1989. At a truck stop in Jennings, five miles from the Georgia border, the wait for tickets lasted five hours and vehicles with license plates from New York, Tennessee, Wisconsin, Louisiana and even California were backed up on the Interstate 75 ramp. ``We do more lottery than diesel. The trucks can't get in here,'' said Liz Burse, manager at Johnson and Johnson truck stop. One bettor tried to jump into line and ``they nearly lynched him,'' she said. Florida laws limit lottery ticket sales to inside the state and only through authorized retailers. At a Chevron station across from Miami International Airport, taxis dropped off people who flew in from such cities as Houston, St. Louis and New York. Some bettors were buying tickets by the hundreds or even thousands. Bill Villafina of Kissimmee said he spent more than seven hours purchasing tickets - all part of a plan to spend ``somewhere in the neighborhood of $50,000,'' primarily for New Jersey relatives. About 175 employees at Jensen Corp., a Fort Lauderdale restaurant and hospital equipment manufacturer, found a Lotto ticket tucked into each of their paycheck envelopes Friday. ``It used to be said that the American dream was a good job, owning your own home and a chicken in every pot,'' a company letter said. ``Nowadays, the American dream is to win a state lottery.''

Senate Judiciary Committee members on both sides of the abortion issue have failed to extract from Supreme Court nominee David Souter his view of how he would approach the subject on the nation's highest court. But the responses from the New Hampshire judge could make either side nervous. In his second day of testimony Friday, Souter denied he would join the Supreme Court with any decision already made on overturning the 1973 abortion rights ruling in Roe vs. Wade. ``I have not got any agenda on what should be done with Roe vs. Wade. I would listen to both sides of that case. I have not made up my mind,'' he said. ---= WASHINGTON (AP) - Democrats are avoiding criticism of President Bush's Persian Gulf policy while openly condemning his domestic stands and his party's ``greed and debt.'' Democratic Party leaders, meeting today uptown from the White House, are formally endorsing Bush's decision to send troops to block Iraq's aggression in the Middle East. But that backing for the Republican president doesn't extend to his domestic policy, which the Democrats say characterize a ``decade of Republican greed and debt.'' On the agenda for the meeting of the Democratic National Committee were resolutions denouncing ``the failure of three successive Republican administrations to develop a national energy policy'' and blaming the GOP for the savings and loan crisis. ---= WASHINGTON (AP) - More than tax increases and spending cuts are at stake in the nearly `round-the-clock deficit-reduction negotiations between congressional and Bush administration officials. As they struggle to avert wholesale cuts in federal programs next month, the president's aides and top members of Congress also must decide how to divide targeted tax cuts that would cost more than $20 billion over the next five years. The intended beneficiaries include rich investors, giant corporations, first-time homebuyers and workers pursuing employer-financed educations. Most of a dozen tax benefits that expire this year enjoy wide support in Congress and are backed by the administration. Thus, their renewal is likely to be attached to any deficit package approved by the negotiators. That package likely will be the only tax bill passed this year. The fate of another big proposed tax cut - one that has been the subject of a running battle between Congress and President Bush since he took office - is far less certain. The administration insists on including in the package a cut in the tax on capital gains. But Democratic leaders are saying that can't be done unless overall income tax rates on upper-income Americans are raised to pay for it. ---= CHICAGO (AP) - Jim Lord's basement is chock-full of tractor-trailers, moving vans, dump trucks and gasoline tankers. There's so many of them, the traffic jam has spread to his barn. At last count, the retired pipefitter had 2,700 toy trucks, but not just any trucks. The ones Lord collects are reproductions of big-name company haulers that can't be found in stores. Lord, 75, is one of about 4,000 enthusiasts to search out the handcrafted gems made by Winross Co. for such companies as Exxon Corp., the Adolph Coors Co. and Campbell Soup Co. ``You can't get them in stores, so we have to find out about them via the grapevine,'' he said recently. ``It's really the challenge of getting them that makes them so sought-after.'' The 6-inch-long trucks are sold to companies by Winross, a family-owned business in Rochester, N.Y., for about $30 dollars each. They look like the companies' real trucks, logos included, and are used as promotional giveaways.

DOC.HEAD: Auto Workers, GM Recess Contract Talks, No Strike Called
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Serves as 1st Ld - Writethru to f0204 for AMs; also on general news wire.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY39
DOC.TEXT: The United Auto Workers union and General Motors Corp. recessed talks early Saturday on a national labor contract and the union told its members not to strike. Negotiators had faced a midnight strike deadline. Talks were to resume Saturday morning on a three-year contract for about 300,000 active GM workers in 29 states. The contract would serve as a model for talks with other major automakers. ``GM thinks that meaningful progress has been made in the current contract negotiations and that an agreement will be reached,'' said a statement issued by GM Vice President Alfred S. Warren Jr. ``Negotiators will continue efforts to achieve this goal.'' The latest bargaining session ended about 12:20 a.m. ``We are continuing our efforts to reach a settlement.'' UAW Vice President Stephen Yokich said in a statement released about 10:45 p.m. ``UAW-represented workers have been advised to stay on the job and report for work on their regular shift until further notice.'' Only GM's Bowling Green, Ky., assembly plant, which makes Corvettes, was scheduled for production during the weekend. The company's other 30 car and truck assembly plants are idle on weekends. The UAW's contracts with GM, Ford and Chrysler Corp. expired at midnight. They cover more than 450,000 active auto workers in the United States and Wallaceburg, Ontario. In Toronto, the Canadian Auto Workers called a strike Friday against Ford Motor Co.'s Canadian subsidiary after negotiators did not meet a midnight deadline. Negotiators had reported talks were progressing and bargaining was to resume Saturday. Ford plants in Canada are closed weekends. It was the first Ford Canada strike since 1976. The CAW represents about 12,800 Ford workers. The Canadian workers make a variety of components for Ford's U.S. assembly plants. A strike in Canada would likely affect the company's U.S. operations within a week. In the United States, the UAW chose on Aug. 28 to focus its bargaining on GM. Talks with Ford and Chrysler have been put on hold since. UAW leaders have said they plan to use a contract ratified by GM workers as a pattern for agreements at Ford and Chrysler. As the talks entered their final hours, unresolved issues included job security, wages and pensions. Union leaders contacted Friday said they were not told details about the unresolved issues. Tentative agreements had been reached on a variety of mostly non-economic issues including health, safety and attendance policy. Dramatic changes in the auto industry during the 1980s, especially the growth of Japanese automakers' shares of the U.S. car and truck market, have affected labor relations between the UAW and the Big Three in general and GM specifically. The Big Three's collective market share dropped about 6 percentage points during the decade to about 68 percent last year. During the same time, the Japanese companies' share rose by about the same amount to over 25 percent. That has forced GM, Ford and Chrysler to shrink their operations and their work forces. In response, the UAW's primary emphasis has shifted to job security from wage increases. As the companies worked to cut costs, they adopted a parts delivery system called ``just-in-time.'' Under such a scheme, automakers ship parts and component systems to assembly plants just before they are needed, sometimes within hours of installation. At the same time, automakers consolidated manufacturing to reduce redundancies and expenses. That opened a new strategy for the UAW - one whose effects were shown last month. Because of just-in-time delivery, the UAW can shut down assembly plants, some of which have more than 5,000 workers, by striking a critical parts plant that employs far fewer people. Last month, the UAW struck GM's AC Rochester West parts plant in Flint for six days over local issues, including an employment level guarantee. Before the walkout ended, GM was forced to close seven assembly plants because of parts shortages. Those shutdowns, in turn, resulted in layoffs at other component plants.

DOC.HEAD: New York Post Gets Temporary Reprieve
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Serves as 2nd Ld - Writethru to f0271 for AMs; also on general news wires.
DOC.HEAD: LaserPhoto NY35 sent Sept. 14.
DOC.TEXT: The New York Post got a temporary reprieve Friday night when all but one of its unions agreed to concessions designed to save the feisty but unprofitable tabloid. ``Ain't Over Yet'' declared Saturday's front page headline when it rolled off the presses early Saturday, hours behind schedule. Post Owner Peter Kalikow had threatened to close the paper after Saturday's editions without the cuts. Ten unions at the paper agreed to concessions during marathon negotiating sessions. Kalikow said he needed $19 million in concessions to keep publishing the newspaper, the nation's oldest continuously published daily. The paper is losing about $27 million a year. The last union, The Newspaper Guild, will vote on his offer Monday night, Kalikow said. The Guild represents 350 editorial and advertising employees. The union's negotiating team voted 7-3 against the offer. ``I feel optimistic that when the members see it they will approve it,'' Kalikow said of his offer. If the Guild members reject the offer, the Post will cease publishing immediately, he said. The newspaper has a circulation of 505,000. ``It was the best offer we could make under the circumstances,'' he said. Barry Lipton, president of Local 3 of the Newspaper Guild, said he recommended his members accept the package. Details were not disclosed. ``It's up to the members. It's the very best we could do. ... I hope that the sense of the membership is to swallow what may be a bitter pill,'' he said. Members of each union must ratify the agreements, but it appeared the Guild vote was the key because its negotiators didn't support the pact. The reprieve was announced after talks stretched for more than 12 hours and passed two deadlines. The paper had planned to print its history, including reminiscences of former employees, if Saturday's edition was its last. ``It's a terrific farewell edition we prepared but hopefully it'll never be read by the public,'' metropolitan editor John Cotter said. Talks had resumed Friday morning between the paper and the Guild and other unions representing more than 850 of the Post's 960 employees. The newspaper's contracts with the unions expire in March 1991. Kalikow said the concessions included pay cuts and layoffs. He said workers would be given stock in the newspaper under the agreements. ``It was a bitter pill for these people to swallow but they realized it was important to save the Post,'' he said. A source involved in the Guild negotiations, who requested anonymity, said that the Post had roposed a cut of 43 Guild-covered jobs. Previously, the newspaper had favored pay cuts rather than job cuts, while the union has called for attrition through resignations and buyouts. The situation was complicated by the plight of the Daily News, which also is losing money, and which also is in the midst of a labor conflict. News executives say any concessions the unions give the Post must also be given the News under ``me-too'' contract clauses. And The New York Times said it would seek union concessions to the extent that they were related to the same economic conditions that have affected the Post and News and led to declines in the papers' ad revenue. Money troubles are not new to the Post - even its founder had them. Alexander Hamilton was heavily in debt in 1801 when he persuaded a group of merchants to finance the paper. His was merely the first of many famous names to be associated with the paper. In the 1820s, New England poet William Cullen Bryant began a 50-year tenure as editor. Poet Walt Whitman covered the Civil War for the Post. Franklin Delano Roosevelt was briefly a co-owner in the 1920s. Heiress Dorothy Schiff bought the Post in 1939 and tried to attract more readers with comics, features, a tabloid format, strong sports stories and nearly 50 columnists. Schiff also made the paper one of the nation's most liberal. Her self-described formula: ``honest unionism, social reform and humane government programs.'' But the humane reformer also was a bit tightfisted. The Post became known for making do with a small staff and old equipment. By the mid-1970s, much of the Post's liberal, middle-class readership had moved to the suburbs. In 1976, Schiff sold the paper to Australian media baron Rupert Murdoch for $31 million. At the time the paper was losing $500,000 annually. Under Murdoch, the Post took on a conservative voice and began dishing out sexy pictures, racy headlines - including the famous ``HEADLESS BODY IN TOPLESS BAR'' - and a steady diet of crime stories. Murdoch said the paper lost $150 million before he sold it in 1988 for $37 million to Kalikow, a real estate developer who also acquired the paper's valuable waterfront land on South Street in Lower Manhattan.

DOC.HEAD: Canadian Autoworkers Call Strike Against Ford
DOC.NOTE: Eds: Updates throughout for AMs as 1st Ld - Writethru to f0298; also on general news wires.
DOC.TEXT: The Canadian Auto Workers union called a strike against Ford Motor Co. of Canada on Friday after negotiators decided they could not meet a midnight deadline for settling all the issues. ``At midnight tonight, we will be commencing the first strike we have had against Ford of Canada since 1976,'' CAW President Robert White said late Friday. ``We still have a very significant distance between the two positions,'' Don MacKenzie, Ford's chief negotiator, told reporters as discussions broke off for the day at a downtown Toronto hotel. Despite the strike announcement, both sides said talks would resume Saturday. Earlier Friday, union and company officials had agreed communication was good and that work was progressing toward a new contract. But White had acknowledged it was virtually impossible to get everything done by the midnight Friday strike deadline. ``It would take a miracle to get all the work that has to be done finished before midnight,'' he had said. Up to 12,800 workers are expected to walk off the job at nine plants and two offices in Ontario. The company has two plants in Oakville, five in Windsor, one in St. Thomas and one in Niagara Falls. However, the strike won't mean anything in terms of production until Monday because Canadian Ford plants do not operate on the weekend. In Detroit, the United Auto Workers union and General Motors Corp. agreed to extend their national labor contract Friday, hours before the same midnight strike deadline as in Canada, local union leaders said. ``They're going to negotiate through the weekend,'' said Charlie Gledhill, acting president of UAW 549 at GM's metal stamping plant in Mansfield, Ohio. ``We're not going to walk out tonight.'' Those talks recessed early Saturday and were expected to continue later in the day. In both countries, the unions target a single company in their talks in hopes of fashioning a pattern contract for workers at other automakers. White said his union's decision to target Ford instead of General Motors like his counterparts in the United States has proved to be the correct move. He said the CAW now has the full attention of Ford and its top officials. If the Canadian union had decided to strike GM, the efforts and attention of company officials would be focused on the U.S. negotiations. The CAW has a $34 million strike fund to support a walkout. White said earlier in the day that Ford had not made a new economic proposal since the first one put on the table a few days ago, which the union found unacceptable. He said the CAW had presented Ford with a counterproposal early Friday and that Ford officials went off to calculate the numbers. Ford Canada spokesman Jim Hartford confirmed that, but said he did not know how long it would take Ford to work out the cost of the union proposal. Neither side offered details of the proposals. Both sides had indicated progress had been made in some areas. After announcing the strike late Friday, White said the tough issues were job security, inflation, and time off. ``Ford is balking at putting enough economics on the table to get an agreement,'' he said. The Canadian branch of the American car giant is suffering from flagging sales, down 6.4 percent in August from a year ago, according to Hartford.
